graf: The garbanzo field yielded two days of work. It was now two weeks later and Galvez hadn’t found any other jobs. He said the fields are his only choice. In Oaxaca, he left school after fourth grade to work. He’s been in California since he was 17, but he is not a U.S. citizen.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Rafael, a man who has worked under many last names, knows a lot of contractors and used to be able to line up work ahead of time.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: But now, in the early mornings, long before sunrise, they go to the parking lot in front of the panaderia where they can no longer afford to buy Mexican sweetbread and coffee. They wait with other day laborers for a contractor to drive up and bark an offer.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: The week before the going rate was $8 an hour, minus $8 to $12 a day for a ride in the van to fields 45 minutes away. So many people have fled town that farmers were hurting for workers and the offer on this day had gone up to $8.50 an hour. Still, Galvez hadn’t been hired. He went home when he wanted to be working.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: His two youngest girls, a tangle of giggles, played leapfrog in the empty living room. Manuel, 16, the oldest of six children, was in his room studying.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Galvez is proud of Manuel for avoiding the streets.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “He comes straight home from school. He works out, watches TV and stays inside. He wants to join the Navy someday,” Galvez said. “I tell the other ones, ‘Be like your brother.’”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Shyly, lowering his head, Galvez recalled that recently Manuel gave him a playful punch in the arm and they tussled the way they did when his son was small.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “He told me he was proud of me. He told me he wanted to be like me,” Galvez said. “I said, ‘I don’t want you to be like me. You have to be better than me.’”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: By late April, the air held the warmth of growing season.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Water flowed in concrete canals. Precisely set sprinklers sent their spray ch-ch-ch-ing over fields. A high school runner in red shorts stood out against miles of blue-green onion fields.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: The illusion of lushness was there. But without the rains, even California’s vast system of buying, selling, pumping and moving trillions of gallons of water from the Sacramento Delta to this dry, clay-bottom plain — even pumping so much groundwater that parts of the Central Valley sink a foot a year — wasn’t enough to keep Huron working.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: The main drag was as sleepy as the stray dogs napping in every shady doorway. Two men in cowboy hats gossiped on a bench. A daily afternoon poker game was languidly being played in a window booth at a near-empty cafe.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “Only for fun, no money,” the waitress said, though there were clearly stacks of bills on the table.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Huron already whispered of the ghost town it could soon be: It has a $2-million deficit.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Only about 1,000 people in a town with a permanent population of 7,000 are registered to vote, and of those, only some 200 actually do.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: No one has declared for the two open City Council seats — including the incumbents. Each week at school, Galvez’s children have fewer classmates.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Antonio Chavarrias, a fieldworker, said the drought is different from other natural disasters because it doesn’t end. This is the third year of drought but, he said, just the beginning of the hardships.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “It’s going to get worse,” he said. “They’re not planting. Think what it will be like at harvest.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Chavarrias came from El Salvador, where, he said, people make $6 for five hours of work. He supports a 22-year-old daughter and a 20-year-old son going to college there.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “They’re in my heart,” he said. He hasn’t seen them in 10 years.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Galvez is determined that the one sacrifice he won’t make for his family is leaving them.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Once before when times were hard, he went alone to Texas to work. He was gone more than three years.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: There was another man. He almost lost his wife.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “I lose time with the children. I lose everything,” he said. “I don’t want to do it again.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: But if they stay, he doesn’t have work. The family now owed almost two months’ back rent.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “It’s breaking my head, wondering what are we going to do, what are we going to do?” he said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Mormons were at Galvez’s house — two blond, Spanish-speaking women from Utah who had been coming weekly.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Down the street, a man in a crisp plaid shirt was walking around in the heat, shaking hands and introducing himself to everyone he passed. He was an evangelical pastor from Lemoore.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: The drought is bringing a lot of religion to Huron. Ministers walk the streets; bars notorious for violence and prostitution are empty.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “We’ve been having less problems downtown,” said Police Chief George Turegano, a retired Capitola officer. “People have less money in their pocket. They’re saving it to move to the next town, the next job.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: When Turegano took the job two years ago — the 10th police chief in about as many years — he told his friends in law enforcement that Huron was like the Wild West.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “Not too many bedroom communities have the level of nightly shootings, prostitution and domestic abuse as these small Westside towns,” he said. “But it’s calmer lately.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: At Galvez’s house the lead missionary was encouraging Galvez’s middle daughter, 12-year-old Dianey, in prayer.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “Just say what’s in your heart,” she told her.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Dianey haltingly gave thanks for waking up in the morning, and that her grandmother hadn’t been sick lately. She didn’t pray for rain as numerous signs across the Central Valley suggest.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Galvez, who was raised Catholic, has been going to several different churches.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: “I like what they say. They all say the same thing: ‘If your mind is right you can talk to God and he will tell you what to do,’” he said. “I still have to learn how to make my mind right.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: In May, a season when Huron’s population once doubled with workers planting and picking, Galvez had found three days of work in two weeks.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: The family was down to the amount of his last check: $256. They had stocked up on huge bags of beans and rice. The Mormon missionaries had brought misshapen cupcakes, the cake not reaching to the top of the cups and canned chocolate frosting three times higher. Two family friends had brought over bags of sweet breads and cilantro from their garden.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: Galvez and Maya called a family meeting. Galvez said they told the children they would probably be moving to Texas soon.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Dreams die in drought
graf: The 15-year-old, Itzel, said no, she had a boyfriend. The 11-year-old, Francisco, said no, he liked his school. The oldest son, Manuel, said not a word. He only put a hand on his father’s shoulder.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Beneath this small farm town at the end of what’s left of the Kings River, the ground is sinking.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Going into the fourth year of drought, farmers have pumped so much water that the water table below Stratford fell 100 feet in two years. Land in some spots in the Central Valley has dropped a foot a year.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: In July, the town well cracked in three places. Household pipes spit black mud, then pale yellow water. After that, taps were dry for two weeks while the water district patched the steel well casing.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: In September, the children of migrant farmworkers who usually come back to Stratford School a few weeks late, after the grape harvest, never came back at all.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: By October, there were new faces in the drought relief line in front of the school, picking up boxes of applesauce, canned tomatoes, peanut butter, rice.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: If rain doesn’t come soon to California, cities and suburbs will survive, with maybe fewer flower beds or more expensive lettuce.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: But in Stratford — where the school has had some of the same teachers for 40 years, the auto parts store doubles as a coffeehouse and first names change but last names don’t — survival isn’t a given.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Even above ground, the town is sinking.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Arches at both ends of the town square spell out S-T-R-A-T-FO-R-D in the shape of a rainbow. Years ago there was a population sign, but people argue over the last number it gave. There are about 900 people left now.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: The glory days, when the arches were entrances to burger joints and gas stations for Central Valley residents driving to Pismo Beach, faded decades ago.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “But nothing like this,” said Josh Orton, manager of the farm equipment store his great-great-grandfather started in 1906. “There’s just no water.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Two doors down at Hardin’s Grocery, the inventory has evaporated to a puddle of chips, drinks, tobacco and pregnancy tests near the cash register.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Customers push open the door to the dim store and its empty shelves, hollering “Hey ya, Kenny, or “ Hola, Kenny” over the door chimes.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “Oye, Carnal” — “hey, dude” — the Yemeni store owner with tired eyes answers in Spanish slang.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: His name is Mahmod Alrihimi, but they’ve been calling him Kenny for 24 years, ever since he leased the business from Mr. Hardin, who still lives in a trailer behind the grocery. (“I don’t know why ‘Kenny.’ Maybe it is easier for them to say?”)

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Each day Alrihimi opens the store at 8 a.m. and closes at 10 p.m. If he’s really tired he’ll go home a half-hour early, but people invariably knock on his door and say, “Kenny, can you come out? We just need a bottle of milk.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: He doesn’t mind. He likes feeling needed. “I really love this town. I know so many families,” he said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: A man put two packages of hot dog buns and a roll of paper towels on the counter.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “Hey, Kenny, OK if I pay for these after Friday?” he asked, lowering his voice.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Alrihimi nodded. But his stomach dropped. This was a man who had never asked for credit before.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: The store owner had 29 receipts that constituted the week’s IOUs. On the backs of two torn-up cigarette cartons, he wrote the running accounts: the ones where they owed $34, paid $12, then charged $8.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “It’s too sad to say no. I think of their kids,” said Alrihimi, a father of five.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “They don’t have any money. I don’t have any money. We’re all trying to get through, little-by-little-bit.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: When he has to run errands, Darlene Lacey watches the store. She’s been helping out since her husband died 13 years ago.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Alrihimi worries about her.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “I think that when people can’t pay, she takes money out of her own pocket and puts it in the cash register,” he said. “She is a very good-heart lady. But she has too little money.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Later that afternoon, when Alrihimi was at the bank, Lacey rang up two sodas for an elderly couple who asked for credit. Then she slipped $2 in the cash register.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “Kenny is hanging on by a thread,” she said. “And, oh my gosh, our little town needs him.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Next door at the post office, a wall of boxes have “closed” stickers over them. They belong to families who’ve moved or haven’t paid their bills.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: The lone employee, Rick Kimball, is bending the rules and keeping mail for those still in town. (“They’re working their tails off to get by. Seems like the least I can do.”)

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: He likes learning about people by paying attention to their mail.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “The Hamiltons? Nice folks. All the women’s first names start with “S” and all the men are named Tony,” he said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Johnny Caldeira, 36, picked up a package, then leaned his elbows on the counter to chat.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “I’m beginning to feel like a bartender,” Kimball, a former parole officer and truck driver, told him.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “You’re the hangout spot now,” Caldeira said. “There aren’t any other places left.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Caldeira went to Stratford School. Most of the classmates he graduated with in eighth grade are still in town.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “Adrian teaches fourth grade, Danny’s in the reserves. The Meyers — George and Charlie — farm,” Caldeira said. “They just lost their grandfather, old man Meyers. I think he was 100. We just lost Mr. Henry.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: His former seventh-grade teacher, William Henry, persuaded Caldeira to go to college after he returned from the war in Iraq. This month the graduate takes the test for his credentials. He wants to teach in Stratford like the man who pushed him.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “Mr. Henry used to be in the Navy before he was a teacher, so when I came back, I could actually talk to him. He had seen things too.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “At first it was, ‘How you doing? When you going back to school?’ Then one day he comes in, slams down a college application and says, ‘Now get your ass in school before I kick it.’ That’s a cleaned-up version. Mr. Henry had a mouth.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Each spring, the seventh- and eighth-graders still dance around a maypole, and there’s always a festa at the Portuguese Hall.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: But it’s the Constitution Day Parade that is really something to behold, said David Orton, Josh’s father.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: A couple of farmers pull kindergartners on flatbed trucks. The Ortons add a tractor and Stratford School Principal Bill Bilbo rides his motorcycle — a crowd favorite.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “There are so many people in the parade that it leaves about 20 people watching,” Orton said, shaking with laughter. “And the next year, we do it again. This town has a way of holding on.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: The Orton family first came to farm in Stratford in the 1800s, when they got pushed off their Lemoore land by railroad barons.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Back then, their farm was on the edge of Tulare Lake — “the lake that once was.” It had been the largest body of fresh water west of the Mississippi, some four and a half times bigger than Lake Tahoe. But the four Sierra rivers that flowed to the lake — the Kings, Kern, Kaweah and Tule — were dammed, diverting water that powerful landowners could own and sell. The tule fog that rises from the ground and blankets the Central Valley in a blinding thickness each winter is said to be a Yokut Indian curse that the stolen waters shall haunt this place forever.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: The drought is affecting even eternal curses. There seems to be less fog each year. Farmers fear it could hurt the moisture-loving, high-value nut crops that are quickly replacing fields of alfalfa, tomatoes and cotton.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: At the Ortons, they still grow row crops, but they planted only 18 of their 100 acres. Now two wells are out and they don’t have water for what they planted.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “We’re growing dirt,” David Orton said. “It’s a very popular crop around here right now.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: On a Wednesday morning when the sky was still dawn-pink, Allyson Lemons and JD, her husband of 62 years, walked to the auto parts store. She carried a plate of fresh-baked chocolate chip cookies.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: With all the town’s cafes long gone, Chris Rodriques always puts on a pot of coffee at his family’s store. On Wednesdays, Allyson and JD bring cookies. Last week it was her cornflake recipe.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: The couple took their place at a long table with floral-patterned dinette chairs, where a group of neighbors had already settled in.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: A couple of farmers read the Wall Street Journal. Dick Newton, 67, stretched out long legs while he checked college football scores in the local paper.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Newton is one of the old families by dint of his mother’s side, who settled in the area in 1905. His father’s family didn’t come till 1911.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: They got to chatting about that time when Newton and his brother were water-skiing on the Kings River — there was water in it then — and from the far bank, Newton’s brother shot an arrow at one of the Lemons’ chickens. The arrow went right through the bird’s neck and carried it to the front porch.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “You remember that?” Newton asked.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “Oh, do I,” said Allyson Lemons. “I heard something. Came to the door. And it landed right at my feet. I cooked it up for dinner.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: The Newton brother who shot the chicken is now farming marijuana on Orcas Island in Washington state, where the crop is legal.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: Newton had a text from a farmer who said that 70% of his crop of pistachios were blanks — no nuts inside.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: No one knew the reason for sure, but when the snows don’t come and rain doesn’t fall and even the fog thins, things go wrong.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: On the other side of the square, Alrihimi opened for the day. Three years ago he’d had a deli in back, with lines of field workers out the door twice a day. Now, he owed “so, so much money.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: The other week, a farmer had put a hand on his shoulder and said, “Kenny, when the rain comes, the money comes.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: “I pray every day the water is coming back,” he said. “I don’t want to leave here.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Sinking land and hearts
graf: He sat on a milk crate in the doorway of the store. Lacey pulled out a crate and joined him in the sunshine of another cloudless day.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: When a man of 91 is downright cantankerous and has been on his land longer than most everyone else has been alive, he wastes no time speaking his mind.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: So after his new neighbor started sinking a well to plant a water-sucking almond orchard in the middle of the worst drought he’d ever seen, James Turner hurried over.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “How deep you going to dig your well?”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Five hundred feet, Davinder Singh told him.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “My well is 300 feet. Why, you’re going to take my water!”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Singh, a man of gentle humor, gave no answer on that warm day last winter. Yet he took an instant liking to the fierce old man.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner reminded him of his 85-year-old father back in India — he’d been a police officer who stubbornly refused every bribe, guaranteeing his family grew up in poverty in a region known for corrupt authorities.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Now Singh was chasing prosperity in California’s almond rush.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Up and down these rural Madera roads with fractional names — Avenue 19, Avenue 19½, Avenue 20 — nut trees were going in, wells were going dry and farmers were putting debt-heavy bets on a crop that requires twice as much water as thirsty cotton.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: They’re doing it not just in spite of the drought, but because of it: Almonds may be California’s last crop valuable enough to make a profit if the drought doesn’t end.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner thought the folks buying up swaths of land for orchards — some of them investment fund managers who had never farmed a day in their lives — were missing the bigger picture.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “You pump all the water out, the land collapses, see? All those pockets where the water is supposed to go, they won’t be there when it does rain,” he said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “I’ve seen so much stupid in my years that I can’t remember all of it. But pumping the earth dry? We’re killing ourselves, plain and simple.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: All through the summer, Turner’s daughter Lorna — he still called her “Lil Bit,” like he had since the day she was born — couldn’t sleep.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “I’d hear that pump roaring over at Dave’s all night every night,” she said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Driving to her job as an accountant at a women’s prison in Chowchilla or over to Fairmead to visit her Aunt Zel, she’d gape at a land so quickly transformed.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “Growing up, there was nothing but grapevines, cotton fields, a few animals grazing and then, overnight, nothing but nut trees,” she said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Zelma Baker, 91, had come to California during the great Dust Bowl migration of the 1930s.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “I don’t know nothing about anything called the Dust Bowl,” said Baker, Lorna’s maternal aunt. “But I do know we left Okemah, Okla., on April 7, 1936, and we arrived in California on Oct. 20.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner’s family, sharecroppers, had come from Oklahoma 10 years earlier. He was only 3, but he still has an accent thick as butter on corn bread, like many of those raised in the Central Valley.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: He bought the farm the year he married and paid off the land in seven years — he didn’t believe in owing money. Growing cotton and alfalfa on the 20 acres didn’t feed five children, so he worked construction and grew grapes and fruit trees.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: In late April, Turner’s well went dry. Across the street, his neighbor, a beekeeper, also ran out of water.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “He told me, ‘James, we’re looking at a reverse Dust Bowl.’”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner had water trucked in. Lorna washed the dishes as quickly as possible and made her 15-year-old son, Travon, keep his showers to four minutes.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner’s daughter and grandson had moved in after his wife, Ernestine, died in 2008.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “We’d been married 60 years when she died,” he said. “We never split. Not once. She was a good woman. She helped me a lot.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: On the day he spoke of Ernestine, he was hauling wood in a cart hooked to his 1955 tractor and listening to a news station on a transistor radio of apparently similar vintage. The topic turned to unrest over an unarmed black teenager killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo. Turner — a black man — turned off the radio.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Rage was one of the things Ernestine had helped him with. He was a soldier about to ship off to the Pacific Theater during World War II when the train stopped in Texas and he got off to get a hamburger.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “I was clean, pressed — I believed in having my clothes nice,” he said. “I had a bruise on my shoulder from sharpshooter practice. I could feel the spot. A man in a dirty shirt looked at me and said, ‘You want anything to eat, then you go over there and get it,’ and he pointed to a corner that said ‘Negroes.’ There I was in Uncle Sam’s uniform maybe going to die for him and this man wouldn’t sell me a hamburger.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner said if he’d had his rifle, he would have shot the man dead. He kept thinking about that until he told Ernestine.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “She wasn’t one to let people walk over her, but she could make a man look forward instead of back,” he said. “I miss her.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Abruptly, he changed his attention to a fluffy dog darting around.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “I don’t like dogs, never have,” he said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “Lil Bit and T., they sneak this one in the house at night. They think I don’t know. I’m old, see? So they think I’m stupid. But I know.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner couldn’t remember a hotter year. It ended up being the hottest on record in California.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: The grapevines growing at the edge of his property had leaves that were dark and curled, but the stress somehow made the Thompson grapes taste better. He told Singh to help himself to the fruit, and he did.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Singh’s wife, Balwinder, offered Turner cups of fragrant, sweet chai, which he always refused. He thought it was strange they drank hot tea in the summer.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: He paid almost $400 to have water trucked in every few weeks. He had the delivery man fill a 2,500-gallon tank and sprinkle a bit on the garden.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner loved his rosebushes best.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: In 1979, when he was recovering from a heart attack, Ernestine brought him a single-stemmed red rose from the grocery store.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “I’m laying in the hospital bed and I looked at that rose and I said, ‘Boy, that rose is pretty.’ That made me love my wife even more. I said to myself, ‘If I get out of this hospital I’m going to plant me a garden of roses.’”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: In July, his rosebushes were dry and had few blooms, but they were alive.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: In the almond groves, harvest was starting when the nuts should have been just cracking open. The clouds of pink and white blooms had arrived at the beginning of February, earlier than anyone could recall. Farmers ran pumps throughout the ominously warm spring as well as the summer.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: You could say almonds, heralded as an anti-aging super nut (technically a seed), are a doomsday food: If aquifers in the world’s farming regions continue to go down and food supplies falter, they’re a source of protein that requires fewer resources than meat or dairy.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Prices were already around $4 a pound — or about $120,000 an acre even with low yield.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “Everything is going up, up, up — except the water table,” Singh said. At the end of July, when the heat hung still and heavy, Turner decided to stop watering.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: There was no guarantee the fall rains would come. His well driller had a waiting list so long that he didn’t expect to get to the wells that had run out in April until December.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner went to a family reunion in New Orleans, and when he was gone, Singh looked across and saw the shriveling vines, the brown shrubs.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “What’s going on over there?” he asked his workers. They said the family was gone for a few weeks and their well was dry.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Singh halted work on the orchard and hooked up a hose to his domestic well. He dragged it over and watered Turner’s plants.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: When Turner returned, Singh told him he should have let him know he was out of water. They were neighbors. He would fill his tank for him every few weeks.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: The gesture hasn’t saved Singh from Turner’s occasional scoldings.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: In October, Singh invited Turner on a trip to Home Depot. Turner found out it was in part to use his military discount on $3,000 worth of farm equipment.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “Why, you had me out after dark. I don’t stay out after dark. I have a cold now,” Turner told him sternly through a closed screen door the next time his neighbor visited. Singh looked down at his feet, hiding a smile during the chiding.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: They don’t know a lot about each other.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Singh doesn’t know that Turner’s children talked him into a reverse mortgage so he and Ernestine could travel in their senior years. Instead, the money went to Ernestine’s hospital bills and, now, a well.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner doesn’t know that Singh drove a truck for someone else, then bought his own truck, then a fleet, saving for years to fulfill a dream of raising his family on a large farm, the way his wife had grown up in India.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: But as to why Singh gives water to Turner, and how Turner feels about the neighbor delivering water, they give the same answer: “He’s a good man.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: It smelled like it was about to rain — a sweet, earthy musk rising from the ground, a fresh breeze beginning to stir.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Singh and his workers and family sat outside drinking chai and looking at the orchard on a December day. In less than a year, the trees had gone from slender, foottall sticks to taller than a person.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: Turner watched from his dining room window.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: “Them trees sure look pretty. Green, topped off nice and straight,” he said. “And hot tea makes sense today.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: One or two storms wouldn’t make a dent in the drought. By most measures, there would have to be a good soaking every three days for the next six months to fill California’s reservoirs. Snow would have to pile up on the Sierra mountains, shining white well into spring, before a vast system of aqueducts and canals would deliver promised water.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: California had recently passed the first legislation to manage its groundwater, but Turner said he wasn’t putting much store by that. It didn’t kick in until 2040.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: He hadn’t felt right about using the water Singh gave him for anything but household necessities. One orange tree in the garden had survived, but was struggling. He missed the way it usually looked this time of year. Covered with bright orange balls, shining like Christmas lights.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: He was pretty sure his favorite rosebush — the one out by the mailbox, that grew big red roses just like the one Ernestine gave him — was dead.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Wells full of generosity
graf: But he’d noticed a speck of green down at the bottom. January was the best month to cut back roses. He’d read that once in a newspaper gardening column. Come the new year he was going to cut it all the way down. Maybe it could still come back.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: The grandmother sat outside in her Sunday best next to a house with peeling paint, her canned iced tea resting on top of a washing machine that didn’t work. She’d been without running water for four months.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Up an easy-to-miss dirt road, a 70-year-old woman moved 5-gallon jugs of water into her single-wide trailer. It was hard because she was weak from chemotherapy. Her water had stopped coming out of the tap three months ago.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: At the elementary school, a kitchen worker talked about all the children who were coming to school dirty.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: This scattered Tulare County community may be the hardest-hit place in California’s punishing drought. Of its 7,300 people, almost 1,000 have no running water.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: But few knew that until Donna Johnson, 72, started counting.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: During a week when the temperature reached 106, Johnson drove her purple PT Cruiser past “Beware of dog” signs and up side roads that looked long-deserted. She found mobile homes hidden behind other buildings. She said to her newfound neighbors, “Hi. Do you have water?”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Again and again, the answer was no.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: When Johnson’s well ran dry in June, she and her husband, Howard, had no idea they were part of something bigger.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “I’d heard ‘California drought!’ on the news,” she said. “But I guess I was just oblivious to how bad it had gotten.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: At the local gas station where everyone stops for a cold soda, Johnson tuned in to the conversations.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “It was all, ‘So-and-so’s well ran dry,’ ” she said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: No public agency was keeping track. Until this week, California was the only Western state that didn’t regulate groundwater, including an estimated 600,000 private, domestic wells mostly in more rural regions such as the Central Valley. Groundwater levels here have plunged by 60 feet or more in some spots, and tens of thousands of wells are in danger.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: In July, Johnson decided to put together a list of people out of water in East Porterville. She figured that while she was at it, she should bring them water.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: The Porterville Recorder ran an article that gave her phone number and address and said she was collecting bottled water for drought victims. The next day there were pallets of plastic bottles under her tarp carport.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Johnson deputized Matt Rogers, a 19-year-old former neighbor, as her righthand man to make the deliveries. The calls from people needing water came as quickly as the donated bottles.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Families would call at midnight and say, ‘We’re completely out of water,’ and we’d go take them some,” Rogers said. “I’d tell them it was a lot of work for a 72-year-old woman, but Donna got mad and told me to stop telling people her age.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Still, the growing numbers and nonstop deliveries were taking a toll.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “I’d come home at night and cry,” Johnson said. “I thought ‘What are these people supposed to do?’ They could be dying for lack of water and just get brushed under the carpet.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: For months, scores of people had called the county, the next-door city of Porterville and the local water district to report dry wells. The answer was always the same: This agency isn’t responsible for wells on private property.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: But officials hadn’t realized how many people were desperate.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Last month, volunteers, firefighters and county workers delivered a three-week emergency supply of drinking water to 300 homes.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: In front of an East Porterville fire station, a storage tank was filled with water from a city hydrant that residents could use for bathing and flushing toilets. Signs warned in English and Spanish: “Do not use this water for drinking.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Nonprofit agencies began coordinating donations, grants and deliveries. Johnson was no longer a solo force. But she didn’t stop her daily water runs.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “They’re working their bejesus off at County Emergency Services,” Johnson said. “But you’ve got to understand a place like East Porterville. Not everyone is going to fill out paperwork, and some people are hard to find.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: On a day when the heat was pressing down like a waffle iron, Johnson and Rogers loaded up shrink-wrapped cases of bottled water.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Johnson pulled her lace-trimmed cowboy hat low. Her sunglasses had zebra stripes and rhinestones. She had elephants on her shirt and an elephant hanging from her rear-view mirror.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Elephants this week. Next week it might be angels or horses,” she said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: She used to be fickle about men too, until she married Howard, a physical therapist who prefers to stay in the background. They share a love of horses and 20 years ago bought a place with a corral in East Porterville, outside city limits.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Did you guys even know that they say if you live on the east side, you’re nothing?” Rogers asked her.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Nobody’s nothing,” Johnson answered.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: On a lawn as pale and scratchy as a hay bale, 9-year-old Destiny Carrillo attempted a cartwheel while her grandfather, Raul Carrillo, a house painter, watched.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Hi, do you have water?” Johnson asked, pulling into their driveway.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “A little,” he said. “But if two people take a shower, it’s done.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Eight people lived in the tidy home. Destiny’s mother, Veronica Carrillo, stepped out on a porch decorated with a small pot of geraniums.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Thank you for the water. We didn’t know where to go. We’re grateful,” she said, smoothing her daughter’s hair.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: On the next block, Manuel Dominguez, 84, didn’t answer his door right away.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Is he OK? He’s old. He’s always at home,” Johnson said, adding another “Yoohoo!”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Dominguez came around the corner from the backyard, where he had been working on the pump of his well.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “He still doesn’t want to believe that the ground is out of water,” said his girlfriend, Gloria Acosta, 65, coming up the driveway with a stack of bottled water.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: She used to bring 3 gallons of drinking water a day from her home in Porterville, but her landlord found out and put a stop to it. He was afraid it would run up his water bill. Now she has bought three cases of 24 bottles of water on sale for $7.98.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Plus $2.38 CRV,” she said. You keep track of stuff like that when you live on Social Security and baby-sitting money. Johnson added another 24-pack of water.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Dominguez’s daughter Angie Nunagray came through the door with a 5-gallon jug of water for washing dishes. She cleans her father’s house every day, being sure not to disturb his stacks of books, the loaded rifles propped in the corner or his collection of scissors covering one wall — because a man can never have too many scissors.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “I vacuum and dust, but you can’t get it really clean without water,” she said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Dominguez pulled out a splintered guitar and sang Mexican waltzes. Acosta rolled her eyes.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “She thinks I’m loco, but she loves me,” he said.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Down a dirt road, a schoolgirl carrying a flute case unchained a dog and they went for a walk, kicking up dust. A man washed his hands in a bucket of water. Places lucky enough to have a small pool of underground water had green lawns.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Marcella Ramirez, 70, had heard Johnson’s car coming and was waiting with an ancient dolly outside her trailer. Wire flowers sprouted from the top of a chain-link fence. An American flag windsock drifted from a sagging carport. A miniature wishing well — it was dry — sat on bare dirt.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Matt can carry it in,” Johnson told her.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Ramirez agreed, but emphasized that she was strong enough to wheel the water in herself if she had to. She said she was a lucky woman. The last year was tough — her brother died, she fought cancer and the well ran dry in June. But she feels healthy now, her hair grew back, and look at her nice SUV.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “I didn’t go to school or nothing and I got a car and a driver’s license,” she said. “I made a good deal and I can’t even read or write.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Johnson’s eyebrows lifted.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Marcella, do you have those forms from the county for water deliveries? Do you need help filling them out?”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: On the hood of Ramirez’s car they puzzled over which boxes to check.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Are you multiethnicity?” Johnson asked.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “Multi what?” Ramirez said. “I don’t know what that means.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Back on the road, Johnson talked about the last time she’d seen rain.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: “It was months ago. I was where I used to have lavender and so many flowers. I watched it dry up before it hit the ground.”

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: On the main road through town, a mother gave her 6-year-old daughter a bath — in her clothes, in a blue plastic drum of nonpotable water. The girl giggled and ducked her head underwater to get out the shampoo.

author: Diana Marcum
headline: Carrying a town's water
graf: Nearby, a tree swing swayed in a stir of hot air. Stairs led to the place where a trailer had once been, until a well ran dry and another family moved away to search for water.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The snow burst through the trees with no warning but a last-second whoosh of sound, a two-story wall of white and Chris Rudolph’s piercing cry: “Avalanche! Elyse!”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The very thing the 16 skiers and snowboarders had sought — fresh, soft snow — instantly became the enemy. Somewhere above, a pristine meadow cracked in the shape of a lightning bolt, slicing a slab nearly 200 feet across and 3 feet deep. Gravity did the rest.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Snow shattered and spilled down the slope. Within seconds, the avalanche was the size of more than a thousand cars barreling down the mountain and weighed millions of pounds. Moving about 7o miles per hour, it crashed through the sturdy old-growth trees, snapping their limbs and shredding bark from their trunks.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The avalanche, in Washington’s Cascades in February, slid past some trees and rocks, like ocean swells around a ship’s prow. Others it captured and added to its violent load.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Somewhere inside, it also carried people. How many, no one knew.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The slope of the terrain, shaped like a funnel, squeezed the growing swell of churning snow into a steep, twisting gorge. It moved in surges, like a roller coaster on a series of drops and high-banked turns. It accelerated as the slope steepened and the weight of the slide pushed from behind. It slithered through shallower pitches. The energy raised the temperature of the snow a couple of degrees, and the friction carved striations high in the icy sides of the canyon walls.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Elyse Saugstad, a professional skier, wore a backpack equipped with an air bag, a relatively new and expensive part of the arsenal that backcountry users increasingly carry to ease their minds and increase survival odds in case of an avalanche. About to be overtaken, she pulled a cord near her chest. She was knocked down before she knew if the canister of compressed air inflated winged pillows behind her head.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She had no control of her body as she tumbled downhill. She did not know up from down. It was not unlike being cartwheeled in a relentlessly crashing wave. But snow does not recede. It swallows its victims. It does not spit them out.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Snow filled her mouth. She caromed off things she never saw, tumbling through a cluttered canyon like a steel marble falling through pins in a pachinko machine.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: At first she thought she would be embarrassed that she had deployed her air bag, that the other expert skiers she was with, more than a dozen of them, would have a good laugh at her panicked overreaction. Seconds later, tumbling uncontrollably inside a ribbon of speeding snow, she was sure this was how she was going to die.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Moving, roiling snow turns into something closer to liquid, thick like lava. But when it stops, it instantly freezes solid. The laws of physics and chemistry transform a meadow of fine powder into a wreckage of icy chunks. Saugstad’s pinwheeling body would freeze into whatever position it was in the moment the snow stopped.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: After about a minute, the creek bed vomited the debris into a gently sloped meadow. Saugstad felt the snow slow and tried to keep her hands in front of her. She knew from avalanche safety courses that outstretched hands might puncture the ice surface and alert rescuers. She knew that if victims ended up buried under the snow, cupped hands in front of the face could provide a small pocket of air for the mouth and nose. Without it, the first breaths could create a suffocating ice mask.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The avalanche spread and stopped, locking everything it carried into an icy cocoon. It was now a jagged, virtually impenetrable pile of ice, longer than a football field and nearly as wide. As if newly plowed, it rose in rugged contrast to the surrounding fields of undisturbed snow, 20 feet tall in spots.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: ‘I Couldn’t Breathe’

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Saugstad was mummified. She was on her back, her head pointed downhill. Her goggles were off. Her nose ring had been ripped away. She felt the crushing weight of snow on her chest. She could not move her legs. One boot still had a ski attached to it. She could not lift her head because it was locked into the ice.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: But she could see the sky. Her face was covered only with loose snow. Her hands, too, stuck out of the snow, one still covered by a pink mitten.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Using her hands like windshield wipers, she tried to flick snow away from her mouth. When she clawed at her chest and neck, the crumbs maddeningly slid back onto her face. She grew claustrophobic.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Breathe easy, she told herself. Do not panic. Help will come. She stared at the low, gray clouds. She had not noticed the noise as she hurtled down the mountain. Now, she was suddenly struck by the silence.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The Cascades are among the craggiest of American mountain ranges, roughly cut, as if carved with a chain saw. In summer, the gray peaks are sprinkled with glaciers. In winter, they are smothered in some of North America’s deepest snowpack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The top of Cowboy Mountain, about 75 miles east of Seattle, rises to 5,853 feet — about half the height of the tallest Cascades, but higher than its nearest neighbors, enough to provide 360-degree views. It feels more like a long fin than a summit, a few feet wide in parts. Locals call it Cowboy Ridge.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: To one side, down steep chutes, is Stevens Pass ski area, which receives about 400,000 visitors each winter. To the other, outside the ski area’s boundary to what is considered the back of Cowboy Mountain, is an unmonitored play area of reliably deep snow, a “powder stash,” known as Tunnel Creek.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It is a term with broad meaning. The name is derived from the Cascade Tunnel, originally a 2.6-mile railroad tube completed in 1900 that connected the east and west sides of the Cascades, a boon for the growth of Seattle and Puget Sound. The mountain pass that it burrowed beneath was named for the project’s engineer, John Frank Stevens, who later helped build the Panama Canal.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: In late February 1910, ceaseless snowstorms over several days marooned two passenger trains just outside the tunnel’s west portal. Before the tracks could be cleared, the trains were buried by what still stands as the nation’s deadliest avalanche. It killed 96 people.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Bodies were extricated and wrapped in blankets from the Great Northern Railway, then hauled away on sleds. Some were not found until the snow melted many months later.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: To skiers and snowboarders today, Tunnel Creek is a serendipitous junction of place and powder. It features nearly 3,000 vertical feet — a rarely matched descent — of open meadows framed by thick stands of trees. Steep gullies drain each spring’s runoff to the valley floor and into a small, short gorge called Tunnel Creek.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The area has all of the alluring qualities of the backcountry — fresh snow, expert terrain and relative solitude — but few of the customary inconveniences. Reaching Tunnel Creek from Stevens Pass ski area requires a ride of just more than five minutes up SkyLine Express, a high-speed four-person chairlift, followed by a shorter ride up Seventh Heaven, a steep two-person lift. Slip through the open boundary gate, with its “continue at your own risk” warning signs, and hike 10 minutes to the top of Cowboy Mountain.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: When snow conditions are right, the preferred method of descent used by those experienced in Tunnel Creek, based on the shared wisdom passed over generations, is to hopscotch down the mountain through a series of long meadows. Weave down the first meadow, maybe punctuate the run with a jump off a rock outcropping near the bottom, then veer hard left, up and out of the narrowing gully and into the next open glade.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Another powder-filled drop ends with another hard left, into another meadow that leads to the valley floor.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Allure ofthe Backcountry

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Tunnel Creek is, in the vernacular of locals, a “hippie pow run” — breezy and unobstructed, the kind that makes skiers giggle in glee as they descend through a billowing cloud of their own soft powder and emerge at the bottom coated in white frosting.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Despite trends toward extreme skiing (now called freeskiing), with improbable descents over cliffs and down chutes that test the guile of even the fiercest daredevils, the ageless lure of fresh, smooth powder endures.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: But powder and people are key ingredients for avalanches. And the worry among avalanche forecasters, snow-science experts and search-and-rescue leaders is that the number of fatalities — roughly 200 around the world each year — will keep rising as the rush to the backcountry continues among skiers, snowboarders, climbers and snowmobilers.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The backcountry represents the fastest-growing segment of the ski industry. More than ever, people are looking for fresh descents accessible by helicopters, hiking or even the simple ride up a chairlift.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Before 1980, it was unusual to have more than 10 avalanche deaths in the United States each winter. There were 34 last season, including 20 skiers and snowboarders. Eight victims were skiing out of bounds, legally, with a lift ticket. And many of the dead were backcountry experts intimate with the terrain that killed them.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “It’s a cultural shift, where more skiers are going farther, faster, bigger,” said John Stifter, the editor of Powder magazine, who was a part of the group at Tunnel Creek in February. “Which is tending to push your pro skiers or other experienced, elite-level backcountry skiers that much farther, faster and bigger, to the point where there’s no margin for error.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: No one knows how many avalanches occur. Most naturally triggered slides are never seen. Those set off by humans are rarely reported unless they cause fatalities or property damage.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: But avalanches occur in Tunnel Creek regularly. Its slopes, mostly from 40 to 45 degrees, are optimal for avalanches — flat enough to hold deep reservoirs of snow, yet steep enough for the snow to slide long distances when prompted. The long elevation drop means snow can be fluffy at the top and slushy at the bottom. Temperatures, wind and precipitation change quickly, and something as welcome as a burst of sunshine can alter the crystallized bonds deep inside the snow. And because Tunnel Creek is outside the ski area, it is not patrolled or specifically assessed for danger.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: In March 2011, a University of Washington student was caught in an avalanche in Tunnel Creek. Having been carried into a stand of trees, he was unburied by friends within minutes and found dead. Three others were partially buried about an hour later when the ski patrol’s arrival set off a second avalanche.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Many of the most experienced locals view Tunnel Creek with a mix of awe and fear.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I’ve always been a naysayer of Tunnel Creek,” the snowboarder Tim Wesley said. “I’ve seen a big avalanche back there before. It has about 2,600 vertical feet. Not typical. The snow changes a lot in that distance. That’s the reason I always have a second thought about Tunnel Creek. In Washington, there’s a saying: If you don’t like the weather, wait five minutes. And it’s true. You’ll be on the chair and it’ll be freezing, and then all of a sudden there’s a warm breeze that smells like the ocean.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Even those who are not leery of Tunnel Creek on the best days heed the pass-it-on warning of the experienced: stay left.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: To head straight down to the bottom is to enter what experts call a terrain trap: a funnel of trouble and clumsy skiing, clogged with trees and rocks and confined by high walls. Few go that way intentionally.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Chris Rudolph, the effervescent 30-year-old marketing manager for Stevens Pass, knew the preferred route down. Tunnel Creek was his favorite at-work diversion. Earlier that weekend, he mentioned plans for a field trip to Tunnel Creek to a select group of high-powered guests and close friends.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The operations manager for Stevens Pass agreed to pick up the group in one of the ski area’s trucks at the end of its descent. From the bottom of Tunnel Creek, it is about a half-mile trek through deep snow to U.S. 2, then a four-mile ride back to Stevens Pass.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: At 11:32 a.m. on Sunday, Feb. 19, heading up the mountain, Rudolph sent a text message to the operations manager.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “A big posse,” Rudolph wrote.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Like many ideas that sound good at the time, skiing Tunnel Creek was an idea hatched in a bar.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It was Saturday, Feb. 18, the afternoon light fading to dusk. Outside the Foggy Goggle, a bar at the base of the ski area, the snow continued to fall, roughly an inch an hour. By morning, there would be 32 inches of fresh snow at Stevens Pass, 21 of them in a 24-hour period of Saturday and Saturday night.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: That was cause for celebration. It had been more than two weeks since the last decent snowfall. Finally, the tired layer of hard, crusty snow was gone, buried deep under powder.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph promoted Stevens Pass with restless zeal. In seven years there, he helped turn a relatively small, roadside ski area into a hip destination.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: He unabashedly courted ski journalists and filmmakers to take a look. They, in turn, gave Stevens Pass star turns in magazines and popular ski movies, raising the area’s cool quotient.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph was the oldest of three children raised in California’s Bay Area by outdoors-minded parents. The young family pulled a pop-up Coleman camper around the West and skied at the areas around Lake Tahoe. The grown siblings continued to vacation with their parents, climbing peaks like Mount Whitney in California and Mount Rainier in Washington.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph peppered his language with words like “rad” and “stoked.” But he was no simple-minded ski bum. He was an Eagle Scout with a marketing degree. When he applied at Stevens Pass years earlier, he sent a video of himself speaking, skiing and mountain biking. He included a bag of popcorn for the viewer. He got the job.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Children knew Rudolph because he kept his pockets full of Stevens Pass stickers. He starred in self-deprecating Webcasts promoting Stevens Pass. He wrote poetry on his blog and strummed a guitar. He drank Pabst Blue Ribbon, the unofficial beer of irony and the hipster generation.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Tunnel Creek was where he took special guests. And it is where he wanted to take the tangled assortment of high-caliber skiers and industry insiders who, as if carried by the latest storm, had blown into Stevens Pass that weekend.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Many of them happened into the Foggy Goggle on Saturday night.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Among them were professional skiers like Saugstad, 33, a former champion of the Freeride World Tour. There were reporters and editors from Powder magazine and ESPN. There were executives from ski equipment and apparel companies. There were Stevens Pass regulars, some with broad reputations in the niche world of skiing, glad to spend time with the assortment of guests.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “It was a very, very deep, heavy, powerful, strong group of pro skiers and ski industry people,” said Keith Carlsen, a photographer and former editor of Powder.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph was the connecting thread. Some visitors, like Saugstad, were at Stevens Pass for a promotional event aimed at expert female skiers, sponsored by Salomon, the ski equipment maker. Rudolph skied with the group all day Saturday. He organized and hosted a catered dinner for the women later that night in Leavenworth, a serious outdoors town dressed as a Bavarian village, 35 miles downhill to the east.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Powder had come to spotlight Stevens Pass for a feature article on night skiing. When the magazine’s editor, John Stifter, arrived by train to Leavenworth two days earlier, he found Rudolph’s car waiting for him. Inside were keys to the car, keys to a slope-side cabin and two Pabst Blue Ribbons in the cup holders.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: At the bar, Rudolph mentioned an idea to a few people: Tunnel Creek on Sunday. Invitations traveled in whispers and text messages, through a knot of friendships and slight acquaintances.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Meet at the fire pit, on the stone deck at Granite Peaks Lodge, at 11. Rudolph thought his Sunday morning staff meeting would end by then.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: As darkness enveloped Stevens Pass on Saturday night, stadium-style lights flooded the slopes in white light, and snowflakes fell in cotton-ball clumps.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph and those with the Salomon event left for dinner in Leavenworth. Stifter, 29, and Carlsen, 38, headed outside to work on their article for Powder.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I skied just off the trail, not out of bounds, but in the ski resort, to shoot some of these night shots I took,” Carlsen said. “And in tree wells I was, like, neck deep — easily nipple deep, wading around in snow, trying to get my angle. There was so much new snow.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: With the daytime crowds gone, the nighttime atmosphere was festive and the faces were familiar. Families played in the deepening snow. More serious skiers and snowboarders sought the freshest powder.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: There are no public accommodations at Stevens Pass, only a parking lot available to a few dozen campers and recreational vehicles. As the evening wound down, several of those with loose plans to ski Tunnel Creek the next morning huddled in the R.V. lot around a fire. Carlsen continued taking photographs. Stifter and others ducked inside one camper to watch homemade videos of others skiing Tunnel Creek over the past couple of decades.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “So it’s something they skied often,” Stifter said. “Not something like, ‘We’re going to go ski Tunnel!’ Not like a once-a-year deal.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The flames in the fire died to orange embers. The last beers were sipped empty, and people slipped into the night. The campers were blanketed with snow.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Beyond the lights glowing from the ski area, snow still fell over the ridge, too, in the vast darkness of steep meadows and narrow gullies just past the western edge of Stevens Pass.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Each snowflake added to the depth, and each snowflake added to the weight. It might take a million snowflakes for a skier to notice the difference. It might take just one for a mountain to move.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Dawn cracked with the intermittent sound of explosives near the top of Cowboy Mountain. Stevens Pass ski patrollers, called to duty whenever more than a few inches of snow fell, had arrived to check and control the ski area’s 200 inbounds avalanche zones.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: After getting the latest assessment from the area’s full-time avalanche forecaster, more than a dozen patrollers filled their backpacks with 2.2-pound emulsion charges, shaped like cartoon dynamite. Chairlifts rumbled to life, ferrying the crews up the dark mountain.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Three two-person teams assigned to Cowboy Ridge removed their skis and filed through the boundary gate. They took turns plowing a path through the fresh snow with their bodies. Their boots forged an icy stairway to the top of the skinny ridge.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Back on their skis, facing down into the ski area and with their backs to Tunnel Creek, they spread across the ridge to stamp and destroy wind-swept cornices, small balconies of crusty snow.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: They removed the charges from their packs. Like party poppers that spew confetti, charges have a pull-wire, an ignition that lights a 90-second fuse. The patrollers lobbed the lighted charges into the many steep chutes below them. With muffled booms, heavy waves of snow tumbled harmlessly into the recesses of the empty slopes below, clearing danger for the day’s thousands of inbounds customers.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The lines for the ski lifts began forming about 7, two hours before they were to open. When the gathering skiers and snowboarders heard the explosions echo down the mountain, they cheered. It signaled a powder day.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: In Leavenworth, Chris Rudolph awoke in his two-bedroom house on Ash Street, the one that he and his girlfriend, Anne Hessburg, painted a rich blue and accented with a garden out front.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Chris was so mad that he had a meeting,” Hessburg said. “It was a pow day, and you couldn’t tie him to his desk on pow days.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: But he thought the meeting would end by 11.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “He said: ‘It’s going to be so good, babe. I’m going to take some folks up to Tunnel Creek,’” Hessburg said. “Tunnel Creek, it was kind of like the holy grail for Chris. It was where he wanted to show off for friends.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Among those who joined the 45-minute parade from Leavenworth, through tight Tumwater Canyon, past the Lake Wenatchee turnoff and up to Stevens Pass, were Dan Abrams and Megan Michelson. They planned to marry in March.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Michelson, 30, was the freeskiing editor for ESPN.com. Abrams, 34, was a founder and the president of Flylow, maker of apparel marketed to backcountry users.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The couple lived in Seattle, but had come to Stevens Pass on Saturday for the Salomon promotional event. Michelson and the other women stayed at a Leavenworth hotel. Abrams slept in a spare bedroom at Rudolph’s house. He and Michelson drove to Stevens Pass together.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I said to Dan, ‘Do you think Tunnel will be safe today?’” Michelson said. “He said something along the lines of, ‘Yeah, those guys know the best route down.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: There were similar conversations elsewhere. In the slope-side cabin at Stevens Pass that Rudolph arranged — he cleaned it on Friday as he spoke to his mother on the phone — the journalists from Powder magazine, Stifter and Carlsen, contemplated the day’s plans.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We started asking questions,” Carlsen said. “‘Where are we going? Out of bounds? Didn’t it just snow nonstop for two days? How much snow?’ That’s when John pulled up the avalanche report, and he read it aloud.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Predicting Avalanches

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Mark Moore, director and lead meteorologist of the Northwest Weather and Avalanche Center, had set that day’s forecast on Saturday afternoon. A 64-year-old with graying hair pulled into a short ponytail, Moore had a feeling it could be a busy weekend.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The avalanche center, based in Seattle, is one of about 20 regional avalanche forecasting centers in the United States, most run by the Forest Service. During the winter, one of its three employees arrives in the middle of the night, analyzes weather maps and computer models, and examines data — snowfall, temperatures, wind, humidity and so on — from 47 remote weather stations scattered across the mountains, including five in the vicinity of Stevens Pass. They take calls from ski patrollers and highway crews.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The biggest storm of the season increased avalanche concerns. But it was not just the new snow that concerned Moore. It was what lay nearly three feet beneath — a thin layer of perfectly preserved frost called surface hoar. The frozen equivalent of dew, created on crisp, clear nights, it features fragile, featherlike crystals that grow skyward.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: On the surface, they glimmer like a million tiny diamonds. When frosted and protected by soft blankets of fluffy snow, they are weak stilts supporting all that falls on top. When they finally give way, falling like microscopic dominoes on a steep slope, they provide an icy flume for the snow above.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: A shot of rain or above-freezing temperatures, both common in Cascade winters, usually destroy the fragile crystals, melding them into the snowpack. But five days of dry, cold weather, from Feb. 3 to 7, created a perfect, sparkly layer of surface hoar. Sporadic light snow, never more than an inch or two a day, delicately shrouded it over the next 10 days.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: By the weekend, as snow fell heavily over the Cascades and powder-hungry hordes took to the slopes, the old layer was long out of sight, and mostly out of mind.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Not to Moore.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Snowpack is never static,” he said. “It’s changing, even once it’s buried.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Changes in temperatures, precipitation, humidity and wind can turn a benign snowpack into a deadly one, and vice versa. Sometimes weather is enough to start an avalanche. But “natural” avalanches rarely kill. The majority of avalanche fatalities are in human-triggered slides — usually of the victims’ own making.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Every skier, everyone who hits the slope, changes the structure of the snowpack,” Moore said. “Even though they don’t know it.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: In the rugged area of the Cascades that includes Stevens Pass, Moore deemed the avalanche danger “high” — the fourth degree out of five — for slopes above 5,000 feet in elevation, facing north to southeast.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: For everything else, the danger level was deemed “considerable,” defined as “dangerous avalanche conditions” with “human-triggered avalanches likely.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The top of Cowboy Mountain is nearly 6,000 feet. The Tunnel Creek terrain descends off its southwest side to roughly 3,000 feet. Officially, the danger was “considerable.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “In avalanche forecasting terms, ‘considerable’ is a really weird forecast,” Saugstad said. “Because it’s this gray area. It’s a hard one to predict. It can mean, well, you’re not going to see any activity. Or, if something goes, you’re going to be screwed. It’s hard to work with that one.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Moore’s forecast offered more specifics.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Although decreasing light showers and decreasing winds are expected Sunday, cold temperatures should slow stabilization of existing wind slabs and help maintain the threat of further human-triggered avalanche activity, especially on previously wind-loaded terrain showing no evidence of recent avalanche activity,” Moore wrote.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Spotty afternoon sunshine, he added, could raise the danger, especially on south-facing slopes.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The snow had stopped at Stevens Pass by the time the lifts opened Sunday morning. The runs were quickly doodled with curvy lines.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Stifter sat in the cabin and examined the forecast on his laptop.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I have this image burned in my head,” Stifter said. “I had a coffee cup in my right hand, I was reading e-mails, and I read the Northwest Avalanche Center report. And it said ‘considerable to high’ was the avalanche danger. And I read it out loud to Keith. And he listened, and I read it again — I read it twice — and looked at it. Huh. I’ve skied enough to know that when it snows a lot, which it did, up to two feet, there’s always going to be instability, with that much weight on an older snowpack.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Stifter left Carlsen behind and headed to the lifts. He found Jim Jack. If anyone could judge terrain and snow in the backcountry, it was Jim Jack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
