graf: The license plate on Jack’s Subaru Brat as a teenager read “IM JIM.” To family and his closest friends, he was Jimmy, sometimes J.J. To most everyone else, he was Jim Jack, blended into one name, accent on the first syllable: JIM-jack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Jack was the head judge and former president of the International Freeskiers Association, which oversaw a world tour of competitions. At 46, he was a sort of Peter Pan of the ski world, a charismatic, carefree boy who never grew up, beloved by like-minded skiers and snowboarders half his age.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: He spent winters traveling the world, spreading the gospel of freeskiing, professing the beauty of finding improbable ways down precarious slopes with grace, nerve and flair. He had been a competitor on the tour, distinguishable from great distances by the silkiness of his loose form, until he landed hard and took his own knee to his face, shattering the bones around his right eye. You could feel the screws when you touched his face.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: He was a party accelerator with a penchant for streaking. He did drama in high school and never declined the stage as an adult. On Halloween, his costumes played off his name: Jack on the Rocks, Jim Jack in the Box, Cracker Jack, Jack Frost.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Wearing lederhosen, Jack starred in a cheeky promotional video for Leavenworth. He was a sure-handed shortstop for the team from Uncle Uli’s, a bar and restaurant in the heart of town. A grilled chicken sandwich on the menu, smothered in spicy sauce, is named the Napkin’ Slappin’ Jim Jack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Jack shared a bungalow off the highway, near the Howard Johnson, with his longtime girlfriend, Tiffany Abraham. They danced late at night in the kitchen and built bonfires in the backyard. The covered front porch held a pile of ski gear and a futon couch, perfect for watching the world go by, beer in hand.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Jack drove a 1994 Chevy pickup with 216,000 miles on it, topped by a Wilderness camper that he added for $350. Widely recognized on the highways and in ski area parking lots around the West, it was held together largely by duct tape and bungee cords. The radio’s volume was stuck on high. If it is too loud, Jack told passengers, just roll down the window.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Jack and his camper rolled into the R.V. parking lot at Stevens Pass on Friday night. On weekends, when the snow was good, the lot filled with dozens of pickup campers and motor homes.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I woke up on Saturday in my R.V.,” said Tim Wangen, a 53-year-old former commercial diver who lived in a cabin at nearby Lake Wenatchee. “When I wake up, I look outside to see who is next to me. I saw that Jim Jack was next to me. I thought, cool, I got a great neighbor this week.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Jack and Wangen had skied a couple of runs Sunday morning by the time Stifter caught up to them. Wangen knew Tunnel Creek as well as anyone, having skied it since he was a boy. Jack traveled the world, scouting courses for extreme skiing. He knew how to avoid danger.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Stifter asked Jack about the avalanche report.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “He’s like: ‘Yeah, not to worry,’” Stifter said. “‘We’ll just do it slowly and safely and just stay in the trees.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The fire pit sits at the center of the bustle on busy days. At the corner of the patio, in front of the lodge, it is a crossroads for people coming and going. Some pull up chairs and relax, facing the bowl of ski runs strung before them. When the clouds lift, Cowboy Mountain dominates the view high to the right. It can feel close enough to reach and touch.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: By midmorning, the fire pit began attracting a growing but confused band of expert skiers. Some were local, some were visitors. Some knew others, some did not, but most knew either Chris Rudolph or Jim Jack. They traded nods and handshakes, unsure if others were headed to Tunnel Creek, too.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We didn’t know why everyone was there,” said Dan Abrams, there with Megan Michelson. “We wondered if everyone was meeting up for the same reason. But it’s like when you find out where the extra keg is at the party. You don’t go tell everybody.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Joel Hammond, the 37-year-old regional sales representative for Salomon, had teamed with Rudolph to organize the previous day’s women’s event. He did not intend to ski Sunday until he awoke in Leavenworth and could not resist the lure of the fresh snow. He drove to Stevens Pass and sent a text message to Rudolph, still in a staff meeting.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Chris was like: ‘Meet at the fire pit, where everybody meets. Then we’re going to rally up,’” Hammond said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Hammond told Jack that he had the latest model of skis in his truck, then left to retrieve a pair for him to try. Stifter bought coffee, a couple of Americanos, from the stand for himself and Jack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Tim Carlson and Ron Pankey, both 37 and childhood friends from Vermont, had spent the morning on the inbounds side of Cowboy Mountain, navigating near-vertical chutes and rock outcroppings. During a break, they spotted familiar faces near the fire pit.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Pankey was a former competitor on the Freeskiing World Tour, so he had known Jack since the mid-1990s. Like Jack, he eventually worked competitions around the world, including the X Games.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Carlson was a snowboarder, not a skier, and a regular at Stevens Pass. Earlier that week, he competed at Washington’s Crystal Mountain. Jack worked the event, and Carlson slept several nights in Jack’s camper.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: When Carlson and Pankey arrived at Stevens Pass that Sunday, they joined Tim Wesley, known to most as Tall Tim — a lanky 39-year-old snowboarder from Leavenworth. The three merged with those waiting for Rudolph.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Another arrival was Wenzel Peikert, 29, an off-duty Stevens Pass ski instructor from Seattle. Skiing over the weekend without his wife and infant daughter, he hung around the Foggy Goggle and the R.V. lot on Saturday night. He, too, sent a message to Rudolph on Sunday, confirming the plan.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I wrote, ‘Gear up?’” Peikert said. “And he wrote, ‘Yeah, for sure.’ So I went into the ski school and grabbed my pack, with my beacon, probe and shovel. I went to the fire pit and I met the whole group. You could tell they were a different level of skier by how they acted and how they dressed.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Among the strangers he saw was Rob Castillo, a 40-year-old father of two and former competitive skier. He had exchanged text messages with Jack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo and Jack lived together in Alta, Utah, for several years in the 1990s. They went helicopter skiing in Alaska and skied down mountains they had climbed in Washington.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Tunnel Creek at 11,” Jack wrote.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Perfect,” Castillo thought. “That’s just what I wanted to do.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: At the fire pit, Castillo considered the others.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “It was kind of like, ‘All right, this group is getting bigger,’” Castillo said. “I wouldn’t pop in with a bunch of no-names, necessarily, and trust any of them, but the ones I knew were definitely qualified to go. And they’re not going to bring people out who aren’t.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: More than anything, Castillo wanted to ski for the first time all season with his two best friends at Stevens Pass – Jack and Johnny Brenan.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: In the R.V. parking lot, a few hundred yards away, Johnny and Laurie Brenan convened in their motor home for an early lunch with their daughters, Josie, 10, and Nina, 7, part of the Stevens Pass ski teams.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brenan, 41, grew up comfortably in the Seattle suburbs, not far from Jack. He followed his passion for skiing to Breckenridge, Colo., working as a ski patroller in the winter and a carpenter in the summer. A burly man whose five o’clock shadow arrived by noon each day, he eventually opened a business that he named for home: Cascade Contracting.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I met Johnny at the Gold Pan in Breckenridge,” Laurie Brenan said. “It was Thursday night, 25-cent beer night. He was sitting on the pool table, and he had an open spot next to him. And I said, ‘I’m going to go sit next to that cute guy.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: They married in 1997 and moved to Leavenworth. Brenan worked as a cabinetmaker, then resurrected Cascade Contracting. On the strength of Brenan’s amicable personality and no-fear creativity, it blossomed with custom homes and expansive remodels.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The Brenans bought a deteriorated 100-year-old farmhouse on a hill in an apple orchard. Johnny Brenan lifted the structure on jacks, rebuilt the foundation and gutted the inside, intending to resell it as a bed-and-breakfast. The Brenans kept it for themselves to raise their family.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brenan zipped from one construction site to another in his truck. He coached soccer teams. He held Monday night poker games in the garage, which Nina always helped prepare. He built a chicken coop in the yard.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Johnny and Josie bought five chickens, and they called the business Eggs, Ink,” Laurie Brenan said. “They had signs and business cards. Then they bought 30 more chickens. It’s like, she’s 5 years old. But the more the merrier for Johnny, even with chickens.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Sunday began perfectly for Brenan. The family R.V. was parked in space No. 3, where the satellite dish picked up the best television reception. Brenan was at the front of the lift line at dawn.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: He offered to fetch coffee for those behind him, a trick he used to keep his place while he helped Laurie get their daughters fed and dressed. He returned to the line, excited for an increasingly rare chance to ski with old friends like Jack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I dropped the kids off for ski team about 8:45,” Laurie Brenan said. “I remember looking down and Johnny was yelling at Jim Jack, doing something with his hands, something crazy. They were like little boys in a candy store. They were so excited.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Back with his family for lunch, Brenan ate an egg sandwich and discussed a business deal on the phone. It was after 11, and he was afraid he would miss the Tunnel Creek run.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: But Rudolph sent a couple of people text messages at about 11:15. He apologized for running late, and said he would be out in about 10 minutes.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brenan had time. He made a pact with Josie.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Josie, be ready at 2,” Brenan said. “I’m going to come back and we’ll go on a powder mission. Be here, because I’ll be here.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brenan strapped on his avalanche beacon, also called a transceiver, a device that emits a silent signal for others to detect your location in case of burial. A friend in the R.V. noted that its batteries were dead. Brenan replaced them with fresh ones.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “What’s that, Papa?” Nina asked her father.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brenan paused to show her how it worked.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “He explained it,” Laurie Brenan said. “It was understood that avalanche beacons were really for body recovery. Not many people survive avalanches. He would say that.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brenan gathered his things and headed toward the fire pit to join his friends.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I said, ‘Are you sure it’s safe?’” Laurie Brenan said. “He looked me right in the eye and said: ‘Of course. I wouldn’t be going if it weren’t.’ I said O.K. because I knew that was true.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: At about 11:30, Rudolph burst through the doors of the lodge at Stevens Pass. He was surprised by the size of the group waiting for him, but he barely broke stride.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Get me out of here before another spreadsheet finds me,” he said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The group, jolted into action, scattered to gather gear.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We all rallied up, jumped on the lifts,” Castillo said. “I remember seeing some other buddies of mine later, like: ‘Oh, I wanted to go out so bad with you guys that day. It looked like such a fun crew.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Stevens Pass opened in the winter of 1937-38 with a rope tow on Big Chief Mountain. A lodge and five new tows were added in the 1940s, including a mile-long T-bar that pulled people up the side of Cowboy Mountain. The ski area took shape in the bowl below the crescent-shape ridge that connects the two mountains.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Seventh Heaven, a two-person lift up a steep wall of Cowboy Mountain, changed the complexion of Stevens Pass when it was built in 1960. It opened a high swath of expert terrain, now marked as double diamond — experts only — on posted signs and the ski map.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It also provided easy access to the top of the high ridgeline. Back then, few people dared to remove their skis and hike the few hundred extra feet to the summit. “When I was younger at Stevens, no one skied off Cowboy — maybe just a few locals,” said Wangen, who has skied the area for nearly five decades. “But the last 20 years, it’s gone ballistic.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Now there is a steady procession of expert skiers and snowboarders through the boundary gate next to the top of the lift. Most drop off the left side of the ridge, back into the resort, through the rocky and narrow chutes.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Those who drop away from the ski area, toward Tunnel Creek, are simply following a much wider trend into “sidecountry” — backcountry slopes easily entered by lifts and, sometimes, a short hike.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I don’t like the term ‘sidecountry,’” Moore, the avalanche forecaster, said. “It makes it sound like ‘backcountry light.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The rise of backcountry skiing can be credited to a collision of factors.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Ski areas that once vigilantly policed their boundaries, from Jackson Hole, Wyo., to Squaw Valley, Calif., have gradually opened their gates to the territory surrounding them. While that has led to wrangling over liability issues and raised debate over search-and-rescue responsibilities, most areas note that they are carved out of public land. They really cannot keep people from going there.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: But ski areas also see the potential to attract more ticket-buying customers, and more influential ones, by blurring the boundary lines. Many areas slyly promote not just the terrain inside their borders, but the wilder topography beyond, using the power of media and word of mouth — as Rudolph did for Stevens Pass.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Skiing adjacent to ski areas, however, can numb people to risk. Easy access, familiar terrain and a belief that help is just a short distance away may lead people to descend slopes they might avoid in deeper wilderness.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: While most backcountry users would not consider entering known avalanche territory without a beacon, one study last winter at Loveland Ski Area in Colorado found that fewer than 40 percent of people who passed through a boundary gate wore one.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Equipment advances have emboldened people. Intermediate powder skiers have been turned into expert ones thanks to fatter skis and the “rocker” shape of their tips — design advances borrowed from snowboarding. Popular ski bindings now temporarily detach at the heel, allowing skiers to glide up rises like a cross-country skier, then reconnect so they can descend like a professional downhiller.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Snowboards have borrowed from skis, too. Some models can be quickly split into two pieces, allowing users to stride up short hills in pursuit of bigger descents.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Similar advances in safety gear, such as easy-to-use digital beacons and air bags, have helped make the backcountry feel less dangerous. Beacons help rescuers find people buried under the snow, while air bags deploy a large balloon meant to help keep the skier closer to the surface of an avalanche. A leading American manufacturer of safety gear is named, appropriately, Backcountry Access.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Companies, including Salomon and Flylow, have marketed heavily to ride the backcountry trend. They are keenly aware that many buyers will never ski the backcountry but want to dress the part.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Those marketing shifts have coincided with a generation raised on the glorification of risk. From X Games to YouTube videos, helmet cameras to social media, the culture rewards vicarious thrills and video one-upmanship. This generation no longer automatically adheres to the axiom of waiting a day for safer conditions. The relative placidness of inbounds skiing is no match for the greater adventure of untamed terrain.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Among avalanche forecasters and the growing cottage industry of safety instructors, there is pride in noting that the number of fatalities has risen at a slower rate than the number of backcountry users. But they see themselves as part of a difficult race between the coming hordes and the tools to protect them.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “You could argue that skiers have never been this educated or safe,” Stifter, the Powder magazine editor, said. “There’s been a huge emergence and emphasis on avalanche classes. Then you also have this lifesaving technology. But if you go to Jackson or Utah, you’ll see people who are not educated, who are just going out there because they see it in the movies and they see it in magazines like Powder: there’s fresh tracks and, man, it looks like fun.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: At the top of Seventh Heaven, the members of the group took off their skis and snowboards. Directly to the right of the lift’s unloading ramp was a narrow trail that disappeared up through a clog of trees.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Read this,” one sign read in all capital letters. “Ski Area Boundary. Minimum of $1000.00 rescue fee! Do you have a partner, beacon, probe and shovel? Explosives may be used in this area at any time. Continue at your own risk.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: A smaller sign read: “Stop. Ski Area Boundary. No ski patrol or snow control beyond this point.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: To the right was a gray steel box. It was labeled, “Avalanche Transceiver Check Station.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “You walk by and it goes beep, beep,” Rob Castillo said. “So as we were going through, you heard it going all the way, right on everyone. Beep. Beep. Beep.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: While there are no laws dictating what equipment people carry into the backcountry, there is a code. Carry a beacon (for sending and receiving signals), a probe (for poking for victims in the snow) and a shovel (for digging them out).

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “When you go in the backcountry, you’re trusting your life in the hands of everybody else and they’re trusting their life in you,” Michelson said. “If I get buried and my ski partner doesn’t have a beacon, shovel or probe, it’s my life on the line.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: One member of the party did not elicit a beep: Erin Dessert, a 35-year-old snowboarder who was early for her afternoon shift as a Stevens Pass lift operator. Wesley invited her along. She thought everyone was riding off the front side of Cowboy Mountain, back into the ski area.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The group marched single file along the narrow ridge for a few minutes until it reached a wider area to convene. Tracks dropped back over a steep edge and into the ski area to the left.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: To the right was nothing but deep powder, hidden by thick trees, like a curtain to the big attraction.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: There were 16 people, although no one thought to count at the time. Their ages ranged from 29 to 53.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “This was a crew that seemed like it was assembled by some higher force,” Dessert said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It was about 11:45. The storm had passed. A low, pewter sky hid the surrounding peaks. Castillo glanced around at the others, wearing helmets and rainbow hues, a kaleidoscope of color amid the gray surroundings, like sprinkles on vanilla ice cream.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I was thinking, wow, what a bunch of heavies,” he said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: There was loose banter and a few casual introductions. Not everyone met everyone else. Someone pulled out marijuana to smoke, and passed it.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Wesley, the snowboarder known as Tall Tim, saw the size of the assembled group. More than a dozen, he thought.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “That never happens,” he said. “And it’s basically the legends of Stevens Pass standing up there.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: There was little doubt that those with Tunnel Creek experience knew the way. About half the group had been down dozens of times each, if not hundreds. The others would follow.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: There was no broad discussion of the route down. Pockets of the group talked about staying left, not being too greedy by going too far down the meadow before cutting across.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “That run, it’s not that it’s supersteep, or there are cliffs, or that it’s a really rowdy run,” Carlson, one of the Stevens Pass regulars, said. “It’s that if anything goes wrong, it’s a terrain trap. If somebody happens to set off even a slough slide and you’re below them in Tunnel, it all bottlenecks and really adds up superfast. That’s the reason that run is heavy. It’s notorious.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Unspoken anxiety spread among those unfamiliar with the descent. The mere size of the group spooked some. Backcountry users of all types — skiers, snowboarders, snowmobilers and climbers — worry about how much of a load a slope can absorb before it gives way. They worry about people above them causing an avalanche. When it comes to the backcountry, there is usually not safety in large numbers.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: That is not only because of the physical impact on the snow. It is because of the complicated dynamics that large groups create. Deadly avalanches are usually the product of bad decisions — human nature, not Mother Nature.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “If it was up to me, I would never have gone backcountry skiing with 12 people,” Michelson, the ESPN journalist, said. “That’s just way too many. But there were sort of the social dynamics of that — where I didn’t want to be the one to say, you know, ‘Hey, this is too big a group and we shouldn’t be doing this.’ I was invited by someone else, so I didn’t want to stand up and cause a fuss. And not to play the gender card, but there were 2 girls and 10 guys, and I didn’t want to be the whiny female figure, you know? So I just followed along.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Others suppressed reservations, too.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “The whole thing felt rushed to me, and it felt kind of like this covert operation,” Stifter said. “Which it kind of was, because you’re going out of bounds. It’s obviously acceptable, especially when you’re going out there with all these locals and the director of marketing. It’s not illegal or anything. It just had this rushed feeling from the time Chris walked out of the office, and he’s like, ‘All right, let’s go.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Carlsen, Stifter’s Powder colleague, was uneasy. He tried to convince himself that it was a good idea.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “There’s no way this entire group can make a decision that isn’t smart,” he said to himself. “Of course it’s fine, if we’re all going. It’s got to be fine.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: After a few minutes, the small talk faded. Worries went unexpressed.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “When you’re up on top of a peak like that, it’s usually hang out for a second, and then it’s momentum,” Castillo said. “You just kind of feel it. Everyone’s like: ‘O.K., we’re not here to hang out. Let’s start going.’ So I saw people starting to slide, get going, and I was like: ‘Hey, Johnny, partner up. Buddy system. Let’s go. Me and you.’ And at that point, it clicked. Everyone’s like, yeah, partners, partners, partners.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It is a tenet of avalanche safety, and the command snapped the group to attention.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Someone said, ‘Partner up — everyone should grab a partner,’” Carlsen said. “Immediately I thought, We’re in a somewhat serious situation. It wasn’t just grab a partner so you don’t get lost. It was grab a partner so you. ...

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “It just felt bigger all of a sudden.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph, the Stevens Pass marketing director, teamed with Saugstad, the professional skier.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I was really excited about that,” Saugstad said, “because he’s just such a cool guy and I thought, wow, cool, he wants to be my partner. A very trustworthy guy that’s an amazing skier.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Jack, on borrowed Salomon skis, paired with Joel Hammond, the Salomon representative. Carlson looked at Pankey, his childhood friend.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Dude, you’re coming with me,” he said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Wesley gave a little whistle to Carlson and Pankey and nodded downhill. He wanted to be first. The conditions were too good to waste time, and he did not want to be slowed by the huge pack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: With little warning, Wesley dropped straight through the large cluster of trees, using firs as a slalom course. Pankey and Carlson followed.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph, always up for competition, sped around the trees, not through them. He curved around a banked C-shape turn that dropped him a couple hundred feet into the broad meadow below.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: He arrived just in time to see Wesley, Pankey and Carlson burst from the trees into the open powder. Rudolph pointed his ski poles and playfully shouted invectives as their tracks crossed.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Wesley laughed, and his two friends followed him left and over a small rise.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph headed straight down the mountain.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I remember looking back at where he was going and being confused,” Wesley said. “Like, ‘Where is he going?’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: All the locals in the group presumed they knew what the others were thinking. They did not.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “When you know an avalanche is not very likely, that’s a great way to go,” Wesley said of Rudolph’s choice to ski straight down farther. “It’s three open glades of awesome powder.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Earlier that morning, Wesley and Carlson had skied the opposite side of Cowboy Mountain, in the ski area. It had been cleared of avalanches by the ski patrol at dawn, but the two still triggered several slough slides — small, shallow avalanches that washed at their feet and petered out before snagging victims.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “That’s why, when they said we’re doing Tunnel, I was like, ‘Ooh, dicey,’” Wesley said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Pankey and Carlson followed Wesley and looked back, too, wondering why Rudolph and the others were not following them toward relatively safer terrain. Within a minute, long enough to be well out of sight of the group they left behind, the three men found something that made them stop.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We were right on top of a knoll, a little rollover, where we were about to make some really fun turns, and we saw that the face had already slid,” Carlson said. “It was pretty large.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Alarmed, the three decided to go farther left. They crossed through trees and avoided big meadows and steep pitches. They soon found evidence of another avalanche, this one cutting through the forest.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I’d really never seen anything slide in the trees like that,” Carlson said. “And that was definitely like: ‘Holy cow, we shouldn’t be back here, Ron. Let’s go left. Let’s go hard left.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Wesley had disappeared in the pale light. He left nothing but a track through the deep snow that the others tried to follow.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I just went, and didn’t really stop,” Wesley said. “I went all the way down. But I’ve never taken a run where I looked uphill more times in fear.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph stopped on the left edge of the upper meadow, above a cluster of trees. Others filed behind him, spilling down the mountain in plumes of spraying snow.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Erin Dessert did not follow. She was confused. She was once a Tunnel Creek regular, until a nonfatal avalanche captured five friends in 2002 and scared her away.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Chris Rudolph’s, like, totally all about safety protocol and mountain awareness and wisdom,” she said. “That guy knows the conditions like an animal. He has instincts. It didn’t register, even for a second, that he might be bringing this group to Tunnel Creek. It wasn’t logical. I thought we were doing the front side.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She headed hard to the right, away from the others. The other snowboarders that she knew, Carlson and Wesley, were gone in the opposite direction. Some in the remaining group noticed Dessert heading away in the distance and dismissed her as an oblivious backcountry rookie. She dipped out of sight in a lonely panic.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I’ve been riding Stevens Pass since I was 3 years old,” Dessert said. “I can tell circumstances, and I just felt like something besides myself was in charge. They’re all so professional and intelligent and driven and powerful and riding with athletic prowess, yet everything in my mind was going off, wanting to tell them to stop.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph and the others, now a group of 12, were focused downhill. It was 11:52 a.m. Rudolph did not wait for the back of the pack to arrive before continuing to demonstrate the way.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “So Chris Rudolph went first, and then he pulled into the trees and we waited for a sec,” said Castillo, who was near the front of the group, wearing a helmet camera. “He goes out of sight and behind the trees. So I said, ‘O.K., Megan, go ahead, spoon those tracks, and you’ll see Chris on the left.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It was not Megan Michelson. It was Elyse Saugstad.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I thought it was Megan,” Castillo said. “I said, ‘Are you Megan?’ She said, ‘No, no, I’m Elyse.’ That’s when I met Elyse. It was right there. And she made these turns that were like: ‘Aah, I think I know who that is. I’ve seen her name. Those are pro turns.’ She ripped the hell out of it.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Saugstad traced through the knee-deep snow just to the right of Rudolph’s elongated S-shape tracks. She dipped through trees at a pinch in the meadow and disappeared out of sight. She crossed over Rudolph’s tracks and giggled. After about 30 seconds, she was back at Rudolph’s side, having cut left into a notch of the trees again.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We skied to an area that was probably about 500 feet down or so from where we started,” Saugstad said. “And where we skied to was an area of old-growth trees. You know, several-hundred-year-old trees. A very good indication that this is a safe place. Things don’t happen here.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo and Brenan teased each other about who would go next.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Finally, he’s like, ‘Go ahead, I got eyes on you,’” Castillo said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: From where Rudolph and Saugstad stopped, they could not see the subsequent skiers approach. Castillowent past and cut left. His camera recorded Rudolph and Saugstad whooping their approval as he stopped in a shower of powder, about 40 feet below them.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: But just before he stopped, Castillo was jolted by a weird sensation.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “A little pang, like, ooh, this is a pretty heavy day out here,” Castillo said. “Thing’s holding, but I remember having a feeling.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo stopped above two trees. He nestled close and pushed his right ski tight against them.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “A lot of people think you should be below trees, but I stand above them,” Castillo said. “I’m like, ‘I’d rather get pinned against this than taken through.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: His helmet camera showed that 14 seconds after Castillo stopped, Brenan appeared through the trees above Rudolph and Saugstad. Brenan had hugged the tree line on the left, avoiding the open meadow, then slalomed through the patch that the others used for protection. He stopped in a spray of snow a few feet from Rudolph and Saugstad.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “That was sick!” someone shouted.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo silently took note of the terrain.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I was downhill from them — skier’s right from them,” Castillo said. “But the trees that they were behind, I didn’t think it was a bad spot to stop. They were huge. Giant old-growths that three of us probably can’t put our hands around.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: But he knew the direction of the slope did not follow the meadow. It dipped harder left into the trees, down toward a gully. And there were still a lot of skiers above them.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Saugstad was next to Rudolph. Brenan was a few feet away.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We weren’t straight across from each other, in a perfect horizontal line on the slope,” Saugstad said. “We were peppered up and down, spread out.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo kept his attention up the hill. Less than 30 seconds after Brenan stopped, he saw Tim Wangencut through the trees above the earlier arrivals, gliding horizontally through the forest. Wangen had been taught how to navigate Tunnel Creek by his father. He knew that the farther down the mountain he went, the harder it would be to cut over the ridge and into the next big meadow. He crossed the shallow gully and rose up the other side.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I could see the others when I cut over,” Wangen said. “I thought: Oh yeah, that’s a bad place to be. That’s a bad place to be with that many people. But I didn’t say anything. I didn’t want to be the jerk.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Wangen had told Peikert to follow his tracks, and Peikert was close behind. Castillo watched where they went.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Want to cut over?” Castillo shouted to those above him.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The start of an avalanche is unlike any other force of nature.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: A hurricane is foretold by wind and lashing waves. A tornado often is spotted before it strikes. Lightning is usually presaged by black clouds and rumbling thunder.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Avalanches rarely provide such a warning. Unlike waves or wind, tremors or storms, they are usually triggered by their own victims, sometimes unaware of what has been unleashed.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “If you swim out in the ocean, the ocean’s always alive,” Saugstad said. “You can feel it. But the mountains feel like they’re asleep.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Back up the mountain, Jack never seemed worried. That was his nature. Here he was, a rare weekend off, skiing with some of his best friends from Leavenworth and people from Powder and ESPN and all over the industry, on an epic run on a perfect powder day.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Carlsen, the Powder photographer, had never been to Tunnel Creek. The first few easy turns gave way to a slope that fell steeply away, out of sight. He sidled up to Jack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I grabbed him, and I said, ‘What is the move here?’” Carlsen said. “It was basically like, ‘This is getting real, how do we handle it?’ He’s like: ‘Oh, no big deal. We go out here, swing out, make a few pow turns, and get back in the trees.’ I looked at him and said, ‘Have a great run.’ Gave him a fist, a knuckle-to-knuckle high-five thing. And that was it. I watched him swing out, way out, skier’s right, and then dive into his turn left.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Jack flowed through the thick powder with his typical ease. He skied the way other people walked down a sidewalk, a friend had said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Jack disappeared over the knoll, gliding through the trees in the middle of the meadow. Behind him, the five remaining skiers watched in silence.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “He looked like he was having a great time, the run of his life, in fact,” Michelson said. “And he actually made, I remember, a little ‘woo’ sound, as he dropped in on his first or second turn because the snow was really good. It was deep and light.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Then the snow changed without warning.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Across the meadow, above Jack, loose snow seemed to chase him down the hill and out of sight.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Not everyone saw it. A couple did. They caught it in their peripheral vision and were unsure what to make of it.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “That was sketchy,” Hammond said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The five others listened. Not a sound. They stared for clues through the flat light below a murky sky. Nothing.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Silent seconds ticked. Finally, Hammond spotted the first sign of evidence. It came from a tree, one among thousands, far down the hill, almost out of sight. Only the top of it was visible, and it was covered in snow.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I saw it moving,” Hammond said. “Like something had hit the tree, and it shook. And I could see the powder falling off the tree.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Afew hundred yards down the mountain, a ghostly white fog rushed through the forest.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I saw it,” Saugstad said. “I saw it coming. But it was weird because it was coming through the trees. It was like snow billowing through the trees. Because it was such a treed area, I think for the first second I saw it I didn’t believe it.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Wangen and Peikert had just traversed in front of its path. It did not miss them by much.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I don’t know if I’d even come to a stop when I heard it,” Peikert said. “It was almost like wind and pressure more than noise. It literally felt like a freight train went over my tails. It wasn’t a deep rumble. I could feel this rush of air.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It was a blur of white, its shattered pieces moving about 50 m.p.h., a powder cloud two stories tall.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Rudolph was the only one to scream.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Avalanche! Elyse!” Rudolph shouted.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Saugstad tried to stride right, hoping to escape. She barely moved before snow flowed through her legs, dragging her down like a riptide.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She pulled the cord on her air bag. She was overwhelmed so quickly by the rising snow that she did not know if it inflated.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I had no ability to control what was happening to me,” Saugstad said. “I was being tossed over and over and over. It was like being in a washing machine and all my body parts flailing every way. I didn’t know which way was up. I didn’t know which way was down. I couldn’t see anything.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She is likely to have tumbled just past Castillo. He groaned and turned his face away. He stuck his head between two trees, like a prisoner in a stockade.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: For 16 seconds, snow and ice pounded his back and washed over him. His shoulders were jammed against the trees. His face pushed into branches of pine needles. He could feel the heavy assault of snow lashing at his back.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Trees cracked around him. Some in the path were chopped in half — the stumps left in the soil, the rest carried away in the growing torrent.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The avalanche, a relatively small one, started with about 6,000 cubic meters of snow and collected 7,000 cubic meters more on the way down. It probably weighed about 11 million pounds.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The trees Castillo hugged in each arm swayed but held. He told himself that when he felt the flow slow, he would pop a hand in the air so that it might stick out of the snow and make him easier to rescue.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Just as I had the thought about what I’m going to do, wondering if it was going to bury me, that’s right when I could feel it,” Castillo said. “It was like a wave. Like when you’re in the ocean and the tide moves away from you. You’re getting thrashed and you feel it pull out and you’re like, O.K., I can stand up now.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo saw daylight again. His camera captured snow sliding past his legs for another 13 seconds. The forest sounded as if it were full of sickly frogs. It was the trees, scrubbed of their fresh snow, still swaying and creaking around him.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo turned to look back up the hill.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Where there were three people, there was nobody,” Castillo said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: He did not know who or what set off the avalanche. He did not know how far down the mountain it went. All he knew was that about a dozen people had been above him a minute earlier, and that the gully below him descended another 2,000 vertical feet to the valley floor.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: And he was alone.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Johnny! Johnny Brenan!” Castillo screamed into the stillness, his voice escalating with panic. The scope of the disaster was too much to comprehend. He wanted to find his partner.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “So I’m screaming his name,” Castillo said. “I’m screaming and screaming. Silence.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Streams of snow still flowed downhill as he scooted toward the heart of the slide path. It flowed into a wide gully, maybe 100 feet across, that narrowed as it descended. Castillo turned his beacon to “search” mode, meaning he would receive signals of those buried, but would not emit signals himself.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I don’t want to be in this gully because I don’t know what’s coming down next,” Castillo said. “I don’t want to be the next guy taken out. Now I don’t even have a beacon on because I’m on search. They’re not going to find me if anything happens to me.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Across the gully, unable to see anyone else, either, Peikert and Wangen had gone into search mode, too.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I was like, if there’s someone in that, the clock’s ticking,” Peikert said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Chances of survival drop precipitously every minute. According to a recent study, the survival rate for individuals completely buried in an avalanche falls to about 40 percent after 15 minutes of burial and to 25 percent after 30 minutes. About 75 percent of avalanche victims die from asphyxia or suffocation. The other 25 percent of fatalities result from trauma.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo spotted Peikert and Wangen across the gully. They, too, were nervous about hangfire, the unstable snow left along the edges of an avalanche’s path that can release at any moment.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The avalanche had turned the gully into an oversize bobsled run, with slick, high-banked walls.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “This gully’s hard-core!” Castillo yelled. “They’re in it!”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Wangen stayed mostly on the banks. Peikert and Castillo crossed the gully a couple of times, reluctantly and quickly.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “What’s your name again?” Castillo shouted at Peikert.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It was soon apparent that the victims, however many there were, suffered one of two fates: they were hung up on the banks of the gully, snagged by a tree or buried in snow, or they had been flushed to the bottom, thousands of feet below.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: If searchers spent too much time looking along the gully, they might squander a chance at rescuing someone at the bottom. If they rushed downhill, they might pass someone in need of saving.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We started to ski down, hoping to find him in a tree well or hanging on or something,” said Castillo, his focus on Brenan. “But I started to realize all the trees were bent over, and I started thinking, this is really fricking bad. And then I skied down to a point where I found Johnny’s ski, probably three or four feet up in a tree. Stuck.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo called 911. It was 12:02 p.m. The avalanche occurred seven minutes earlier.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Hi, I’m at Stevens Pass resort, on the backside of Tunnel Creek,” Castillo told the King County Sheriff’s Department dispatcher. He added, “We had a major avalanche, and we might have three or four people missing, at least.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The dispatcher asked him to slow down. Castillo, occasionally shouting at others nearby, tried to explain where the avalanche occurred. He was asked how many people there were.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “There’s at least 10,” Castillo said. “Between 10 and 12.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The dispatcher asked if anybody was hurt.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We haven’t found them,” Castillo said. “I found one ski. It rolled through pretty heavy, man. I had partners right next to me and they’re missing. I just found a ski about 1,000 yards down. Or 1,000 feet down.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The call lasted four minutes. Castillo, carrying his friend’s ski, turned down the mountain.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Near the top, the five skiers who planned to follow Jim Jack deciphered what happened through a series of increasingly blunt clues. Loose snow. A shaking tree.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Hammond was due to ski next. He took a couple of turns through the fine powder of the meadow and stopped. There was a sudden drop, nearly three feet deep. The fluffy snow was gone. A surface of bluish ice stretched down the hill, into the trees and out of sight.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Once I had gotten to the edge, I was like, oh my gosh, this thing ripped big,” Hammond said. “I could see the scope of it.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: He shouted for everyone to go into search mode. The other four skiers moved quickly to see.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We all skied up to it and were like, holy smokes,” Stifter said. “From there all I remember was pulling out my phone. And I called Jim Jack.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Others started dialing numbers, too. They called Chris Rudolph and Elyse Saugstad. There were no answers. Hammond dropped onto the slick slide path. Another clue lay on the ice, pointing downhill.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I hopped out there and made one or two turns, and I saw one of Jim’s skis,” Hammond said. “The only reason I recognized Jim’s skis was that it was a pair of skis that he borrowed from me.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The realization that Jack had been carried away was a gut punch.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “In one respect, you’re like, oh no, a ski — where’s Jim?” Abrams said. “On the other hand, you think, O.K., there’s his ski. Let’s find him.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Michelson called 911. According to sheriff’s department records, it was 12:03 p.m.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Her voice was steady and sure. She patiently tried to explain where they were — “The backside of the ski area in the backcountry,” she explained. “Tunnel Creek.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The dispatcher asked if people were buried.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I believe so, yes,” Michelson replied. “I don’t know how many. We have a large group.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Word was relayed to the ski area. Chris Brixey, manager of the Stevens Pass Ski Patrol, had 17 patrollers working on the mountain that day, two more in the aid room, and a dispatcher. Brixey is a regular at Johnny Brenan’s Monday night poker parties. He did not know that a group of friends, including Rudolph, his Stevens Pass co-worker, had gone to Tunnel Creek.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I happened to be walking through the aid room,” Brixey said. “Our dispatcher handed me a note that said 10 people are buried in Tunnel Creek. I called the 911 operator and got Megan’s information. I called Megan directly. She said there’s about 12 people and they were looking for eight people. I didn’t know Megan. My gut feeling was that this was a group of inexperienced people who are now dealing with tragedy.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brixey called the area’s most seasoned patroller and put him in charge of the four-member first-response unit, called the hasty team, to follow the group’s trail. He also enlisted other patrollers and a pair of avalanche rescue dogs.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Word of a large avalanche in Tunnel Creek soon echoed around Stevens Pass, from the patrol room to the R.V. lot, up the lifts and down the slopes. According to the Stevens Pass Ski Patrol log, the area closed public access to the boundary gate atop the Seventh Heaven lift at 12:19.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: By then, the group that had started off together less than 30 minutes earlier was strewn up and down nearly 3,000 vertical feet. No one knew how many were missing.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Keith Carlsen was nearest the top, searching for Jack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I thought someone has to make sure he’s not still up here,” Carlsen said. “It wasn’t likely, but his ski was there, and he got swept, and there’s no sign of him, so maybe he got pummeled into the snow, into a hole, somewhere, right away.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The others headed down, scanning the path and its edges with their beacons. Carlsen methodically checked the upper meadow.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I thought I was going to be the one to find him, and I would find him alone,” Carlsen said. “And the bed surface at the top was rock hard. And I’m thinking: I’m going to get a signal, and this guy’s going to be buried, and I’m going to have to somehow dig him out. I’m going to find Jim Jack.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Scared and alone, Carlsen’s voice broke the silence.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I’m saying, and I remember repeating this in my head: ‘Jim, am I about to find you? Jim, are you underneath me? Jim, where the hell are you? Is this possible? Is he really underneath here? Am I about to dig Jim out?’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Farther down, others followed the path into the gully. As it descends toward the valley floor, it carves deeper into the mountain. In some spots, canyon walls are 20 feet high. There were steep, icy drops that would become gushing waterfalls during the spring runoff.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “There are places it’s so tight that I would stop and my skis would straddle the middle,” Hammond said. “And I’d be elevated, like being on springs.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It was still clogged with rocks and trees that had not been fully scoured away. Where the ravine bent, the avalanche rode high on the outside wall, like a child on a water slide, sometimes breaking over the top of the bank and unearthing trees on the ridges.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “It was fear,” Abrams said. “Fear that you lost someone, and fear that you’re standing in an avalanche path. You’re thinking, Don’t get caught up on trees, listen for the beacons, where’s my fiancée?”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It became increasingly evident that whoever was caught in the avalanche would be found at the bottom.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I probably went down for one or two minutes and I got no signal,” Michelson said. “I shouted: ‘They’ve gone all the way down! The way this gully is, they’ve been flushed.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Tim Carlson and Ron Pankey, having split from the big group at the top, nervously negotiated the roundabout route to the bottom of Tunnel Creek. They could not catch up to Tim Wesley, but followed his snowboard track to the valley floor. It was 12:07 p.m.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: They glided past the foot of a mound of chunky debris. One of the ravines had spewed a sizable avalanche, but there was no way to know it had occurred in the past few minutes.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I looked up and I saw a ski pole sticking up,” Carlson said. “It looked like someone stuck it in there. It was sticking up right at the very end of the pile. Handle up.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: He shouted to Pankey.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I was like, ‘Dude, you need to turn your transceiver on,’” Carlson said. “‘There’s people in here.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Carlson clicked out of his snowboard bindings and climbed onto the pile. Pankey turned his beacon to search mode. It beeped immediately.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: His skis off, Pankey climbed onto the debris pile, too. He saw the ski pole and two gloves. He was sucker-punched by dread.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “You figure someone who is fighting is going to have his gloves on,” Pankey said. “If they’re limp, yeah, their gloves are going to come off.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Then he noticed the brand.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “That was my thought — Oh, God, those are Scott gloves. Jim Jack was wearing Scott gloves,” Pankey said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Their beacons shrieked.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I probably searched for maybe a minute before I was on top of a signal,” Carlson said. “Your signal goes ‘beepbeepbeepbeepbeepBEEPBEEPBEEPBEEPBEEP,’ and it gets a little fainter, like oh, over here. I got a strong signal, traversed over, got a weak signal, went back, got a strong signal, went back and I was basically on top of a body.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “And, uh, the first shovel I dug in, I hit Jim Jack’s arm.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The two men dug frantically.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I saw Jim Jack’s face,” Carlson said. “Eyes open, just staring at me. We could see he wasn’t breathing. Ron started giving him breaths and I was searching for his body, underneath his chest. I was like, ‘What the hell is going on?’ There was no body where you’d expect a body to be. And then I started digging around, and I could see he was folded up into this ball. His feet were above his head.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: His body had been pummeled.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “There was no blood, but he didn’t have his helmet on, he didn’t have his backpack on, his jacket was pulled over his head,” Carlson said. “He had some scrapes on his belly. And just pulling him out of the snow you could feel it and see it. Giving him a couple of breaths, it just came out so quick. And you push on his chest and it would just collapse. There was nothing there. And Jim Jack — we’re all strong dudes, and there was just nothing left.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I pulled his arm upright, and it was just really soft,” Carlson added. “It was like pulling a wet towel. Pulled the other arm and it was the same feeling. And I pulled his legs out, and there was nothing connected to anything. It was completely crushed.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: They turned off Jack’s beacon and tried to lay him peacefully in the snow. Pankey pushed his eyelids closed.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: He called 911 at 12:31 p.m. and told the dispatcher that he had “recovered a body.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She asked him for his name.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Jim Jack,” Pankey replied.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Jack’s phone chirped. It had survived the avalanche, and Pankey reached into Jack’s pocket and pulled it out. It was a text message from Jack’s girlfriend, Tiffany Abraham. Rumors of a big avalanche in Tunnel Creek had reached the base area of Stevens Pass.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Where are you?” it read. “You OK?”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Pankey looked over at the ski pole sticking straight out of the snow. It looked familiar. Pankey had noticed it on the hike up the ridge to Cowboy Mountain.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “That’s the guy’s in front of me,” Pankey said. “He was hiking in front of me and Jim Jack was behind me, and he had these old Smith, corrective angle, curved poles. So I’m like, ‘That’s Johnny’s pole.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: At the upper end of the meadow, more than 100 yards away and out of sight, Elyse Saugstad waited in the silence, unable to move.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She did not know how long she had been frozen there — head pointed downhill, hands sticking out of the snow, face poking through the ice just enough to breathe and see the breaking clouds trailing the weekend’s storm.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Her hip ached. Her mind wandered. She wondered who else was caught in the avalanche. She wondered who was left to rescue them.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She felt herself getting colder. Her pink mittens, like those of a child’s, had strings that attached them to her jacket. When she had come to a stop, one of the mittens was on her hand. The other was off, hanging from her wrist.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Saugstad could not claw the hard-packed snow with her mittens on. She took them off and picked at the ice until her fingers ached. She put her mittens on again until they warmed up.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She had not spoken since the avalanche stopped. It had not occurred to her to cry for help. Someone would come. She hoped.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Finally, for the first time, she shouted.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Help!” she screamed.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The face of Wenzel Peikert startled her.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Among those who skied down the gully, Peikert arrived first to the avalanche’s final resting place. The walls of the ravine slowly fell away and opened onto a wide, sloping meadow. It was covered by an enormous pile of chunky ice cubes, some fit for a cocktail glass, others the size of couches. The debris was filled with dirt, rocks and shredded tree parts.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It stretched about 150 yards down what remained of the slope. It was 10 or 20 feet tall, obstructing Peikert’s view to the bottom. Peikert’s beacon began its frantic chirping.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I started getting a signal,” Peikert said. “I marked it with one of my poles. That’s what they teach, to mark where you start picking up a signal and keep working to where it gets stronger. I took my skis off because it was so hard to ski on that stuff. And as I got close to that signal, I saw two pink gloves sticking out.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Saugstad was about 20 feet downhill.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Her feet were into the snow and her head was downhill, but I saw two pink gloves and her face,” Peikert said. “I don’t know if she uncovered her face or not, but it was just barely sticking out of the snow. And a little bit of orange from her backpack. I started digging her out, trying not to hurt her. I said, ‘Are you O.K.?’ And she said: ‘I think so. My leg’s kind of hurt.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Peikert pulled his shovel from his backpack and started to dig.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “For a pause, really quickly, I thought to myself: she’s alive, she’s breathing, her face is out of the snow,” Peikert said. “I thought, let’s go find others. But then I realized that more snow could come down. I found someone alive, and I needed to get her out of here.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Saugstad sensed his urgency.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “When he started unburying me, he flung his shovel and it went flying down the hill so far that he couldn’t stop and go get it,” she said. “And so then he had to start digging me out with his hands.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Peikert hurried, knowing that others were likely buried nearby.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “She was actually really hard to get out,” he said. “One of her skis had stayed on, so it had kind of locked her into the snow. Even a ski boot gets locked in. I dug to get her ski off. It probably took five minutes of digging to get her out.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Finally, Michelson and Abrams arrived from above. They found Peikert and Saugstad on their feet.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “It didn’t dawn on me that she had been buried,” Michelson said. “I was relieved she was alive.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Over several minutes, others trickled down from above.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Once we got to the bottom, when we got through the ravine and got to the mouth, I just remember saying, ‘Oh, my God,’” Stifter said. “Snow chunks the size of boulders. That’s when I realized the magnitude of everything. It looked like a war zone. It was chaos.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Michelson took charge as an impromptu site commander. No one was sure who was missing or how many victims there might be. Michelson used her beacon and pinpointed two spots for others to search, then continued sweeping the meadow to search for more.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “My numbers and directions were bouncing all over the place,” Peikert said. “But Megan comes up and hers was right on it. Mine is a little bit older, but I don’t know why it was bouncing around. I started probing, and I hit a spot where there obviously was something other than snow.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Peikert and Rob Castillo dug through the ice. It had been more than 30 minutes since the avalanche.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Finding Their Friends

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Johnny Brenan was discovered about three feet below the surface. He had been buried a few feet from Saugstad all along.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I found his back first,” Peikert said. “His head was really bent under. I tried to dig a hole through his armpit, to his head, thinking I might be able to get his face turned to give him C.P.R. There was blood. His chin was split open. His helmet was pushed back onto the back of his head and was filled with snow. One leg was off in a weird position, like he had a broken femur or hip or something. I finally got him out. He was cold. Blue.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Castillo, Brenan’s longtime friend and ski partner, worked side by side with Peikert, at last getting his legs out.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “The muscles were just beat,” Castillo said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: About 20 feet up the hill, Abrams, Wangen and Stifter zeroed in on a victim, too. It was the spot that Peikert had marked with his pole before he spotted Saugstad.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “We were still searching for the lowest signal,” Stifter said. “And the lowest signal I got on the transceiver was 2.4, and it took me, like, half a second to realize, oh, that’s six feet down because it’s in meters. So I’m like, all right, this is our lowest reading. And I think on our third probe we struck something. I told Dan and Tim, ‘All right, get the shovels out,’ and we started digging.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Digging was nothing like scooping snow from a driveway. It was more like shoveling the chunky piles that snowplows leave along the side of a cleared highway, full of large pieces seemingly glued together.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “They’re big mounds of snow and they’re like concrete,” Stifter said. “So you dig and dig, and then that person would rotate to the back and take a break and the guy who was second would start clearing snow out for the guy who is digging.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Quickly exhausted, they rotated frequently.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “It was just a bad dream,” Abrams said. “I was standing there holding my shovel that I never intended to use, except maybe to get my car out.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Finally, they reached a victim: Chris Rudolph.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “He was lying facedown, so it was hard to get to his face,” Stifter said. “And it was hard because we couldn’t move him because he was just encased in there. His feet were buried really deeply. Finally I was able to get to his face. His face was blue. And so finally I was like: ‘We’ve got to get his feet out! We’ve got to get his feet out!’ That took another good couple of minutes to get his feet free. Then we gently pulled him out by his backpack.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Stifter performed C.P.R. on Rudolph: 2 breaths, 30 compressions, to the point of exhaustion.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Saugstad called 911. It was 12:40 p.m.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I’m reporting an avalanche,” she said, breathlessly.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Frantic voices behind her shouted encouragement.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Come on! You can do it! Come on, buddy! Take a breath!”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The dispatcher said there were “units on scene.” Saugstad said they had not arrived and asked if they were coming by helicopter.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Uh, we do not have a helicopter yet in the area because of the avalanche risk,” the dispatcher said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Hammond was the last to arrive from above and took over trying to revive Rudolph.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I definitely believed that there was a chance,” Stifter said. “My hope dissipated certainly after Joel got there and I was sitting there. We knew. We looked at each other.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Twenty feet downhill, the huddle around Brenan slowly came to the same conclusion. Peikert had been performing C.P.R. for close to 30 minutes, with Castillo’s help.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I was hoping for a miracle then,” Castillo said. “But I really kind of understood that he was probably dead.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: An hour’s worth of adrenaline dissolved to disheartened shock. A few other skiers had happened upon the scene, but no rescue help had arrived.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Saugstad walked around dazed, wearing her deflated air bag “like dead angel wings,” Carlsen said. Castillo made his way to the bottom of the hill to learn that Jim Jack was dead, too. Erin Dessert, the snowboarder who had veered away from the group at the top, frightened by the direction everyone was headed, had cautiously made her way down and rediscovered the group. She cradled Rudolph’s head as others tried their last attempts to resuscitate him.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “It’s Chris Rudolph,” she said. “You know? He’s the knight in shining armor of Stevens Pass.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Laurie Brenan and Tiffany Abraham, Jack’s girlfriend, were both in the Bull’s Tooth Pub and Eatery, on the second level of the Granite Peaks Lodge.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I saw Tiffany sitting at the bar, and I sat a few seats away,” Brenan said. “She says, ‘I haven’t seen Jim yet.’ And I said, ‘Oh, he and Johnny did Tunnel Creek.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: The man next to Abraham, a neighbor from Leavenworth, overheard. There was an avalanche in Tunnel Creek, he said. Someone came into the restaurant a while ago and asked for volunteers to help search.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Abraham’s heart sank. Normally a font of buoyant optimism, she had a sudden pang of dread.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I downed my cocktail because I knew I’d need it,” Abraham said. “The bartender was telling a story, and I was trying to be polite and listen, but I knew I had to get out of there. I got my lunch boxed up and walked down to the ski patrol office. I took the elevator, and it was the slowest elevator in the world.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She could tell immediately that bad news was waiting. She spotted a friend who was on his way to the scene.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “He grabs my hand and I screamed at him,” Abraham said. “‘What the hell is going on?’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: They went into the ski patrol room, on the ground level on the backside of the lodge. Inside is a first-aid room with beds for injured skiers. Beyond is a ski patrol break room, a couch against one wall.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Anne Hessburg, Rudolph’s girlfriend, was sitting there, balled up in tears. She had skied all morning with a friend and taken an early lunch at the Iron Goat pizzeria. She walked up to the slope-side cabin that Rudolph had provided to the journalists from Powder magazine. Hessburg stored skis there. A friend received a call while she was there.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Someone told him there was an avalanche in Tunnel Creek,” Hessburg said. “He told me, and my stomach immediately dropped.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Hessburg rushed to the ski patrol room. She could tell by the way people were moving that it was something serious. She could hear the squawks on the walkie-talkies. Someone told her only that Rudolph was probably involved, as if to break the emotional fall.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brixey, the ski patrol manager, confirmed it. Rudolph was dead. That was about when Abraham walked into the patrol room with her friend, noticing a broken Hessburg on the couch.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Abraham’s friend turned to her, looked her in the eyes, and told her about Jack.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Baby girl, he’s gone,” he said.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I just lost my breath,” Abraham said. “I lost it. I couldn’t even be in my skin.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Laurie Brenan had no premonition. She watched Abraham rush out of the restaurant at the news of an avalanche and casually followed a few minutes behind.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I thought everything was fine,” she said. “But I’m going over to ski patrol. I felt like Johnny was probably using his skills, digging somebody out.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: She tried to stay out of the way as people hurried in and out of the patrol room.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “Then I heard someone say something about Jim Jack, and I thought, oh my God, how can that be?” Brenan said. “I knew they were all in the same group. I start calling to see if I can get someone to get my kids safe, back to the R.V., and get them a snack and put on a movie or something.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brenan spotted Brixey, the patrol manager and Monday night poker player, and waited for an opening to approach.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I said, ‘So, Chris, there’s been an avalanche in Tunnel Creek?’” Brenan said. “And he said yes. Anyone hurt? He said yes. Is anyone dead? He said yes. And I said, ‘Do I know these people?’ And he said yes. I said, ‘Where’s Johnny?’ And he said, ‘I haven’t heard.’”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: It was true. One 911 call from Tunnel Creek had reported the death of Jack. Another had reported the death of Rudolph. A third made mention of a third fatality, but the dispatcher never asked the name. Brixey did not learn about Brenan until his own patrol members reached the scene.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “I went outside, totally shaking,” Laurie Brenan said. “I kept dropping my water bottle, again and again, because I was shaking so much. Then Chris Brixey comes and gets me.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brixey’s outward calm belied the turmoil inside. As a paramedic, he had told a lot of strangers that a loved one had died. But never a close friend.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “That was, by far, the biggest challenge for me, walking Laurie from outside back to my office,” Brixey said. “Not knowing what I was going to say, but knowing what I had to say.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: They walked past the empty beds, past Hessburg on the couch, past Abraham. In the office, he turned to her.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “He said Johnny was one of the people buried,” Brenan said. “‘He didn’t make it.’ I didn’t want to believe it. I said, ‘Have you seen him?’ He said no. I said: ‘Then you don’t know. It’s possible he’s not there. You go back and get more information because that is wrong. Go. Go find him. You’re wrong.’ I remember thinking: He’s got two kids. This was for fun. Johnny doesn’t leave his responsibilities. Ever.”

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: Brixey left. Brenan melted into shock. Finally, a friend from Leavenworth came in. He had gone to Tunnel Creek about 20 minutes behind the large group and happened upon the scene.

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “He said, ‘I can tell you it was him,’” Laurie Brenan said. “‘I gave him C.P.R. We tried.’

author: John Branch
headline: Snow Fall
graf: “It really felt like I had died then,” Brenan said. “And that I was reborn into a nightmare.”
