graf: "When I was 16 in high school," she says, "I was date-raped. I had an abortion. I never told anyone, not my friends and not my mother. As the abortion was happening, I prayed to God and asked Him to take the baby back, and give him back to me when I could take care of him."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "So, I do wonder, sometimes . . .

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Balfour wipes a tear.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: " . . . It's there in the back of my mind, that what happened to me is punishment from God. I killed a child, and then I had one ripped away from me at the peak of my happiness."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: On the floor, Braiden is entranced by an Elmo doll.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "Sometimes," Balfour says, "I wish I had died in childbirth with him . . ."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: She's weeping now. For the moment, there's no soldier left.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: " . . . that way, Jarrett could have Braiden, and I could be with Bryce."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Miles Harrison is in a Leesburg Starbucks, seated next to the condiment station, pulling napkin after napkin to dry his eyes.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "I hurt my wife so much," he says, "and by the grace of whatever wonderful quality is within her, she has forgiven me. And that makes me feel even worse. Because I can't forgive me."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: In the months after he was acquitted in the death of his son, Harrison's public agony continued. His mug shot was back in the newspapers after the Russian Foreign Ministry officially protested his acquittal and threatened to halt the country's adoption program with Americans. It was something of an international incident.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: For months, Harrison declined to speak for this article, but in early February, he said he was ready.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "I pray for forgiveness from the Russian people," he said. "There are good people in this country who deserve children, and there are children in Russia who need parents. Please don't punish everyone for my mistake."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Harrison is a Roman Catholic. Weeks after Chase's death, he returned to his local church, where priest and parishioners left him to grieve in solitude. Afterward, the priest embraced him and whispered in his ear: "I will always be here for you."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: The church is St. Francis de Sales in Purcellville. The priest was Father Michael Kelly. On New Year's Eve, on a windswept road after a heavy rain, as Father Michael stopped to move a tree that had fallen across the road, he was struck by another falling tree and killed.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Harrison doesn't know what to make of this; nothing entirely holds together anymore, except, to his astonishment, his marriage.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: In their home, Carol and Miles Harrison have kept Chase's nursery exactly as it was, and the child's photos are all over. "Sometimes we'll look at a picture together," Harrison says, "and I will see Carol cry. She tries not to let me see, but I see, and I feel such guilt and hurt."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Harrison says he knows it is unlikely he and Carol will be allowed to adopt again.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: He leans forward, his voice breaking into a sobbing falsetto, as it did in the courtroom at his worse moment of shame.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "I have cheated her out of being a mother."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: In Starbucks, heads turn.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "She would be the best mother in the world."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: The first time, someone answers the phone but doesn't say anything. There is just the sound of a TV turned up way too loud, and after a little while, the phone clicks dead. A few days later, he answers, but the TV is not lowered. Call back later, he says. On the third day, he takes the call.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Are you doing okay?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "I don't even know. Tryin' to take it day by day."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Andrew Culpepper's voice is a flat monotone, like a man in a trance. His sentences are short and truncated. This is the sanitation department electrician in Portsmouth, the lucky one. He was the man who wasn't criminally charged when Miles Harrison was. He never had to legally defend himself.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Are you alone now?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "Yeah. "

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: She left you?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "Yeah. She's hurt and stuff. Dealing with it her way, I guess."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Are you thankful you weren't prosecuted?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: No answer.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Andrew?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "Not for myself, for my parents. Doesn't matter what they do to me. Nothing I don't do to myself every day."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Are you sure you're okay?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "I try to take my mind off it. When I start thinking about it, I get like . . ."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Like what?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Silence for the longest time.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "Like this."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: As part of her plan to simplify her life, Lyn Balfour has quit her job. It's going to get a little more complicated soon, because she's pregnant again: The insemination that she had on that day in October was successful. The baby is due in July.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Balfour's laywers petitioned the court to get the record of her prosecution expunged. Such a request is usually unopposed after an acquittal, in recognition that a legally innocent person has a right to start again with a legally clean slate. But in this case, Commonwealth's Attorney Dave Chapman challenged it and, unusually, argued the relatively small legal battle himself.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Outside the courthouse, Chapman ex-plained: "It's very rare to oppose expungement. But we are, because of the enormity of this case, because it is the sole public record of the death of a completely defenseless and helpless infant."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: After a half-day hearing, the judge ruled for the commonwealth, saying Balfour had failed to prove that she would suffer a "manifest injustice" if the court records remained unsealed.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Afterward, Balfour calmly answered questions from the news media, as always. She was unemotional, unapologetic, on message. She will consider an appeal. She will continue to speak out for greater public awareness of the dangers of leaving children alone in cars. She sounded, as always, just a little bit cold.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Jarrett Balfour finally made it home, after 18 months in Iraq, where his job was to analyze seized explosive devices made by insurgents and try to identify their technology and trace their origin. He extended his tour of duty twice, as the legal bills kept mounting. Jarrett is 30. He's tall, lanky and strikingly handsome, with sandy hair brushed straight back. He looks like a man leaning into a strong wind.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Initially after he got home, Jarrett says, things were awkward, with "hiccups" in communication. He would make an innocuous statement about something Braiden was doing, and Lyn would overreact, as if he were second-guessing her parenting skills. It's getting better, he says.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Braiden is 91/2 months old, exactly the age Bryce was when he died. Lyn has been having nightmares again.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Just before the tragedy, she had two dreams that seem to her, in retrospect, like foreboding. In one, she accidentally drowned Bryce; in the other, it was death by fire. Balfour believes these dreams were sent by God to help prepare her for what she was about to endure.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Recently she dreamed she lost control of Braiden's stroller, and it rolled out into traffic. No, she doesn't think it's the same thing, happening again.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "I couldn't take it again," Jarrett says quietly.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: So, there are tensions. They are working it out. Both of them say they are confident this marriage will last.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: After Jarrett leaves for work, Lyn talks about how much the presence of Braiden has helped them heal. She considers her family blessed because they've been able to have other children:

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: "Can you imagine losing your only child and not having a hope of having another? Can you imagine that despair?"

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: That's why, she says, she's made a decision. She's checked it out, and it would be legal. There would be no way for any authority to stop it because it would fall into the class of a private adoption. She'd need a sperm donor and an egg donor, because she wouldn't want to use her own egg. That would make it too personal.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: What is she saying, exactly?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Miles and Carol Harrison deserve another child, Balfour explains measuredly. They would be wonderful parents.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: This is the woman you either like or don't like, right away. She is brassy and strong-willed and, depending on your viewpoint, refreshingly open or abrasively forward. Above all, she is decisive.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Balfour says she's made up her mind. If Miles and Carol Harrison are denied another adoption, if they exhaust all their options and are still without a baby, she will offer to carry one for them, as a gift.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Ways to Help Prevent a Tragedy: Several products are available to remind a parent if a child remains in a car seat after the car is turned off. One of the more popular is Cars-N-Kids Car Seat Monitor, which turns on upon sensing a child's weight and sounds a lullaby when the car has stopped; it retails for about $40 and is available online.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: KidsAndCars.org, an advocacy group for child vehicle safety, urges some basic measures to prevent the tragedy of children being inadvertently left in vehicles:

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Always put something you'll need for work -- cellphone, handbag, employee badge, etc. -- on the floor of the back seat, near the child.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Keep a large teddy bear in the child's car seat when it's not occupied. When the child is placed in the seat, put the teddy bear up front in the passenger seat. It's a visual reminder that anytime the teddy bear is in the passenger seat, the child is in the back.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Fatal Distraction
graf: Make arrangements with your child's day-care provider or babysitter that you will always call them if your child will not be there on a particular day as scheduled. Ask them to always phone you if your child does not show up when expected.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The family had lived in the rundown rental house for almost three years when someone first saw a child's face in the window.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: A little girl, pale, with dark eyes, lifted a dirty blanket above the broken glass and peered out, one neighbor remembered.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Everyone knew a woman lived in the house with her boyfriend and two adult sons. But they had never seen a child there, had never noticed anyone playing in the overgrown yard.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The girl looked young, 5 or 6, and thin. Too thin. Her cheeks seemed sunken; her eyes were lost.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The child stared into the square of sunlight, then slipped away.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Months went by. The face never reappeared.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Just before noon on July 13, 2005, a Plant City police car pulled up outside that shattered window. Two officers went into the house — and one stumbled back out.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Clutching his stomach, the rookie retched in the weeds.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Plant City Detective Mark Holste had been on the force for 18 years when he and his young partner were sent to the house on Old Sydney Road to stand by during a child abuse investigation. Someone had finally called the police.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: They found a car parked outside. The driver's door was open and a woman was slumped over in her seat, sobbing. She was an investigator for the Florida Department of Children and Families.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Unbelievable," she told Holste. "The worst I've ever seen."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The police officers walked through the front door, into a cramped living room.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "I've been in rooms with bodies rotting there for a week and it never stunk that bad," Holste said later. "There's just no way to describe it. Urine and feces — dog, cat and human excrement — smeared on the walls, mashed into the carpet. Everything dank and rotting."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Tattered curtains, yellow with cigarette smoke, dangling from bent metal rods. Cardboard and old comforters stuffed into broken, grimy windows. Trash blanketing the stained couch, the sticky counters.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The floor, walls, even the ceiling seemed to sway beneath legions of scuttling roaches.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "It sounded like you were walking on eggshells. You couldn't take a step without crunching German cockroaches," the detective said. "They were in the lights, in the furniture. Even inside the freezer. The freezer!"

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: While Holste looked around, a stout woman in a faded housecoat demanded to know what was going on. Yes, she lived there. Yes, those were her two sons in the living room. Her daughter? Well, yes, she had a daughter . . .

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The detective strode past her, down a narrow hall. He turned the handle on a door, which opened into a space the size of a walk-in closet. He squinted in the dark.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: At his feet, something stirred.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She lay on a torn, moldy mattress on the floor. She was curled on her side, long legs tucked into her emaciated chest. Her ribs and collarbone jutted out; one skinny arm was slung over her face; her black hair was matted, crawling with lice. Insect bites, rashes and sores pocked her skin. Though she looked old enough to be in school, she was naked — except for a swollen diaper.First he saw the girl's eyes: dark and wide, unfocused, unblinking. She wasn't looking at him so much as through him.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "The pile of dirty diapers in that room must have been 4 feet high," the detective said. "The glass in the window had been broken, and that child was just lying there, surrounded by her own excrement and bugs."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: When he bent to lift her, she yelped like a lamb. "It felt like I was picking up a baby," Holste said. "I put her over my shoulder, and that diaper started leaking down my leg."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The girl didn't struggle. Holste asked, What's your name, honey? The girl didn't seem to hear.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: He searched for clothes to dress her, but found only balled-up laundry, flecked with feces. He looked for a toy, a doll, a stuffed animal. "But the only ones I found were covered in maggots and roaches."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Choking back rage, he approached the mother. How could you let this happen?

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "The mother's statement was: 'I'm doing the best I can,' " the detective said. "I told her, 'The best you can sucks!' "

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: He wanted to arrest the woman right then, but when he called his boss he was told to let DCF do its own investigation.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: So the detective carried the girl down the dim hall, past her brothers, past her mother in the doorway, who was shrieking, "Don't take my baby!" He buckled the child into the state investigator's car. The investigator agreed: They had to get the girl out of there.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Radio ahead to Tampa General," the detective remembers telling his partner. "If this child doesn't get to a hospital, she's not going to make it."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Her name, her mother had said, was Danielle. She was almost 7 years old.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She weighed 46 pounds. She was malnourished and anemic. In the pediatric intensive care unit they tried to feed the girl, but she couldn't chew or swallow solid food. So they put her on an IV and let her drink from a bottle.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Aides bathed her, scrubbed the sores on her face, trimmed her torn fingernails. They had to cut her tangled hair before they could comb out the lice.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Her caseworker determined that she had never been to school, never seen a doctor. She didn't know how to hold a doll, didn't understand peek-a-boo. "Due to the severe neglect," a doctor would write, "the child will be disabled for the rest of her life."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Hunched in an oversized crib, Danielle curled in on herself like a potato bug, then writhed angrily, kicking and thrashing. To calm herself, she batted at her toes and sucked her fists. "Like an infant," one doctor wrote.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She wouldn't make eye contact. She didn't react to heat or cold — or pain. The insertion of an IV needle elicited no reaction. She never cried. With a nurse holding her hands, she could stand and walk sideways on her toes, like a crab. She couldn't talk, didn't know how to nod yes or no. Once in a while she grunted.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She couldn't tell anyone what had happened, what was wrong, what hurt.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Dr. Kathleen Armstrong, director of pediatric psychology at the University of South Florida medical school, was the first psychologist to examine Danielle. She said medical tests, brain scans, and vision, hearing and genetics checks found nothing wrong with the child. She wasn't deaf, wasn't autistic, had no physical ailments such as cerebral palsy or muscular dystrophy.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The doctors and social workers had no way of knowing all that had happened to Danielle. But the scene at the house, along with Danielle's almost comatose condition, led them to believe she had never been cared for beyond basic sustenance. Hard as it was to imagine, they doubted she had ever been taken out in the sun, sung to sleep, even hugged or held. She was fragile and beautiful, but whatever makes a person human seemed somehow missing.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Armstrong called the girl's condition "environmental autism." Danielle had been deprived of interaction for so long, the doctor believed, that she had withdrawn into herself.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The most extraordinary thing about Danielle, Armstrong said, was her lack of engagement with people, with anything. "There was no light in her eye, no response or recognition. . . . We saw a little girl who didn't even respond to hugs or affection. Even a child with the most severe autism responds to those."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Danielle's was "the most outrageous case of neglect I've ever seen."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The authorities had discovered the rarest and most pitiable of creatures: a feral child.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The term is not a diagnosis. It comes from historic accounts — some fictional, some true — of children raised by animals and therefore not exposed to human nurturing. Wolf boys and bird girls, Tarzan, Mowgli from The Jungle Book.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: It's said that during the Holy Roman Empire, Frederick II gave a group of infants to some nuns. He told them to take care of the children but never to speak to them. He believed the babies would eventually reveal the true language of God. Instead, they died from the lack of interaction.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Then there was the Wild Boy of Aveyron, who wandered out of the woods near Paris in 1800, naked and grunting. He was about 12. A teacher took him in and named him Victor. He tried to socialize the child, teach him to talk. But after several years, he gave up on the teen and asked the housekeeper to care for him.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "In the first five years of life, 85 percent of the brain is developed," said Armstrong, the psychologist who examined Danielle. "Those early relationships, more than anything else, help wire the brain and provide children with the experience to trust, to develop language, to communicate. They need that system to relate to the world."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The importance of nurturing has been shown again and again. In the 1960s, psychologist Harry Harlow put groups of infant rhesus monkeys in a room with two artificial mothers. One, made of wire, dispensed food. The other, of terrycloth, extended cradled arms. Though they were starving, the baby monkeys all climbed into the warm cloth arms.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Primates need comfort even more than they need food," Armstrong said.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The most recent case of a feral child was in 1970, in California. A girl whom therapists came to call Genie had been strapped to a potty chair until she was 13. Like the Wild Boy, Genie was studied in hospitals and laboratories. She was in her 20s when doctors realized she'd never talk, never be able to take care of herself. She ended up in foster care, closed off from the world, utterly dependent.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Danielle's case — which unfolded out of the public spotlight, without a word in the media — raised disturbing questions for everyone trying to help her. How could this have happened? What kind of mother would sit by year after year while her daughter languished in her own filth, starving and crawling with bugs?

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: And why hadn't someone intervened? The neighbors, the authorities — where had they been?

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "It's mind-boggling that in the 21st century we can still have a child who's just left in a room like a gerbil," said Tracy Sheehan, Danielle's guardian in the legal system and now a circuit court judge. "No food. No one talking to her or reading her a story. She can't even use her hands. How could this child be so invisible?"

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: But the most pressing questions were about her future.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: When Danielle was discovered, she was younger by six years than the Wild Boy or Genie, giving hope that she might yet be teachable. Many of her caregivers had high hopes they could make her whole.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Danielle had probably missed the chance to learn speech, but maybe she could come to understand language, to communicate in other ways.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Still, doctors had only the most modest ambitions for her.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "My hope was that she would be able to sleep through the night, to be out of diapers and to feed herself," Armstrong said. If things went really well, she said, Danielle would end up "in a nice nursing home."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Danielle spent six weeks at Tampa General before she was well enough to leave. But where couldshe go? Not home; Judge Martha Cook, who oversaw her dependency hearing, ordered that Danielle be placed in foster care and that her mother not be allowed to call or visit her. The mother was being investigated on criminal child abuse charges.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "That child, she broke my heart," Cook said later. "We were so distraught over her condition, we agonized over what to do."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Eventually, Danielle was placed in a group home in Land O'Lakes. She had a bed with sheets and a pillow, clothes and food, and someone at least to change her diapers.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: In October 2005, a couple of weeks after she turned 7, Danielle started school for the first time. She was placed in a special ed class at Sanders Elementary.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Her behavior was different than any child I'd ever seen," said Kevin O'Keefe, Danielle's first teacher. "If you put food anywhere near her, she'd grab it" and mouth it like a baby, he said. "She had a lot of episodes of great agitation, yelling, flailing her arms, rolling into a fetal position. She'd curl up in a closet, just to be away from everyone. She didn't know how to climb a slide or swing on a swing. She didn't want to be touched."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: It took her a year just to become consolable, he said.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: By Thanksgiving 2006 — a year and a half after Danielle had gone into foster care — her caseworker was thinking about finding her a permanent home.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: A nursing home, group home or medical foster care facility could take care of Danielle. But she needed more.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "In my entire career with the child welfare system, I don't ever remember a child like Danielle," said Luanne Panacek, executive director of the Children's Board of Hillsborough County. "It makes you think about what does quality of life mean? What's the best we can hope for her? After all she's been through, is it just being safe?"

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: That fall, Panacek decided to include Danielle in the Heart Gallery — a set of portraits depicting children available for adoption. The Children's Board displays the pictures in malls and on the Internet in hopes that people will fall in love with the children and take them home.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: In Hillsborough alone, 600 kids are available for adoption. Who, Panacek wondered, would choose an 8-year-old who was still in diapers, who didn't know her own name and might not ever speak or let you hug her?

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The day Danielle was supposed to have her picture taken for the Heart Gallery, she showed up with red Kool-Aid dribbled down her new blouse. She hadn't yet mastered a sippy cup.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Garet White, Danielle's care manager, scrubbed the girl's shirt and washed her face. She brushed Danielle's bangs from her forehead and begged the photographer to please be patient.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: White stepped behind the photographer and waved at Danielle. She put her thumbs in her ears and wiggled her hands, stuck out her tongue and rolled her eyes. Danielle didn't even blink.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: White was about to give up when she heard a sound she'd never heard from Danielle. The child's eyes were still dull, apparently unseeing. But her mouth was open. She looked like she was trying to laugh.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Teenagers tore through the arcade, firing fake rifles. Sweaty boys hunched over air hockey tables. Girls squealed as they stomped on blinking squares.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Bernie and Diane Lierow remember standing silently inside GameWorks in Tampa, overwhelmed. They had driven three hours from their home in Fort Myers Beach, hoping to meet a child at this foster care event.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: But all these kids seemed too wild, too big and, well, too worldly.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Bernie, 48, remodels houses. Diane, 45, cleans homes. They have four grown sons from previous marriages and one together. Diane couldn't have any more children, and Bernie had always wanted a daughter. So last year, when William was 9, they decided to adopt.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Their new daughter would have to be younger than William, they told foster workers. But she would have to be potty-trained and able to feed herself. They didn't want a child who might hurt their son, or who was profoundly disabled and unable to take care of herself.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: On the Internet they had found a girl in Texas, another in Georgia. Each time they were told, "That one is dangerous. She can't be with other children."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: That's why they were at this Heart Gallery gathering, scanning the crowd.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Bernie's head ached from all the jangling games; Diane's stomach hurt, seeing all the abandoned kids; and William was tired of shooting aliens.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Diane stepped out of the chaos, into an alcove beneath the stairs. That was when she saw it. A little girl's face on a flier, pale with sunken cheeks and dark hair chopped too short. Her brown eyes seemed to be searching for something.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Diane called Bernie over. He saw the same thing she did. "She just looked like she needed us."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Bernie and Diane are humble, unpretentious people who would rather picnic on their deck than eat out. They go to work, go to church, visit with their neighbors, walk their dogs. They don't travel or pursue exotic interests; a vacation for them is hanging out at home with the family. Shy and soft-spoken, they're both slow to anger and, they say, seldom argue.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: They had everything they ever wanted, they said. Except for a daughter.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: But the more they asked about Danielle, the more they didn't want to know.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She was 8, but functioned as a 2-year-old. She had been left alone in a dank room, ignored for most of her life.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: No, she wasn't there at the video arcade; she was in a group home. She wore diapers, couldn't feed herself, couldn't talk. After more than a year in school, she still wouldn't make eye contact or play with other kids.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: No one knew, really, what was wrong with her, or what she might be capable of.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "She was everything we didn't want," Bernie said.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: But they couldn't forget those aching eyes.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: When they met Danielle at her school, she was drooling. Her tongue hung from her mouth. Her head, which seemed too big for her thin neck, lolled side to side.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She looked at them for an instant, then loped away across the special ed classroom. She rolled onto her back, rocked for a while, then batted at her toes.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Diane walked over and spoke to her softly. Danielle didn't seem to notice. But when Bernie bent down, Danielle turned toward him and her eyes seemed to focus.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: He held out his hand. She let him pull her to her feet. Danielle's teacher, Kevin O'Keefe, was amazed; he hadn't seen her warm up to anyone so quickly.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Bernie led Danielle to the playground, she pulling sideways and prancing on her tiptoes. She squinted in the sunlight but let him push her gently on the swing. When it was time for them to part, Bernie swore he saw Danielle wave.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: That night, he had a dream. Two giant hands slid through his bedroom ceiling, the fingers laced together. Danielle was swinging on those hands, her dark eyes wide, thin arms reaching for him.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Everyone told them not to do it, neighbors, co-workers, friends. Everyone said they didn't know what they were getting into.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: So what if Danielle is not everything we hoped for? Bernie and Diane answered. You can't pre-order your own kids. You take what God gives you.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: They brought her home on Easter weekend 2007. It was supposed to be a rebirth, of sorts — a baptism into their family.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "It was a disaster," Bernie said.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: They gave her a doll; she bit off its hands. They took her to the beach; she screamed and wouldn't put her feet in the sand. Back at her new home, she tore from room to room, her swim diaper spewing streams across the carpet.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She couldn't peel the wrapper from a chocolate egg, so she ate the shiny paper too. She couldn't sit still to watch TV or look at a book. She couldn't hold a crayon. When they tried to brush her teeth or comb her hair, she kicked and thrashed. She wouldn't lie in a bed, wouldn't go to sleep, just rolled on her back, side to side, for hours.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: All night she kept popping up, creeping sideways on her toes into the kitchen. She would pull out the frozen food drawer and stand on the bags of vegetables so she could see into the refrigerator.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "She wouldn't take anything," Bernie said. "I guess she wanted to make sure the food was still there."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: When Bernie tried to guide her back to bed, Danielle railed against him and bit her own hands.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: In time, Danielle's new family learned what worked and what didn't. Her foster family had been giving her anti-psychotic drugs to mitigate her temper tantrums and help her sleep. When Bernie and Diane weaned her off the medication, she stopped drooling and started holding up her head. She let Bernie brush her teeth.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Bernie and Diane already thought of Danielle as their daughter, but legally she wasn't. Danielle's birth mother did not want to give her up even though she had been charged with child abuse and faced 20 years in prison. So prosecutors offered a deal: If she waived her parental rights, they wouldn't send her to jail.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She took the plea. She was given two years of house arrest, plus probation. And 100 hours of community service.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: In October 2007, Bernie and Diane officially adopted Danielle. They call her Dani.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Okay, let's put your shoes on. Do you need to go potty again?" Diane asks.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: It's an overcast Monday morning in spring 2008 and Dani is late for school. Again. She keeps flitting around the living room, ducking behind chairs and sofas, pulling at her shorts.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: After a year with her new family, Dani scarcely resembles the girl in the Heart Gallery photo. She has grown a foot and her weight has doubled.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: All those years she was kept inside, her hair was as dark as the dirty room she lived in. But since she started going to the beach and swimming in their backyard pool, Dani's shoulder-length hair has turned a golden blond. She still shrieks when anyone tries to brush it.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The changes in her behavior are subtle, but Bernie and Diane see progress. They give an example: When Dani feels overwhelmed she retreats to her room, rolls onto her back, pulls one sock toward the end of her toes and bats it. For hours. Bernie and Diane tell her to stop.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Now, when Dani hears them coming, she peels off her sock and throws it into the closet to hide it.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She's learning right from wrong, they say. And she seems upset when she knows she has disappointed them. As if she cares how they feel.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Bernie and Diane were told to put Dani in school with profoundly disabled children, but they insisted on different classes because they believe she can do more. They take her to occupational and physical therapy, to church and the mall and the grocery store. They have her in speech classes and horseback riding lessons.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Once, when Dani was trying to climb onto her horse, the mother of a boy in the therapeutic class turned to Diane.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "You're so lucky," Diane remembers the woman saying.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Lucky?" Diane asked.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The woman nodded. "I know my son will never stand on his own, will never be able to climb onto a horse. You have no idea what your daughter might be able to do."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Diane finds hope in that idea. She counts small steps to convince herself things are slowly improving. So what if Dani steals food off other people's trays at McDonald's? At least she can feed herself chicken nuggets now. So what if she already has been to the bathroom four times this morning? She's finally out of diapers.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: It took months, but they taught her to hold a stuffed teddy on the toilet so she wouldn't be scared to be alone in the bathroom. They bribed her with M&M's.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Dani, sit down and try to use the potty," Diane coaxes. "Pull down your shorts. That's a good girl."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Every weekday, for half an hour, speech therapist Leslie Goldenberg tries to teach Dani to talk. She sits her in front of a mirror at a Bonita Springs elementary school and shows her how to purse her lips to make puffing sounds.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Puh-puh-puh," says the teacher. "Here, feel my mouth." She brings Dani's fingers to her lips, so she can feel the air.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Dani nods. She knows how to nod now. Goldenberg puffs again.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Leaning close to the mirror, Dani purses her lips, opens and closes them. No sound comes out. She can imitate the movement, but doesn't know she has to blow out air to make the noise.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She bends closer, scowls at her reflection. Her lips open and close again, then she leaps up and runs across the room. She grabs a Koosh ball and bounces it rapidly.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She's lost inside herself. Again.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: But in many ways, Dani already has surpassed the teacher's expectations, and not just in terms of speech. She seems to be learning to listen, and she understands simple commands. She pulls at her pants to show she needs to go to the bathroom, taps a juice box when she wants more. She can sit at a table for five-minute stretches, and she's starting to scoop applesauce with a spoon. She's down to just a few temper tantrums a month. She is learning to push buttons on a speaking board, to use symbols to show when she wants a book or when she's angry. She's learning it's okay to be angry: You can deal with those feelings without biting your own hands.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "I'd like her to at least be able to master a sound board, so she can communicate her choices even if she never finds her voice," Goldenberg says. "I think she understands most of what we say. It's just that she doesn't always know how to — or want to — react."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Dani's teacher and family have heard her say only a few words, and all of them seemed accidental. Once she blurted "baaa," startling Goldenberg to tears. It was the first letter sound she had ever made.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She seems to talk most often when William is tickling her, as if something from her subconscious seeps out when she's too distracted to shut it off. Her brother has heard her say, "Stop!" and "No!" He thought he even heard her say his name.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Having a brother just one year older is invaluable for Dani's development, her teacher says. She has someone to practice language with, someone who will listen. "Even deaf infants will coo," Goldenberg said. "But if no one responds, they stop."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: William says Dani frightened him at first. "She did weird things." But he always wanted someone to play with. He doesn't care that she can't ride bikes with him or play Monopoly. "I drive her around in my Jeep and she honks the horn," he says. "She's learning to match up cards and stuff."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: He couldn't believe she had never walked a dog or licked an ice cream cone. He taught her how to play peek-a-boo, helped her squish Play-Doh through her fingers. He showed her it was safe to walk on sand and fun to blow bubbles and okay to cry; when you hurt, someone comes. He taught her how to open a present. How to pick up tater tots and dunk them into a mountain of ketchup.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: William was used to living like an only child, but since Dani has moved in, she gets most of their parents' attention. "She needs them more than me," he says simply.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: He gave her his old toys, his "kid movies," his board books. He even moved out of his bedroom so she could sleep upstairs. His parents painted his old walls pink and filled the closet with cotton-candy dresses.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: They moved a daybed into the laundry room for William, squeezed it between the washing machine and Dani's rocking horse. Each night, the 10-year-old boy cuddles up with a walkie-talkie because "it's scary down here, all alone."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: After a few minutes, while his parents are trying to get Dani to bed, William always sneaks into the living room and folds himself into the love seat.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: He trades his walkie-talkie for a small stuffed Dalmatian and calls down the hall, "Good night, Mom and Dad. Good night, Dani."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Some day, he's sure, she will answer.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Even now, Dani won't sleep in a bed.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Bernie bought her a new trundle so she can slide out the bottom bunk and be at floor level. Diane found pink Hello Kitty sheets and a stuffed glow worm so Dani will never again be alone in the dark.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "You got your wormie? You ready to go to sleep?" Bernie asks, bending to pick up his daughter. She's turning slow circles beneath the window, holding her worm by his tail. Bernie lifts her to the glass and shows her the sun, slipping behind the neighbor's house.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: He hopes, one day, she might be able to call him "Daddy," to get married or at least live on her own. But if that doesn't happen, he says, "That's okay too. For me, it's all about getting the kisses and the hugs."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: For now, Bernie and Diane are content to give Dani what she never had before: comfort and stability, attention and affection. A trundle, a glow worm.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Now Bernie tips Dani into bed, smooths her golden hair across the pillow. "Night-night," he says, kissing her forehead.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Good night, honey," Diane calls from the doorway.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Bernie lowers the shade. As he walks past Dani, she reaches out and grabs his ankles.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She's out there somewhere, looming over Danielle's story like a ghost. To Bernie and Diane, Danielle's birth mother is a cipher, almost never spoken of. The less said, the better. As far as they are concerned Danielle was born the day they found her. And yet this unimaginable woman is out there somewhere, most likely still on probation, permanently unburdened of her daughter, and thinking — what? What can she possibly say? Nothing. Not a thing. But none of this makes any sense without her.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Michelle Crockett lives in a mobile home in Plant City with her two 20-something sons, three cats and a closet full of kittens. The trailer is just down the road from the little house where she lived with Danielle.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "My daughter?" she asks. "You want to talk about my daughter?" Her voice catches. Tears pool in her glasses. On a steamy afternoon a few weeks ago, Michelle opens the door wearing a long T-shirt. When she sees two strangers, she ducks inside and pulls on a housecoat. She's tall and stout, with broad shoulders and the sallow skin of a smoker. She looks tired, older than her 51 years.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The inside of the trailer is modest but clean: dishes drying on the counter, silk flowers on the table. Sitting in her kitchen, chain-smoking 305s, she starts at the end: the day the detective took Danielle.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Part of me died that day," she says.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Michelle says she was a student at the University of Tampa when she met a man named Bernie at a bar. It was 1976. He was a Vietnam vet, 10 years her senior. They got married and moved to Las Vegas, where he drove a taxi.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Right away they had two sons, Bernard and Grant. The younger boy wasn't potty-trained until he was 4, didn't talk until he was 5. "He was sort of slow," Michelle says. In school, they put him in special ed.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Her sons were teenagers when her husband got sick. Agent Orange, the doctors said. When he died in August 1997, Michelle filed for bankruptcy.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Six months later, she met a man in a casino. He was in Vegas on business. She went back to his hotel room with him.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "His name was Ron," she says. She shakes her head. "No, it was Bob. I think it was Bob."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: For hours Michelle Crockett spins out her story, tapping ashes into a plastic ashtray. Everything she says sounds like a plea, but for what? Understanding? Sympathy? She doesn't apologize. Far from it. She feels wronged.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Danielle, she says, was born in a hospital in Las Vegas, a healthy baby who weighed 7 pounds, 6 ounces. Her Apgar score measuring her health was a 9, nearly perfect.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "She screamed a lot," Michelle says. "I just thought she was spoiled."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: When Danielle was 18 months old, Michelle's mobile home burned down, so she loaded her two sons and baby daughter onto a Greyhound bus and headed to Florida, to bunk with a cousin.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: They lost their suitcases along the way, she says. The cousin couldn't take the kids. After a week, Michelle moved into a Brandon apartment with no furniture, no clothes, no dishes. She got hired as a cashier at Publix. But it was okay: "The boys were with her," she says. She says she has the paperwork to prove it.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She goes to the boys' bathroom, returns with a box full of documents and hands it over.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The earliest documents are from Feb. 11, 2002. That was when someone called the child abuse hotline on her. The caller reported that a child, about 3, was "left unattended for days with a retarded older brother, never seen wearing anything but a diaper."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: This is Michelle's proof that her sons were watching Danielle.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The caller continued:

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "The home is filthy. There are clothes everywhere. There are feces on the child's seat and the counter is covered with trash."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: It's not clear what investigators found at the house, but they left Danielle with her mother that day.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Nine months later, another call to authorities. A person who knew Michelle from the Moose Lodge said she was always there playing bingo with her new boyfriend, leaving her children alone overnight.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Not fit to be a mother," the caller said.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The hotline operator took these notes: The 4-year-old girl "is still wearing a diaper and drinking from a baby bottle. On-going situation, worse since last August. Mom leaves Grant and Danielle at home for several days in a row while she goes to work and spends the night with a new paramour. Danielle . . . is never seen outside the home."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Again the child abuse investigators went out. They offered Michelle free day care for Danielle. She refused. And they left Danielle there.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Why? Didn't they worry about two separate calls to the hotline, months apart, citing the same concerns?

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "It's not automatic that because the home is dirty we'd remove the child," said Nick Cox, regional director of the Florida Department of Children and Families. "And what they found in 2002 was not like the scene they walked into in 2005."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The aim, he said, is to keep the child with the parent, and try to help the parent get whatever services he or she might need. But Michelle refused help. And investigators might have felt they didn't have enough evidence to take Danielle, Cox said.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "I'm concerned, though, that no effort was made to interview the child," he said.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "If you have a 4-year-old who is unable to speak, that would raise a red flag to me. "I'm not going to tell you this was okay. I don't know how it could have happened."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Michelle insists Danielle was fine.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "I tried to potty-train her, she wouldn't train. I tried to get her into schools, no one would take her," she says in the kitchen of her trailer. The only thing she ever noticed was wrong, she says, "was that she didn't speak much. She talked in a soft tone. She'd say, ‘Let's go eat.' But no one could hear her except me."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She says she took Danielle to the library and the park. "I took her out for pizza. Once." But she can't remember which library, which park or where they went for pizza.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "She liked this song I'd sing her," Michelle says. "Miss Polly had a dolly, she was sick, sick, sick . . ."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Michelle's older son, Bernard, told a judge that he once asked his mom why she never took Danielle to the doctor. Something's wrong with her, he remembered telling her. He said she answered, "If they see her, they might take her away."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: A few months after the second abuse call, Michelle and her kids moved in with her boyfriend in the rundown rental house in Plant City. The day the cops came, Michelle says, she didn't know what was wrong.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "My house was a mess," she says. "I'd been sick and it got away from me. But I never knew a dirty house was against the law."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The cop walked past her, carrying Danielle.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "He said she was starving. I told him me and my sisters were all skinny till we were 13.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "I begged him, ‘Please, don't take my baby! Please!' "

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She says she put socks on her daughter before he took her to the car, but couldn't find any shoes.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: A judge ordered Michelle to have a psychological evaluation. That's among the documents, too.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Danielle's IQ, the report says, is below 50, indicating "severe mental retardation." Michelle's is 77, "borderline range of intellectual ability."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "She tended to blame her difficulties on circumstances while rationalizing her own actions," wrote psychologist Richard Enrico Spana. She "is more concerned with herself than most other adults, and this could lead her to neglect paying adequate attention to people around her."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She wanted to fight for her daughter, she says, but didn't want to go to jail and didn't have enough money for a lawyer.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "I tried to get people to help me," Michelle says. "They say I made her autistic. But how do you make a kid autistic? They say I didn't put clothes on her — but she just tore them off."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: After Danielle was taken away, Michelle says, she tripped over a box at Wal-Mart and got in a car accident and couldn't work anymore. In February, she went back to court and a judge waived her community service hours.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She's on probation until 2012.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She spends her days with her sons, doing crossword puzzles and watching movies. Sometimes they talk about Danielle.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: When Danielle was in the hospital, Michelle says, she and her sons sneaked in to see her. Michelle took a picture from the file: Danielle, drowning in a hospital gown, slumped in a bed that folded into a wheelchair.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "That's the last picture I have of her," Michelle says. In her kitchen, she snubs out her cigarette. She crosses to the living room, where Danielle's image looks down from the wall.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She reaches up and, with her finger, traces her daughter's face. "When I moved here," she says, "that was the first thing I hung."

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: She says she misses Danielle.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: "Have you seen her?" Michelle asks. "Is she okay?"

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Is she okay?

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Danielle is better than anyone dared hope. She has learned to look at people and let herself be held. She can chew ham. She can swim. She's tall and blond and has a little belly. She knows her name is Dani.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: In her new room, she has a window she can look out of. When she wants to see outside, all she has to do is raise her arms and her dad is right behind her, waiting to pick her up.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Times researcher Caryn Baird contributed to this report.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: About this story: St. Petersburg Times reporter Lane DeGregory and Times photographer Melissa Lyttle met Danielle and her new family at their home in February. All of the scenes at their house and in speech therapy were witnessed by the journalists.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: The opening scene and others were reconstructed from interviews with neighbors, the detective, Danielle's care manager, psychologist, teacher, legal guardian and the judge on her case. Additional information came from hundreds of pages of police reports, medical records and court documents.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: Michelle Crockett was interviewed at home in Plant City.

author: Lane DeGregory
headline: The Feral Child
graf: In June, Danielle's new parents sold their Florida home and moved out of state. Bernie built Dani a treehouse. Last week, she began summer school.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: He emerged from the metro at the L'Enfant Plaza station and positioned himself against a wall beside a trash basket. By most measures, he was nondescript: a youngish white man in jeans, a long-sleeved T-shirt and a Washington Nationals baseball cap. From a small case, he removed a violin. Placing the open case at his feet, he shrewdly threw in a few dollars and pocket change as seed money, swiveled it to face pedestrian traffic, and began to play.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: It was 7:51 a.m. on Friday, January 12, the middle of the morning rush hour. In the next 43 minutes, as the violinist performed six classical pieces, 1,097 people passed by. Almost all of them were on the way to work, which meant, for almost all of them, a government job. L'Enfant Plaza is at the nucleus of federal Washington, and these were mostly mid-level bureaucrats with those indeterminate, oddly fungible titles: policy analyst, project manager, budget officer, specialist, facilitator, consultant.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Each passerby had a quick choice to make, one familiar to commuters in any urban area where the occasional street performer is part of the cityscape: Do you stop and listen? Do you hurry past with a blend of guilt and irritation, aware of your cupidity but annoyed by the unbidden demand on your time and your wallet? Do you throw in a buck, just to be polite? Does your decision change if he's really bad? What if he's really good? Do you have time for beauty? Shouldn't you? What's the moral mathematics of the moment?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: On that Friday in January, those private questions would be answered in an unusually public way. No one knew it, but the fiddler standing against a bare wall outside the Metro in an indoor arcade at the top of the escalators was one of the finest classical musicians in the world, playing some of the most elegant music ever written on one of the most valuable violins ever made. His performance was arranged by The Washington Post as an experiment in context, perception and priorities -- as well as an unblinking assessment of public taste: In a banal setting at an inconvenient time, would beauty transcend?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: The musician did not play popular tunes whose familiarity alone might have drawn interest. That was not the test. These were masterpieces that have endured for centuries on their brilliance alone, soaring music befitting the grandeur of cathedrals and concert halls.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: The acoustics proved surprisingly kind. Though the arcade is of utilitarian design, a buffer between the Metro escalator and the outdoors, it somehow caught the sound and bounced it back round and resonant. The violin is an instrument that is said to be much like the human voice, and in this musician's masterly hands, it sobbed and laughed and sang -- ecstatic, sorrowful, importuning, adoring, flirtatious, castigating, playful, romancing, merry, triumphal, sumptuous.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: So, what do you think happened?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Hang on, we'll get you some extra help.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Leonard Slatkin, music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, was asked the same question. What did he think would occur, hypothetically, if one of the world's great violinists had performed incognito before a traveling rush-hour audience of 1,000-odd people?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "Let's assume," Slatkin said, "that he is not recognized and just taken for granted as a street musician... Still, I don't think that if he's really good, he's going to go unnoticed. He'd get a larger audience in Europe... but, okay, out of 1,000 people, my guess is there might be 35 or 40 who will recognize the quality for what it is. Maybe 75 to 100 will stop and spend some time listening."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: So, a crowd would gather?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "Oh, yes."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: And how much will he make?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "About $150."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Thanks, Maestro. As it happens, this is not hypothetical. It really happened.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "How'd I do?"

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: We'll tell you in a minute.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "Well, who was the musician?"

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Joshua Bell.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: A onetime child prodigy, at 39 Joshua Bell has arrived as an internationally acclaimed virtuoso. Three days before he appeared at the Metro station, Bell had filled the house at Boston's stately Symphony Hall, where merely pretty good seats went for $100. Two weeks later, at the Music Center at Strathmore, in North Bethesda, he would play to a standing-room-only audience so respectful of his artistry that they stifled their coughs until the silence between movements. But on that Friday in January, Joshua Bell was just another mendicant, competing for the attention of busy people on their way to work.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Bell was first pitched this idea shortly before Christmas, over coffee at a sandwich shop on Capitol Hill. A New Yorker, he was in town to perform at the Library of Congress and to visit the library's vaults to examine an unusual treasure: an 18th-century violin that once belonged to the great Austrian-born virtuoso and composer Fritz Kreisler. The curators invited Bell to play it; good sound, still.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "Here's what I'm thinking," Bell confided, as he sipped his coffee. "I'm thinking that I could do a tour where I'd play Kreisler's music..."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: He smiled.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: ". . . on Kreisler's violin."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: It was a snazzy, sequined idea -- part inspiration and part gimmick -- and it was typical of Bell, who has unapologetically embraced showmanship even as his concert career has become more and more august. He's soloed with the finest orchestras here and abroad, but he's also appeared on "Sesame Street," done late-night talk TV and performed in feature films. That was Bell playing the soundtrack on the 1998 movie "The Red Violin." (He body-doubled, too, playing to a naked Greta Scacchi.) As composer John Corigliano accepted the Oscar for Best Original Dramatic Score, he credited Bell, who, he said, "plays like a god."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: When Bell was asked if he'd be willing to don street clothes and perform at rush hour, he said:

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "Uh, a stunt?"

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Well, yes. A stunt. Would he think it... unseemly?

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Bell drained his cup.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "Sounds like fun," he said.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Bell's a heartthrob. Tall and handsome, he's got a Donny Osmond-like dose of the cutes, and, onstage, cute elides into hott. When he performs, he is usually the only man under the lights who is not in white tie and tails -- he walks out to a standing O, looking like Zorro, in black pants and an untucked black dress shirt, shirttail dangling. That cute Beatles-style mop top is also a strategic asset: Because his technique is full of body -- athletic and passionate -- he's almost dancing with the instrument, and his hair flies.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: He's single and straight, a fact not lost on some of his fans. In Boston, as he performed Max Bruch's dour Violin Concerto in G Minor, the very few young women in the audience nearly disappeared in the deep sea of silver heads. But seemingly every single one of them -- a distillate of the young and pretty -- coalesced at the stage door after the performance, seeking an autograph. It's like that always, with Bell.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Bell's been accepting over-the-top accolades since puberty: Interview magazine once said his playing "does nothing less than tell human beings why they bother to live." He's learned to field these things graciously, with a bashful duck of the head and a modified "pshaw."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: For this incognito performance, Bell had only one condition for participating. The event had been described to him as a test of whether, in an incongruous context, ordinary people would recognize genius. His condition: "I'm not comfortable if you call this genius." "Genius" is an overused word, he said: It can be applied to some of the composers whose work he plays, but not to him. His skills are largely interpretive, he said, and to imply otherwise would be unseemly and inaccurate.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: It was an interesting request, and under the circumstances, one that will be honored. The word will not again appear in this article.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: It would be breaking no rules, however, to note that the term in question, particularly as applied in the field of music, refers to a congenital brilliance -- an elite, innate, preternatural ability that manifests itself early, and often in dramatic fashion.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: One biographically intriguing fact about Bell is that he got his first music lessons when he was a 4-year-old in Bloomington, Ind. His parents, both psychologists, decided formal training might be a good idea after they saw that their son had strung rubber bands across his dresser drawers and was replicating classical tunes by ear, moving drawers in and out to vary the pitch.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: To get to the Metro from his hotel, a distance of three blocks, Bell took a taxi. He's neither lame nor lazy: He did it for his violin.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Bell always performs on the same instrument, and he ruled out using another for this gig. Called the Gibson ex Huberman, it was handcrafted in 1713 by Antonio Stradivari during the Italian master's "golden period," toward the end of his career, when he had access to the finest spruce, maple and willow, and when his technique had been refined to perfection.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "Our knowledge of acoustics is still incomplete," Bell said, "but he, he just... knew."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Bell doesn't mention Stradivari by name. Just "he." When the violinist shows his Strad to people, he holds the instrument gingerly by its neck, resting it on a knee. "He made this to perfect thickness at all parts," Bell says, pivoting it. "If you shaved off a millimeter of wood at any point, it would totally imbalance the sound." No violins sound as wonderful as Strads from the 1710s, still.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: The front of Bell's violin is in nearly perfect condition, with a deep, rich grain and luster. The back is a mess, its dark reddish finish bleeding away into a flatter, lighter shade and finally, in one section, to bare wood.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: "This has never been refinished," Bell said. "That's his original varnish. People attribute aspects of the sound to the varnish. Each maker had his own secret formula." Stradivari is thought to have made his from an ingeniously balanced cocktail of honey, egg whites and gum arabic from sub-Saharan trees.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Like the instrument in "The Red Violin," this one has a past filled with mystery and malice. Twice, it was stolen from its illustrious prior owner, the Polish virtuoso Bronislaw Huberman. The first time, in 1919, it disappeared from Huberman's hotel room in Vienna but was quickly returned. The second time, nearly 20 years later, it was pinched from his dressing room in Carnegie Hall. He never got it back. It was not until 1985 that the thief -- a minor New York violinist -- made a deathbed confession to his wife, and produced the instrument.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Bell bought it a few years ago. He had to sell his own Strad and borrow much of the rest. The price tag was reported to be about $3.5 million.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: All of which is a long explanation for why, in the early morning chill of a day in January, Josh Bell took a three-block cab ride to the Orange Line, and rode one stop to L'Enfant.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: As Metro stations go, L'Enfant Plaza is more plebian than most. Even before you arrive, it gets no respect. Metro conductors never seem to get it right: "Leh-fahn." "Layfont." "El'phant."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: At the top of the escalators are a shoeshine stand and a busy kiosk that sells newspapers, lottery tickets and a wallfull of magazines with titles such as Mammazons and Girls of Barely Legal. The skin mags move, but it's that lottery ticket dispenser that stays the busiest, with customers queuing up for Daily 6 lotto and Powerball and the ultimate suckers' bait, those pamphlets that sell random number combinations purporting to be "hot." They sell briskly. There's also a quick-check machine to slide in your lotto ticket, post-drawing, to see if you've won. Beneath it is a forlorn pile of crumpled slips.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: On Friday, January 12, the people waiting in the lottery line looking for a long shot would get a lucky break -- a free, close-up ticket to a concert by one of the world's most famous musicians -- but only if they were of a mind to take note.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Bell decided to begin with "Chaconne" from Johann Sebastian Bach's Partita No. 2 in D Minor. Bell calls it "not just one of the greatest pieces of music ever written, but one of the greatest achievements of any man in history. It's a spiritually powerful piece, emotionally powerful, structurally perfect. Plus, it was written for a solo violin, so I won't be cheating with some half-assed version."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Bell didn't say it, but Bach's "Chaconne" is also considered one of the most difficult violin pieces to master. Many try; few succeed. It's exhaustingly long -- 14 minutes -- and consists entirely of a single, succinct musical progression repeated in dozens of variations to create a dauntingly complex architecture of sound. Composed around 1720, on the eve of the European Enlightenment, it is said to be a celebration of the breadth of human possibility.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: If Bell's encomium to "Chaconne" seems overly effusive, consider this from the 19th-century composer Johannes Brahms, in a letter to Clara Schumann: "On one stave, for a small instrument, the man writes a whole world of the deepest thoughts and most powerful feelings. If I imagined that I could have created, even conceived the piece, I am quite certain that the excess of excitement and earth-shattering experience would have driven me out of my mind."

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: So, that's the piece Bell started with.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: He'd clearly meant it when he promised not to cheap out this performance: He played with acrobatic enthusiasm, his body leaning into the music and arching on tiptoes at the high notes. The sound was nearly symphonic, carrying to all parts of the homely arcade as the pedestrian traffic filed past.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Three minutes went by before something happened. Sixty-three people had already passed when, finally, there was a breakthrough of sorts. A middle-age man altered his gait for a split second, turning his head to notice that there seemed to be some guy playing music. Yes, the man kept walking, but it was something.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: A half-minute later, Bell got his first donation. A woman threw in a buck and scooted off. It was not until six minutes into the performance that someone actually stood against a wall, and listened.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: Things never got much better. In the three-quarters of an hour that Joshua Bell played, seven people stopped what they were doing to hang around and take in the performance, at least for a minute. Twenty-seven gave money, most of them on the run -- for a total of $32 and change. That leaves the 1,070 people who hurried by, oblivious, many only three feet away, few even turning to look.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
graf: No, Mr. Slatkin, there was never a crowd, not even for a second.

author: Gene Weingarten
headline: Pearls Before Breakfast
