headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Mr. Shata viewed cooperation as his Islamic duty. "Whoever is afraid of dialogue is hiding something," he said.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The greatest test of Mr. Shata's relationship with the authorities came with the arrest of a young Muslim congregant who was accused of plotting terrorism.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Shahawar Matin Siraj, 23, was a chatty Pakistani immigrant who worked in the Islamic bookstore next to the mosque. On the job, he was sometimes seen talking to James Elshafay, 21, a soft-spoken Muslim American from Staten Island. In August 2004, both were charged in Brooklyn federal court with conspiring to blow up the 34th Street subway station at Herald Square.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The men had been videotaped discussing the plot and scouting the subway station with a paid police informer who told them he belonged to an Islamic "brotherhood."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: In the days after the arrests, reporters swarmed into Bay Ridge. Anonymous threats were called in to the bookstore, Islamic Books & Tapes. One letter to the store read, "You're all dead meat."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The imam and others at the mosque soon realized they knew the informer: a gray-haired Egyptian who called himself Osama Daoudi and said he lived in Staten Island.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "He used to say, 'My name is Osama, like Osama bin Laden,' " Mr. Shata recalled.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Mr. Daoudi had surfaced at the mosque a year earlier, said Mr. Shata. He tried to interest the imam in a real estate deal, proposing that Mr. Shata use his influence over Muslims to collect money owed to Mr. Daoudi in exchange for a secret cash commission, Mr. Shata recalled.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The imam wanted nothing to do with the scheme, he said, and kept his distance. He found Mr. Daoudi off-putting. He claimed to be the son of a famous Egyptian sheik and was known at the mosque for weeping when he prayed. But he also smoked.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "Piety in Islam forbids smoking," Mr. Shata observed.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Most striking was the anti-American sentiment that Mr. Daoudi espoused, Mr. Shata said. During visits with the imam, Mr. Daoudi complained that Americans might fear him because he had a Ph.D. in nuclear engineering. He also said that the F.B.I. wanted to search his home, the imam recalled.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "I told him, 'As long as you do nothing wrong, open your house and your heart to people,' " said Mr. Shata.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The imam said he believed that after Mr. Daoudi found him uninterested, he turned his focus to Mr. Siraj and Mr. Elshafay.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Starting in September 2003, the informer spent months drawing Mr. Siraj into the plot, teaching him about violent jihad, said Mr. Siraj's lawyer, Martin R. Stolar.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The authorities would say little about the case, which is set for trial next month. Efforts to locate Mr. Daoudi, whose name was provided by Mr. Stolar, were unsuccessful.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The Police Department's chief spokesman, Paul J. Browne, dismissed Mr. Stolar's claim that the police had manufactured the plot. "We didn't propose that," he said. "We took action to stop it and there's a big difference."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Mr. Siraj had an "interest in violence" that was known to the authorities prior to an informer's involvement, Mr. Browne added.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: For the imam, the informer's supposed maneuvering was not surprising. Mr. Shata shares a view common among Muslims in Bay Ridge that confidential informers are untrustworthy because some have criminal records or work for pay.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: This perception irks Mr. Frahm, the F.B.I. official. Informers' reports are closely vetted, he said, and their motives are irrelevant if they provide correct information.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Mr. Frahm devotes much time to building trust among Muslim leaders. But he also warns them not to turn a blind eye to questionable activity. "You can't play part-time American," he said.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Anger at the authorities came easily at the mosque. But a quiet, if disturbing, question soon followed: Entrapped or not, what had caused these young men to entertain thoughts of terrorism?

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The imam looks for answers on the crowded sidewalk outside the mosque.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The worn cement slabs along Fifth Avenue have long been divided into two social camps. After the Friday prayer, the section in front of the mosque fills with the neighborhood's Arab pioneers, gray-haired and balding Palestinians and Egyptians.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Several feet south, under the marquee of a movie theater, the neighborhood's Arab teenagers gather. Before Sept. 11, the groups rarely mingled. But in the years since, many of the younger set have returned to their faith.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The imam now rises to deliver his Friday khutba, or sermon, before rows of young men, some in low-hanging jeans and baseball caps turned backward. Many have come to learn more about their religion so they can defend it at work or at school. Others no longer feel at home elsewhere. They have been passed over for jobs, or stopped and questioned by the authorities too many times.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: It is these men, and their sense of alienation, that most worry Mr. Shata. The mosque is not their only refuge. A new crop of sheesha cafes opened along the avenue after Sept. 11, filling with male chatter and the sweet smoke of water pipes.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "I once read a Spanish proverb," Mr. Shata said one evening. "The wall of hatred was asked, 'How were you built?' And the reply was, 'From the stones of insults.' "

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Over the last three decades, the European immigrant enclave of Bay Ridge has given way to Gazan barbers, halal butchers and Egyptian jewelers. But the newest settlers have not always been welcome.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "It became, 'This ain't Bay Ridge anymore, it's Beirut,' " said Russell Kain, a retired community affairs officer from the 68th Precinct.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: America has brought the imam his own share of taunts. A woman on a plane once asked him if he was Muslim and then demanded to change seats. Mr. Shata grew up wearing the long robes of his Egyptian homeland. He now travels in a suit.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: But in Bay Ridge, he fights alienation with an open heart. He is increasingly a blend of East and West, proudly walking to the mosque in a robe and sandals, while warding off the cold with a wool Yankees hat. "I feel like I'm living in my country," he said.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: It is a message he repeats everywhere he goes, one he says is the antidote to hatred. He meets with Muslim youth groups at mosques around the city, telling them not to wait for an invitation to embrace America. Even if Muslims feel singled out, Mr. Shata often says, America is still the freest country in the world.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The imam plans to stay for "as long as God wills it," he said. He got his green card in November.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Mr. Shata knows most of his congregants by face, and the 400 who pray daily by name. If he sees a young person taken by sudden devotion, his impulse is to probe. Is the person driven by faith or isolation? He can't always be sure.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The imam's concerns are shared by the F.B.I. Several officials said the bureau had recently focused its surveillance on the city's Muslim youth after learning that the London bombings last July were mostly carried out by South Asians raised in Britain. Mr. Shata and the authorities agree that young Muslims are most captive to the messages of militant sheiks.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "Islam is a religion based on intellect," he tells his young listeners. "Islam says to you: 'Think. Don't close your eyes and just follow your emotions. Don't follow the sheik. Perhaps you have a better mind than his.' "

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "If you do wrong," he says, "you do wrong to the whole Islamic world."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: One evening in July, Mr. Shata sat in the neat, air-conditioned living room of a brick row house in Queens. An Egyptian family had invited him over to bless their newest member, a 5-week-old girl.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The infant, swathed in soft pink cotton, slept in a car seat on the floor as her mother and grandmother offered tea and pastries. On a wide-screen television, Al Jazeera flashed news that two Algerian diplomats had been killed in Iraq.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Mr. Shata was bothered by the killers' description of the victims as "infidels." The world, he said, needed to agree on a definition of terrorism. "What I may see as terrorism, you may not see that way," he said.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Few subjects pose a more complicated test of loyalties for Mr. Shata than the struggle between Arabs and Israelis. Many Palestinians attend his mosque. When he discusses the conflict, one gets the sense that he is, again, speaking to several audiences.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Like Arabs around the world, Mr. Shata disagrees profoundly with the United States' steadfast support of Israel, and views the militant group Hamas as a powerful symbol of resistance.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: When Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the founder and spiritual leader of Hamas, was killed by Israelis in March 2004, Mr. Shata told hundreds who gathered at a memorial service in Brooklyn that the "lion of Palestine has been martyred."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Mr. Shata is also acutely aware that the United States classifies Hamas as a terrorist group. In the same speech, he condemned all violence. "We don't hate Jews," he recalled saying. "To kill one man is to kill all mankind."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Yet in another sermon, the imam exalted a young Palestinian mother, Reem Al-Reyashi, who blew herself up in 2004 at a crossing point between Gaza and Israel, killing four Israelis. Mr. Shata described the woman as a martyr.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: When asked about the speech, Mr. Shata seemed unusually conflicted. He has forged friendships with rabbis in New York -- something he never imagined in Egypt. Engaging in a discussion about the Arab-Israeli struggle would invite controversy, he said, both within his mosque and outside it. "I worry this will cause trouble with my Jewish brothers," he said. He rarely broaches the topic in sermons and addressed it only reluctantly in interviews.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "I do not accept suicide operations that target civilians at any time or place," Mr. Shata said. But striking Israeli soldiers "as a means of defense" was justifiable.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The Israelis, he said, have "killed Palestinian women, destroyed their homes, taken their land and materials and made them into refugees," while Palestinians lack the military means to fight back. Islamic law forbids suicide, he said, but the Koran says Muslims can defend themselves if attacked. Ms. Al-Reyashi killed two soldiers, a border police officer and a security guard, though Palestinian and Israeli civilians were hurt.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Mr. Shata acknowledged that his opinion, while common among Arabs, is strongly opposed not only by many non-Muslims, but even by some of his congregants. "Some Muslims, if they hear this, would make me out to be a nonbeliever because they see that all these suicide operations are a must," he said. "And there are other Muslims who feel that all of these operations are forbidden.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "My nature is always to be in the middle," he said. "It's always the person in the middle who ends up being the enemy of the right and the left. I don't want to open up two fronts against me."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Mr. Shata is forceful in his condemnation of terrorism in the West, a message he feels is rarely heard. After the suicide bombings in London last year, he and other Muslims called a news conference in Brooklyn to denounce the violence. Nobody came.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: In his sermons, Mr. Shata repeatedly makes the point that terrorism violates the tenets of Islam. "I feel that I breathe underwater, or that I cry in a desert," he said recently. "That nobody responds."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: It was part of Mr. Shata's annual Sept. 11 speech, a tradition he began in 2003. Recordings of the sermon, titled "What Muslims Want From America," sold out at the mosque overnight.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: The three Sept. 11 speeches echo the imam's journey in America. His first speech was conciliatory in tone; a treatise on the peaceful nature of Islam. In 2004, he urged Muslims to respect the law, and trust that America is not "the enemy." Last September, his message hardened.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "We want the U.S. to be just in dealing with our issues," Mr. Shata declared. A man "should not feel that he is under surveillance for every word he says, every move he makes and every piece of paper he signs."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: Muslims feel isolated, yet crave acceptance, he said, likening them to their ancestors 14 centuries ago, who sought refuge from the king of Abyssinia.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "O king, we have come to thy country having chosen thee above all others," he said, reciting the words of the group's leader, Jafar Ibn Abi Talib.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: To lead the faithful in a faith under fire
graf: "It is our hope, o king, that here, with thee, we shall not suffer wrong."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The young Egyptian professional could pass for any New York bachelor.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Dressed in a crisp polo shirt and swathed in cologne, he races his Nissan Maxima through the rain-slicked streets of Manhattan, late for a date with a tall brunette. At red lights, he fusses with his hair.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: What sets the bachelor apart from other young men on the make is the chaperon sitting next to him -- a tall, bearded man in a white robe and stiff embroidered hat.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "I pray that Allah will bring this couple together," the man, Sheik Reda Shata, says, clutching his seat belt and urging the bachelor to slow down.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Christian singles have coffee hour. Young Jews have JDate. But many Muslims believe that it is forbidden for an unmarried man and woman to meet in private. In predominantly Muslim countries, the job of making introductions and even arranging marriages typically falls to a vast network of family and friends.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: In Brooklyn, there is Mr. Shata.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Week after week, Muslims embark on dates with him in tow. Mr. Shata, the imam of a Bay Ridge mosque, juggles some 550 "marriage candidates," from a gold-toothed electrician to a professor at Columbia University. The meetings often unfold on the green velour couch of his office, or over a meal at his favorite Yemeni restaurant on Atlantic Avenue.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The bookish Egyptian came to America in 2002 to lead prayers, not to dabble in matchmaking. He was far more conversant in Islamic jurisprudence than in matters of the heart. But American imams must wear many hats, none of which come tailor-made.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Whether issuing American-inspired fatwas or counseling the homesick, fielding questions from the F.B.I. or mediating neighborhood spats, Mr. Shata walks an endless labyrinth of problems.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: If anything seems conquerable, it is the solitude of Muslim singles. Nothing brings the imam more joy than guiding them to marriage. It is his way of fashioning a future for his faith. It is his most heartfelt effort -- by turns graceful and comedic, vexing and hopeful -- to make Islam work in America.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Word of the imam's talents has traveled far, eliciting lonely calls from Muslims in Chicago and Los Angeles, or from meddlesome parents in Cairo and Damascus.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: From an estimated 250 chaperoned dates, Mr. Shata has produced 10 marriages.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "The prophet said whoever brings a man and woman together, it is as if he has worshiped for an entire year," said Mr. Shata, 37, speaking through an Arabic translator.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The task is not easy. In a country of plentiful options, Muslim immigrants can become picky, even rude, the imam complains.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: During one date, a woman studied the red-circled eyes of a prospective husband and asked, "Have you brought me an alcoholic?"

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: On another occasion, an Egyptian man stared at the flat chest of a pleasant young Moroccan woman and announced, "She looks like a log!" the imam recalled.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "This would never happen in Egypt," said Mr. Shata, turning red at the memory. "Never, never. If I knew this boy had no manners I never would have let him into my office."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The concept of proper courtship in Islam, like much about the faith, is open to interpretation.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Islamic law specifies that a man and woman who are unmarried may not be alone in closed quarters. Some Muslims reject any mingling before marriage. Others freely date. Many fall somewhere in between, meeting in groups, getting engaged and spending time alone before the wedding, while their parents look the other way.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: For one Syrian in New York, a date at Starbucks is acceptable if it begins and ends on the premises: The public is his chaperon.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Mr. Shata is a traditionalist. There were few strangers in his rural town of birth, Kafr al Battikh, in northeastern Egypt. Men and women often agreed to marry the day they met, and a few made the deal sight unseen. It was rare to meet anyone from a distant province, let alone another country.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: New York is not only the capital of the world, imams often joke, but also the crossroads of Islam, a human sampling more diverse than anywhere save Mecca during the annual pilgrimage known as the Hajj. Beyond the city's five boroughs, Muslim immigrants have formed Islamic hubs in California, Illinois, Michigan and Texas.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: At the center of these hubs stands a familiar sight in a foreign land, the mosque. What was a place of worship in Pakistan or Algeria becomes, in Houston or Detroit, a social haven. But inside, the sexes remain largely apart.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: A growing number of Muslim Web sites advertise marriage candidates, and housewives often double as matchmakers. One mosque in Princeton, N.J., plays host to a closely supervised version of speed dating. And so many singles worship at the Islamic Society of Boston that a committee was formed to match them up.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Fearing a potential surplus of single Muslim women, one Brooklyn imam reportedly urged his wealthier male congregants during a Ramadan sermon last year to take two wives. When a woman complained about the sermon to Mr. Shata, he laughed.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "You know that preacher who said Hugo Chávez should be shot?" he asked. "We have our idiots, too."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: More than a matchmaker, Mr. Shata sees himself as a surrogate elder to young Muslims, many of whom live far from their parents. In America, only an imam is thought to have the connections, wisdom and respect to step into the role.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Mr. Shata began the service three months after arriving in Brooklyn in 2002, recruited to lead the Islamic Society of Bay Ridge, a mosque on Fifth Avenue.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Dates chaperoned by Mr. Shata -- or "meetings between candidates," as the imam prefers to call them -- often take place in his distinctly unromantic office, amid rows of Islamic texts. As a couple get acquainted, the imam sits quietly at his desk, writing a sermon or surfing the Arabic Web sites of CNN and the BBC.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: If there is an awkward silence, the imam perks up and asks a question ("So tell me, Ilham, how many siblings do you have?") and the conversation is moving again.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Candidates are vetted carefully, and those without personal references need not apply. But instinct is Mr. Shata's best guide. He refused to help a Saudi from California because the man would consider only a teenage wife. Others have shown an all-too-keen interest in a green card.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Those who pass initial inspection are listed in the imam's version of a little black book -- their names, phone numbers, specifications and desires. Some prefer "silky hair," others "a virgin." Nearly all candidates, men and women alike, want a mate with devotion to Islam, decent looks and legal immigration status.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Scanning the book, the imam makes his pitch with the precision of a car salesman.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "There is a girl, an American convert, Dominican, looks a little Egyptian. Skin-wise, not white, not dark. Wheat-colored. She's 19, studies accounting," Mr. Shata told a 24-year-old Palestinian man one afternoon.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "This is my only choice?" replied the man, Yamal Othman, who lives in Queens.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Such questions annoy Mr. Shata. An imam, he says, should be trusted to select the best candidate. Often, though, his recommendations are met with skepticism.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "It's harder than choosing a diamond," said Mr. Shata.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Sometimes, on the imam's three-legged dates, no one seems more excited than Mr. Shata himself. He makes hurried, hearty introductions and then steps back to watch, as if mixing chemicals in a lab experiment. Love is rarely ignited, but the imam remains awed by its promise.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Mr. Shata discovered love 15 years ago, when he walked into the living room of the most stately house in Kafr al Battikh.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The imam was tall, 22, a rising star at the local mosque. For months, Omyma Elshabrawy knew only his voice. She would listen to his thunderous sermons from the women's section, out of view. Then, one evening, he appeared at her home, presented as a prospective groom to her father, a distinguished reciter of the Koran.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The young woman, then 20, walked toward Mr. Shata carrying a tray of lemonade.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "She entered my heart," said the imam.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: After serving the drinks, she disappeared. Right then, Mr. Shata asked her father for her hand in marriage. The older man paused. His daughter was the town beauty, an English student with marriage offers from doctors. The imam was penniless.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: But before Mr. Elshabrawy could respond, a sugary voice interrupted. "I accept," his daughter said from behind a door.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "I loved him from the moment I saw him," Ms. Elshabrawy said.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: They now have four children.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The family posed last year for a Sears-style portrait, taken by a woman in Bay Ridge who photographs Muslim families in her basement. A blue sky and white picket fence adorn the background. The imam sits at center, with the baby, Mohammed, in his lap, his three daughters smiling, his wife wrapped in a lime-green hijab.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Mr. Shata carries the picture in the breast pocket of his robe. It is as close as most people get to his family. At the mosque, they are a mystery. His wife has been there twice.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Their years in America have come with great hardship, a subject the imam rarely discusses. The trouble is the illness of his 7-year-old daughter, Rawda, who is severely epileptic. She has dozens of seizures every day and rarely leaves home. No combination of medicine seems to help.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "Rawda is the wound in my heart," the imam said.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Mr. Shata offers long, stubborn theories about the value of marriage, but to observe him at home is to understand the commitment he seeks to foster in other Muslims.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The family lives in a spare, dimly lighted apartment two blocks from the mosque. Headscarves are piled over Pokémon cards. The gold-painted words "Allah is Great" are framed over a threadbare couch. In the next room, an "I {sheart} New York" bumper sticker is slapped on the wall.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Mr. Shata spends long hours away from his family, lecturing at mosques, settling disputes, whispering the call to prayer in the ears of newborn babies. On his walk home at night, he shops for groceries, never forgetting the Honey Nut Cheerios, a favorite American discovery of his children.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: When he walks in the door, his face softens. Loud kisses are planted on tender cheeks. Mohammed squeals, the girls smile, sweet laughter echoes.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: But then there is Rawda.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "My beautiful girl," the imam says softly one evening, holding his limp daughter in his lap after a seizure has passed. He places one pill in Rawda's mouth, then another. She looks at him weakly.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "There we go," he whispers. "Inshallah."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Her lids close with sleep. He lays her in bed and shuts off the light.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Hardship, the imam believes -- like marriage, like life -- is a test from God.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: It is proof of the imam's uncommon popularity among women that he is trusted with roughly 300 female marriage candidates.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The mosque on Fifth Avenue is a decidedly male place. Men occupy every position on the board of directors. They crowd the sidewalk after prayer. Only they may enter the mosque's central room of worship. Only men, they often point out, are required to attend the Friday prayer.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: One floor below is the cramped room where the women worship. On Fridays, they sit pressed together, their headscarves itching with heat. They must watch their imam on a closed-circuit television that no one seems to have adjusted in years.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: But they listen devotedly. Teenage girls often roll their eyes at foreign imams, who seem to them like extraterrestrials. Their immigrant mothers often find these clerics too strict, an uncomfortable reminder of their conservative homelands.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Mr. Shata is both foreign and familiar. He presides over a patriarchal world, sometimes upholding it, and other times challenging it. In one sermon, he said that a man was in charge of his home and had the right to "choose his wife's friends."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Another day, to the consternation of his male congregants, he invited a female Arab social worker to lecture on domestic violence. The women were allowed to sit next to the men in the main section of the mosque.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The imam frowns at career women who remain single in their 30's, but boasts of their accomplishments to interest marriage candidates. He employs his own brand of feminism, vetting marriage contracts closely to ensure brides receive a fair dowry and fighting for them when they don't.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Far more than is customary, he spends hours listening to women: to their worries and confessions, their intimate secrets and frank questions about everything from menstruation to infidelity. They line up outside his office and call his home at all hours, often referring to him as "my brother" or "father." He can summon the details of their lives with the same encyclopedic discipline he once used to memorize the Koran.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "Are you separated yet?" Mr. Shata asked a woman he encountered at Lutheran Medical Center one day last July. She nodded. "May God make it easier for you," he said.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: By most standards, the Egyptian bachelor was a catch. He had broad shoulders and a playful smile. He was witty. He earned a comfortable salary as an engineer, and came from what he called "a good family."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: But the imam saw him differently, as a young man in danger of losing his faith. The right match might save him.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The bachelor, who is 33, came to Brooklyn from Alexandria, Egypt, six years earlier. He craved a better salary, and freedom from controlling parents. He asked that his name not be printed for fear of causing embarrassment to his family.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: America was not like Egypt, where his family's connections could secure a good job. In Brooklyn, he found work as a busboy. He traded the plush comfort of his parents' home for an apartment crowded with other Egyptian immigrants. His nights were lonely. Temptation was abundant.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Women covered far less of their bodies. Bare limbs, it seemed, were everywhere. In Islam, men are instructed to lower their gaze to avoid falling into sin.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "In the summertime, it's a disaster for us," said the bachelor. "Especially a guy like me, who's looking all the time."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Curiosity lured him into bars, clubs and the occasional one-night stand.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: But with freedom came guilt, he said. After drifting from his faith, he visited Mr. Shata's mosque during Ramadan in 2004.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The imam struck him as oddly disarming. He made jokes, and explained Islam in simple, passionate paragraphs. The bachelor soon began praying daily, attending weekly lectures and reading the Koran. By then, he had his own apartment and a consulting job.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Now he wanted a Muslim wife.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: If the bachelor had been in Egypt, his parents would offer a stream of marriage candidates. The distance had not stopped them entirely. His mother sent him a video of his brother's wedding, directing him to footage of a female guest. He was unimpressed.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "I'm a handsome guy," he explained one evening as he sped toward Manhattan. It was his second date with Mr. Shata in attendance. "I have a standard in beauty."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: From the passenger seat, the imam flipped open the glove compartment to find an assortment of pricey colognes. He inspected a bottle of Gio and, with a nod from the bachelor, spritzed it over his robe.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The imam and the bachelor were at odds over the material world, but on one thing they agreed: it is a Muslim duty to smell good. The religion's founder, the Prophet Muhammad, was said to wear musk.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The car slowed before a brick high-rise on Second Avenue. Soon the pair rode up in the elevator. The bachelor took a breath and rang the doorbell. An older woman answered. Behind her stood a slender, fetching woman with a shy smile.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The young woman, Engy Abdelkader, had been presented to the imam by another matchmaker. A woman of striking beauty and poise, Ms. Abdelkader is less timid than she first seems. She works as an immigration and human rights lawyer, and speaks in forceful, eloquent bursts. She is proud of her faith, and lectures publicly on Islam and civil liberties.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: She was not always so outspoken. The daughter of Egyptian immigrants, Ms. Abdelkader, 30, was raised in suburban Howell, N.J., where she longed to fit in. Though she grew up praying, in high school she chose not to wear a hijab, the head scarf donned by Muslim girls when they reach puberty.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: But Sept. 11 awakened her, Ms. Abdelkader said. For her and other Muslims, the terrorist attacks prompted a return to the faith, driven by what she said was a need to reclaim Islam from terrorists and a vilifying media. Headscarves became a statement, equal parts political and religious.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "There's nothing oppressive about it," said Ms. Abdelkader. "As a Muslim woman I am asking people to pay attention to the content of my character rather than my physical appearance."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The pair sat on a couch, awkwardly sipping tea. They began by talking, in English, about their professions. The bachelor was put off by the fact that Ms. Abdelkader had a law degree, yet earned a modest salary.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "Why go to law school and not make money?" he asked later.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Ms. Abdelkader's mother and a female friend who lived in the apartment sat listening nearby until the imam mercifully distracted them. The first hint of trouble came soon after.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: It was his dream, the engineer told Ms. Abdelkader, to buy a half-million-dollar house. But he was uncertain that the mortgage he would need is lawful in Islam.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Ms. Abdelkader straightened her back and replied, "I would rather have eternal bliss in the hereafter than live in a house or apartment with a mortgage."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: An argument ensued. Voices rose. Ms. Abdelkader's mother took her daughter's side. The friend wavered. The bachelor held his ground. The imam tried to mediate.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Indeed, he was puzzled. Here was a woman who had grown up amid tended lawns and new cars, yet she rejected materialism. And here was a man raised by Muslim hands, yet he was rebelliously moderate.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: After the date, the bachelor told the imam, "I want a woman, not a sheik."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Months later, he married another immigrant; she was not especially devoted to Islam but she made him laugh, he said. They met through friends in New York.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: Ms. Abdelkader remains single. The imam still believes she was the perfect match.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: That evening, the imam stood on the sidewalk outside. Rain fell in stinging drops.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "I never wanted to be a sheik," he said. "I used to think that a religious person is very extreme and never smiles. And I love to smile. I love to laugh. I used to think that religious people were isolated and I love to be among people."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: The rain soaked the imam's robe and began to pool in his sandals. A moment later, he ducked inside the building.

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "The surprise for me was that the qualities I thought would not make a good sheik -- simplicity and humor and being close to people -- those are the most important qualities. People love those who smile and laugh. They need someone who lives among them and knows their pain."

author: Andrea Elliott
headline: Tending to Muslin hearts and Islam's future
graf: "I know them," said Mr. Shata. "Like a brother."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Inside a limousine parked on the airport tarmac, Katherine Cathey looked out at the clear night sky and felt a kick.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "He's moving," she said. "Come feel him. He's moving."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Her two best friends leaned forward on the soft leather seats and put their hands on her stomach.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I felt it," one of them said. "I felt it."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Outside, the whine of jet engines swelled.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Oh, sweetie," her friend said. "I think this is his plane."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As the three young women peered through the tinted windows, Katherine squeezed a set of dog tags stamped with the same name as her unborn son:

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: James J. Cathey.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "He wasn't supposed to come home this way," she said, tightening her grip on the tags, which were linked by a necklace to her husband's wedding ring.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The women looked through the back window. Then the 23-year-old placed her hand on her pregnant belly.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Everything that made me happy is on that plane," she said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: They watched as airport workers rolled a conveyor belt to the rear of the plane, followed by six solemn Marines.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Katherine turned from the window and closed her eyes.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I don't want it to be dark right now. I wish it was daytime," she said. "I wish it was daytime for the rest of my life. The night is just too hard."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Suddenly, the car door opened. A white-gloved hand reached into the limousine from outside - the same hand that had knocked on Katherine's door in Brighton five days earlier.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The man in the deep blue uniform knelt down to meet her eyes, speaking in a soft, steady voice.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Katherine," said Maj. Steve Beck, "it's time."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The American Airlines 757 couldn't have landed much farther from the war.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The plane arrived in Reno on a Friday evening, the beginning of the 2005 "Hot August Nights" festival - one of the city's biggest - filled with flashing lights, fireworks, carefree music and plenty of gambling.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When a young Marine in dress uniform had boarded the plane to Reno, the passengers smiled and nodded politely. None knew he had just come from the plane's cargo hold, after watching his best friend's casket loaded onboard.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: At 24 years old, Sgt. Gavin Conley was only seven days younger than the man in the coffin. The two had met as 17-year-olds on another plane - the one to boot camp in California. They had slept in adjoining top bunks, the two youngest recruits in the barracks.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: All Marines call each other brother. Conley and Jim Cathey could have been. They finished each other's sentences, had matching infantry tattoos etched on their shoulders, and cracked on each other as if they had grown up together - which, in some ways, they had.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When the airline crew found out about Conley's mission, they bumped him to first-class. He had never flown there before. Neither had Jim Cathey.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: On the flight, the woman sitting next to him nodded toward his uniform and asked if he was coming or going. To the war, she meant.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He fell back on the words the military had told him to say: "I'm escorting a fallen Marine home to his family from the situation in Iraq."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The woman quietly said she was sorry, Conley said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Then she began to cry.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When the plane landed in Nevada, the pilot asked the passengers to remain seated while Conley disembarked alone. Then the pilot told them why.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The passengers pressed their faces against the windows. Outside, a procession walked toward the plane. Passengers in window seats leaned back to give others a better view. One held a child up to watch.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: From their seats in the plane, they saw a hearse and a Marine extending a white-gloved hand into a limousine, helping a pregnant woman out of the car.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: On the tarmac, Katherine Cathey wrapped her arm around the major's, steadying herself. Then her eyes locked on the cargo hold and the flag-draped casket.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Inside the plane, they couldn't hear the screams.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Each door is different.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Some are ornately carved hardwood, some are hollow aluminum. Some are protected by elaborate security systems, some by loose screen doors.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: During the past year, the 40-year-old Marine major in the white gloves has stood at the front doors of homes in three states, preparing to deliver the message no family wants to hear.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: It is a job he never asked for and one for which he received no training. There are no set rules, only impersonal guidelines. It is a mission without weapons.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Steve Beck trained to fight as a Marine, winning accolades as the most accomplished marksman of his class - a man who later earned two master's degrees in a quest to become a leader on the battlefield. He had hoped to deploy during the Persian Gulf War and definitely thought he would get his chance this time.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Instead, he found himself faced with an assignment that starts with a long walk to a stranger's porch and an outstretched hand. It continues with a promise steeped in the history of the Corps that most people associate only with the battlefield:

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Never leave a Marine behind.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In combat, men have been killed while retrieving their comrades' bodies, knowing that the dead Marine would have done the same for them. It's a tradition instilled in boot camp, where Marines are steeped in 230 years of history and the sacrifices of tens of thousands of lives.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For Beck, that promise holds long after the dead return home.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In the past 12 months, he has seen inside the caskets, learned each Marine's name and nickname, touched the toys they grew up with and read the letters they wrote home. He has held grieving mothers in long embraces, absorbing their muffled cries into the dark blue shoulder of his uniform.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Sometimes he's gone home to his own family and found himself crying in the dark.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When he first donned the Marine uniform, Beck had never heard the term "casualty assistance calls officer." He certainly never expected to serve as one.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As it turned out, it would become the most important mission of his life.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Each door is different. But once they're open, Beck said, some of the scenes inside are inevitably the same.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "The curtains pull away. They come to the door. And they know. They always know," he said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "You can almost see the blood run out of their body and their heart hit the floor. It's not the blood as much as their soul. Something sinks. I've never seen that except when someone dies. And I've seen a lot of death.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "They're falling - either literally or figuratively - and you have to catch them.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "In this business, I can't save his life. All I can do is catch the family while they're falling."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Hours before Beck's first call, a homemade bomb exploded.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Somewhere in the Iraqi desert, in the midst of the rubble, lay the body of a Marine from Colorado.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The information from his dog tags was checked. Double-checked. And then the name began its journey home.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: During World War I, World War II and the Korean War, the message arrived in sparse sympathy letters or in the terse language of telegrams, leaving relatives alone to soak in the words. Near the end of the Vietnam War, the military changed the process, saddling stateside troops with the knock at the door.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: On that day in October 2004, inside an office at Buckley Air Force Base in Aurora, Beck's phone rang.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "We have a casualty in your area," the voice said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: At the time, Beck wasn't sure what came next. He did know that he didn't have much time. Once the call is received, the goal for notification is four hours.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Troops in the field now often have access to e-mail and satellite telephones. So when a service member dies, his commander is directed to shut off communications back home to keep rumors from reaching the family before the notification officers.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Still, the pressure is palpable. The call often comes in the middle of the night. Officers must retrieve vital information from headquarters - the Marine's next of kin, the basic circumstances surrounding the death, addresses and phone numbers - and there is no room for error.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: With each step, they get closer to the door.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck looks like the job: hard and soft. His white cotton gloves cover calloused hands. They lead to thick, regular-guy arms shaped by work instead of weightlifting, and a round, pale face with big cheeks that turn red when he hasn't had enough sleep, which is most of the time.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck's bookshelf is packed with titles ranging from the History of the Peloponnesian War to the 9/11 Commission Report. He can quote Clausewitz and Sun Tsu in regular conversation.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: But he never strays far from his roots.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Born in Sand Springs, Okla., he still pronounces his home state "O-koma." He'll describe another Marine's muscles as "hard as a woodpecker's lips," and when he wants something done with precision, he'll require his troops to get it "down to the gnat's ass."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: His car radio is eternally tuned to country stations because, he insists, "a day without country music is like a day without sunshine."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: It's an Everyman quality that can't be faked, one that has become a crucial component in helping the families of fallen Marines.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: After receiving that first call last fall, Beck grabbed for a thick, acronym-studded manual, The Casualty Assistance Calls Officer's (CACO) Guide. It offered only the basics:

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "In cases of death, the following is suggested and may be modified as follows," it reads, in part.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "The Commandant of the Marine Corps has entrusted me to express his deep regret that your (relationship), (name), (died/was killed in action) in (place of incident), (city/state or country) on (date). (State the circumstances). The Commandant extends his deepest sympathy to you and your family in your loss."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When he began the job as site commander at Marine Air Control Squadron 23, Beck knew that death notification was a possibility. The previous commander already had supervised three funerals in the region that includes Colorado and parts of Wyoming, Kansas, South Dakota and Nebraska.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Until that first call, however, Beck had plenty of other worries.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: From their base among the top-secret radar installations at Buckley, Beck and his Marines are highly trained to support aircraft and missile operations. They also are continually training Marine Reservists and sending them to Iraq.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Since the beginning of the war, the Marines stationed at Buckley have made 19 notifications following the deaths of active-duty Marines. Fifteen of those were killed in action in Iraq and four died in stateside traffic accidents.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck personally has notified five families, but even when he isn't the one who delivers the message, he is involved.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Before leaving on his first notification, Beck asked for advice from two men in another branch of the service.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "One of the first things they said was, 'Don't embrace them. If they embrace you, keep your distance,'" he said, shaking his head.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I didn't have much use for them."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Different services have different guidelines for notification. In the Army, one officer is responsible for the knock, while another steps in to handle the aftercare.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In the Marines, the same person who knocks on the door is the family's primary contact for the next year or more.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: There is no group of Marines whose primary task is death notification. Just as every Marine is a rifleman - expected to be able to handle a weapon and head to the front if tapped - any officer also may be called to make the walk to the door.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For Beck, that door is the "LOD" - the line of departure. The point of no return.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: After all of the racing, all of the frantic scramble, it's the point where time freezes.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Once I get to the porch, I stand there and take a deep breath. At that point, you can wait 10 seconds, wait 30 seconds, wait an hour - it's not going to go away," he said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "There's no option. There's no fork in the road. You just stare down that straight path. You step up because there is no fork.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I pick myself up, gather my thoughts and ring the bell."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: There were no footprints in the snow.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: That struck Beck as he sat across the street in his government SUV that night, outside a house in Laramie blanketed by cold and quiet.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In his briefcase was a sheet of paper: "INITIAL CASUALTY REPORT," it read. "LCPL. KYLE W. BURNS."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Every second he waited would be one more second that, for those in the house, everything was still all right. He stared at the front door, at the drifting snow, then looked at his watch.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When he left Denver, it was still Nov. 11; now it was well past midnight.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Veterans Day was over.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Inside the house, the lights were still on.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: All during the drive to Laramie, Beck imagined what would happen at the door and what he would say once it opened. This was his second notification. He had easily memorized the words in the manual. There was no script for the rest.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He talked it out with his passenger, Gunnery Sgt. Shane Scarpino. In the truck, the two men played out scenarios the same way they would if headed into battle. What if the parents aren't home? What if they become aggressive? What if they break down? What if, what if, what if.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Two Marines are required for every visit, not just for emotional support, but for each other's protection. While most parents eventually grow close to their casualty assistance officer, the initial meeting tests all emotions. One of the Buckley Marines had been slapped by a mother. Last year, a group of Marines in Florida had their van set on fire by a distraught father.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Amid sheets of blowing snow just outside Laramie, Beck had pulled the truck into a gas station and the two Marines grabbed their garment bags.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When they emerged from the restroom, their spit-shined black shoes clicked on the floor. Their dark blue pants, lined with a red stripe signifying past bloodshed, fell straight. Their jackets wrapped their necks with a high collar that dates back to the Revolutionary War, when Marines wore leather neckstraps to protect them from enemy swords.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As they walked out of the gas station, Beck felt the eyes of the clerk.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He knows, Beck thought.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Once they drove into the family's neighborhood, the modest white house found them first, beckoning with the brightest porch lights and biggest house numbers on the block.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck pulled to the curb and cut his headlights. He looked at Scarpino.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Then the two men climbed out of the truck, and walked into the pristine snow.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: From then on, every step would leave footprints.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The man nobody wants to see

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Down in the basement of their home in Laramie, Kyle Burns' parents didn't hear the doorbell.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The couple had spent most of the snowy night trying to hook up a new television. It was nearly 1 a.m. when the dog leapt into a barking frenzy.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Jo Burns looked out the window and saw the two Marines.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I thought, 'Go away! Get the hell away from here!'" she said. "Then I just started screaming."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Down in the basement, Bob Burns assumed that someone was trying to break in. He grabbed a flashlight and flew up the stairs.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "When I got up there, I saw Major Beck and the (gunnery) sergeant," he said. "I'll never forget Major Beck's profile."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: It was a silhouette their son had warned them about.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "When Kyle left, he sat us down and told us that if he didn't come back, the Marines would come," Jo said. "So when I saw them standing there ..."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck and Scarpino spent hours with the family, telling them the little information they knew, promising they would take care of everything they could.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Over the next few weeks, Beck found a way to bring home two Marines who had enlisted alongside Kyle. He helped organize a memorial service and Kyle's burial at Fort Logan National Cemetery in Denver. He helped the Burnses navigate the piles of paperwork dealing with insurance and benefits.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The whole time, Marines from Buckley watched over Kyle's body.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: That first night, as the two men prepared to leave, Jo Burns gave each a hug. Bob Burns shook their hands.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I don't know why, but even then I felt compassion for them," Bob Burns said. "I've done a lot of reflecting on that first night and that's what comes back: compassion."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I don't know how Major Beck does this," Jo Burns said. "Because nobody wants to see him.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "You know, he feels every one of these like they were his own. He does. I tried to talk to him about that once, but he just put his hand up and turned around to face the wall.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "He had tears in his eyes. And he just said, 'I know.'"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Although Beck had no training as a casualty assistance officer, in a way he had trained for it all of his life.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: His earliest memory begins with a needle.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As a toddler, he learned to hold a syringe to inject his diabetic mother with insulin. His parents had divorced when he was 1. Sometimes, he was the only one there to help.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As he grew up, the family scraped by. Some days he wore Salvation Army clothes to school. Things got harder from there.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When he was 13, Beck and his mother watched his 3-year-old brother die after being hit by a car. Months earlier, young Steve had taught the little boy to play catch.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Before the funeral, Beck stood at the open casket and placed his brother's baseball glove inside.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: It took years for Beck and his mother to recover. She retreated and he rebelled, leaving home early.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Eventually, Beck channeled his anger into books, even planning to go to medical school, where he hoped to find a cure for his mother's diabetes.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: But the stirrings of the Persian Gulf War shook him as he prepared to take his medical school entrance exams. His father had been a Marine and Beck had long thought of joining. He figured this would be the war of his generation and he didn't want to miss it.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: His mother died while he was attending officer training school. When he lost her, he also lost his reason for studying medicine. He never went back.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Though his relationship with his father - a cop and former Drug Enforcement Administration agent - wasn't as close as that with his mother, they eventually reconciled. Then his father was diagnosed with cancer.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "On my last trip out to see him, I took a drive with him and asked him if there was anything I could do," Beck said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "He asked me if I could get a color guard at his funeral. That's all he asked for: a Marine color guard."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I said, 'Dad, that's easy.'

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I didn't get to talk to him again."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: On a winter night, Beck pulled his SUV into Denver International Airport and looked into the sky, staring at all the lights that were not stars.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: A limousine pulled in behind him, followed by an empty hearse.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: It was early December, nine months before he would stand on the tarmac in Reno alongside a 23-year-old widow.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: There is no rule requiring airports to allow a family into a secure area to receive the body of a fallen service member, and some airports around the country have refused, Beck said, shaking his head.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "In my mind, this is the first time that a Marine is back on Colorado soil, and (the family) deserves to be there," Beck said. "If I had my way, they'd know which frickin' light in the sky is him, which plane is bringing him in all the way."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Inside the SUV, his phone rang. He looked at the number and smiled.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Hi, babe," he said. "We're at the airport, getting ready to bring one of our guys home. How are the kids?"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For Beck's wife, Julie, and their three young children, his job has sometimes meant his absence on birthdays and anniversaries. He spent last Thanksgiving at a funeral.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Still, when he wakes up in the middle of the night to an ominous call, Julie wakes with him and remains nearby until he heads off to knock on another door. He talks about her the way the families he cares for talk about him: She's his rock.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Hang in there," he said into the phone. "I'll be home late."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Then another call. Again, he recognized the number: another one of his families.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The contact list on Beck's cell phone is programmed with the numbers of grieving parents and spouses from Rapid City to Reno.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: But he's not the only one, he insists, over and over. He said he takes his cues from his Marines, the men and women who get involved to the point where many of their families say they might as well have been deployed overseas.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "This job is all about sacrifice," Beck said. "We sacrifice our family stability. Many of us sacrifice income. We sacrifice our bodies. We break things. We're hard on ourselves. We break each other. And we're asked to make the ultimate sacrifice."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Outside the car, a Denver police officer's walkie-talkie crackled and he motioned to Beck.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The cortege pulled behind the police escort, heading toward the tarmac.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "There are moments in this experience that energize you, and there are moments that suck you dry," Beck said. "Those moments are short, but they're so defining.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "And you're about to see one of them."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As jet engines roared around him, Beck looked at the plane. The Marines marched to the cargo hold, toward the casket.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "See the people in the windows? They'll sit right there in the plane, watching those Marines," Beck said. "You gotta wonder what's going through their minds, knowing that they're on the plane that brought him home."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Commercial airplanes transport caskets every day - including service members killed in action. For the most part, the passengers have no idea what lies below.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Most people will never see the Transportation Security Administration officials standing on the tarmac with their hands over their hearts as a body is unloaded. They won't see the airport police and firefighters lined up alongside their cars and engines, lights flashing, saluting the hearse on its way out.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Occasionally, a planeload of passengers is briefly exposed to the hard reality outside the cabin.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "They're going to remember being on that plane for the rest of their lives," Beck said, looking back at the passengers. "They're going to remember bringing that Marine home.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Before graduating from boot camp, every Marine masters the blank stare: the focused-but-distant look that glares down from recruiting posters, the one meant to strike fear in enemies, the one intended to convey more than two centuries of tradition.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Marines are taught to hold the stare no matter what. If a fly crawls on their face, or in their ear, they are ordered to remain steady.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: No training could prepare them for the funerals.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: According to protocol - an extension of their sacred "never leave a Marine behind" mandate - a fallen Marine's body must be guarded by another Marine whenever it is accessible by a member of the public.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: During the past year, the 60 active-duty Marines stationed at Buckley have taken turns standing guard over the caskets. Inevitably, they get to know the person inside.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Underneath their formal white caps, or "covers," many of the Buckley Marines keep the funeral brochures of every Marine they have watched over.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Now they're watching over us," said Sgt. Andrea Fitzgerald, as she turned over her cap, revealing a photo tucked inside. "I call them my angels."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: At the visitation, Marines hear the families talk to the body. At the memorial services, they hear the eulogies. During the burials, they see the flag presented to the grieving mother or widow.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Through it all, they try to hold the stare.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "They can stand there for hours," Beck said. "Their feet fall asleep up to their knees. The pain we're feeling drives us. It drives us for the family because the pride is bigger than the pain. But the pain - you gotta eat it, you gotta live with it, you gotta take it home and cry in the dark. What else are you going to do?"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For Sgt. Kevin Thomas, of Aurora, it starts when the Marines first meet the casket at the airport.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "You always hear all these statements like 'freedom isn't free.' You hear the president talking about all these people making sacrifices," he said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "But you never really know until you carry one of them in the casket. When you feel their body weight. When you feel them, that's when you know. That's when you understand."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Thomas said he would rather be in Iraq - or anyplace he doesn't feel so helpless.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Still, he said, he has learned lessons from funeral duty that he knows combat can't teach.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I'll be sitting in front of the computer and I'll see the news: Another service member killed. It's enough to choke me up, tighten my chest. That's another hundred people that are about to be affected," Thomas said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "It's almost enough to wish that you could take his place, so these people wouldn't hurt so much.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "There's no way that doing one of these funerals can't make you a better person. I think everyone in the military should have to do at least one."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Still, it doesn't end at the cemetery.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "People think that after the funeral, we're finished," Beck said. "It's not over. It's not over at all. We have to keep taking care of the families."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: 'He only got halfway through'

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The sound of strapping tape ripped through the living room in Laramie.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Now for the hard part," Jo Burns said, after opening one of the cardboard boxes from Iraq filled with her son's possessions.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Then she corrected herself.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "It's all hard."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: It had been more than a month since Beck's midnight drive to the white house with the biggest numbers on the block. Beck wasn't required to personally deliver the boxes to Laramie. He didn't have to stay with the family for two hours more as they sifted through them, either.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: But actually, Beck said, he had no choice.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I know that Kyle Burns is looking at me, making sure I'm squared away - with his family and with him," he said during the drive to Wyoming. "I know I'm going to have to answer the mail on that one day - not with God, but with Kyle."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Inside the living room, Bob Burns began lifting Ziploc bags from the box, cataloging the contents in a shaky voice.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Here's his wallet," he said, as he looked inside. "A fishing license. A hunting license. A Subway Club card? Good grief."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "They're things that reminded him of home," Jo Burns said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: A few minutes later, she pulled out a list in her son's handwriting and started to cry.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "What is it, Jo?" Bob Burns asked.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "It's everyone he wanted to call. And write."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Well," Bob said, "now we've got a list, don't we, Jo?"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: They found more. A camouflage Bible. A giant clothespin. Pens with their tops chewed up.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Corporal's stripes.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "He already bought them," Bob said. "He only had a couple more tests to take."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
