graf: Kyle's older brother, Kris, pulled out a book, Battlefield Okinawa, and feathered the pages, then placed his finger at a wrinkle on the spine.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Looks like he only got to about here," he said. "He only got halfway through."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Jo Burns never wanted Kyle to be a Marine. When he invited a recruiter over to meet her, she was openly hostile.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I have to be honest," she said later. "I didn't believe all that brotherhood bullshit. I thought it was just a bunch of little boys saying things that boys say.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I never believed it until after he died."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In the midst of it all, they found a little snow globe with a typical Wyoming scene: trees, an elk, a bear and a coyote.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Jo Burns shook it up and watched the flakes fall.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She then grasped Beck's hand.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "He told us several times, 'You won't be alone through this - we'll be here,'" she said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I guess I didn't understand what that meant."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Throngs of raucous, face-painted fanatics filled the Stevens High School gymnasium in Rapid City, S.D., preparing for the biggest basketball game of the season.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As the time for tipoff neared, some of the kids cheered and others stomped their feet on the stands. But when the lights dimmed, the teams didn't take the court.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Good evening, ladies and gentlemen," said a uniformed Marine major, as the gym fell to murmurs, then silence.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Eight Marines from Buckley marched to the front of the gym floor, along with a dozen members of the Stevens High School football team and the family of Lance Cpl. Joe Welke.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "For some of you, this is a surprise," Beck said. "For others, you knew we had something special. For everyone, I promise you, this will be a memorable night."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In the gym rafters hung the retired jerseys of former Stevens High football players who later turned pro. On Feb. 5, the crowd's attention was drawn to a special display case for three more uniforms, all worn by the same man.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Keep Joseph Welke long in your memories, for his sacrifice and that of others should never be forgotten," Beck said. "For if it is, none of us deserve our freedom."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The spotlight swept across the line of football players as they passed the jersey of No. 36 from player to player, across the gym, until it rested with Joe Welke's mother.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Then the light shone on the Marines. Many of them had been the last to carry Welke's body, the last to feel the weight.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: This night, they carried his empty uniforms.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "The Marine dress blue uniform is the only uniform in use today that is comprised of all the colors of the American flag," Beck said to the crowd, as the suit was passed along, through white-gloved hands, until it also rested with Betty Welke.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: A Marine then held up a desert camouflage uniform - one that had arrived in the U.S. only a few days earlier.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "The Marine combat utility uniform has seen duty around the globe in the toughest of environments," Beck said. "Joe's combat uniform is with us tonight and comes directly from the deserts of Iraq."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The Marines passed the uniform along until it reached Beck. He turned, cradling it with the same reverence he showed months earlier at the funeral when he presented Betty Welke with the folded American flag that had covered her son's casket.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The lance corporal's mother buried her face in the uniform. Her sobbing lifted into the silence of the gym.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In the stands, the face paint smeared into tears. Beck whispered in Betty Welke's ear.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I said, 'Do you want to hold that for a little while?' And she said, 'Yes.'

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "She was crying into it pretty good. And for me, that was kind of perfect. Because his combat uniform from Iraq has her tears in it. Her tears are in those threads. Forever."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The day after the ceremony in the gym, the Welke home in Rapid City filled with Marines Joe Welke never knew. Around the country, as people prepared for Super Bowl Sunday, the Marines prepared for a birthday party.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Today he would be 21," said Joe Welke's older brother, Nick. "He'd be back in town now. His battalion just got back."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Twenty-one," he said. "The one you look forward to."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When the Colorado Marines arrived, they were met the way Joe Welke would have welcomed them - with backslaps and beer.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "The Marines were so adamant about coming up here with me on this," Beck said. "They were the ones who carried Joe. That funeral touched them so deeply."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: After the start of the football game, the Marines and Joe Welke's high school buddies headed for the big-screen TV in the basement. Betty Welke remained upstairs, looking through photo albums as Beck hovered nearby.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When they were alone, she pressed an album closed and looked up at the major.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I want to know what's really happening over there," she said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For the next hour, Beck spoke passionately about the scenes he said not enough people see: the Iraqi elections, the small, successful everyday missions, and the positive days he saw ahead for Iraq - turning points he said her son helped make possible.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He then explained how he believes it could take more than a decade until the sacrifices made by the military pay off. The American public, he said, would have to learn to be patient.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She remained quiet, soaking it all in.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "But is it worth it?" she asked him finally. "Was it worth his life?"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He looked her in the eyes.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Betty, with all you've been through, that's not something I can answer for you," Beck said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "That's something for you to decide."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Casualty notification isn't always conducted with the same care.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In May, the parents of an Army private first class were stunned when their son's casket was delivered to them on a forklift in a cargo area of a St. Louis airport where employees on break smoked nearby. They also thought it insensitive that, when informing them of their son's death, the casualty assistance officer literally read from a script.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Others have watched their casualty officers "drop off the radar," or end up in Iraq, with no replacement provided. In some cases, the military has taken months to pay for a funeral or left families alone to navigate the morass of paperwork that follows the death of a loved one.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Recently, the governor of Illinois met with Army officials to voice the concerns of military families in his state. Other cases surfaced in February, during congressional testimony by war widows.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Successful casualty assistance is not the rule, it is quite the exception," one Marine widow told the congressional committee. "This is certainly not the military taking care of its own."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Some branches now offer daylong courses on casualty notification. Next week, the Marine Corps is holding a large symposium in Quantico, Va., where casualty assistance calls officers - including Beck - will convene to share stories and advice.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Many problems could be solved, Beck said, if everyone followed a simple principle:

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "To do this right, to do it properly, you have to look at these women as if they were your mother or your wife, and these men as if they were your father or your brother. And you have to ask, 'What would I want someone to do if it were me?'"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Inside a ballroom at an Aurora hotel in April, Beck adjusted a line of medals on a banquet table, struggling with all they reflected.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "When you think about what these guys did, it's not easy to look at these medals," he said. "What's the trade-off? What's the exchange? How do you say (holding up a medal), 'This is for your son?'"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: At the beginning of the year, Beck realized there were a number of medals due the Marines whose families he watched over. Instead of mailing the medals to them, which often occurs, he decided to hold a formal ceremony to present them to the families personally.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He called the ceremony "Remembering the Brave."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck considered the medals again, feeling their weight.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "It's not a trade, but in the minds of the mothers, I wonder if they think it is a trade, and that they're thinking, 'I don't want this medal. I want my son,'" he said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "The only way I can dispel that is through something like this. By showing them the honor. By honoring their son."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: After the lights dimmed in the ballroom, more than 500 people fell silent.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "You are about to hear the descriptions of individual acts of courage," Beck said. "Listen closely."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Listen. Closely."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For nearly an hour, they heard detailed accounts of rocket-propelled grenade attacks and improvised explosive devices, of ambushes and assaults - each with the same ending.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Slowly, methodically, the Marines brought out the medals and citations and kneeled before a mother or father they had first met on a doorstep. For each family, the Marines also presented a vase of yellow roses, one rose for every year of the Marine's life.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: After it was over, Beck sat back and took another deep breath.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Even some of our Marines say, 'Why are we doing this to the families? Why do you have to keep reminding them?'"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck shook his head.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "This isn't about reminding them - they don't need reminding. These families think about this every day of their lives."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He looked up, addressing every person who hasn't felt what those families have.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "This isn't about reminding them," he said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "This is about reminding you."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: On the tarmac in Reno, the white glove reached into the limousine, but Katherine Cathey couldn't move.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Katherine," Beck said, "it's time."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I'm not ready for this," she said. "I'll never be ready."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Her mother leaned into the car and spoke to her daughter.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Katherine," she said. "Jim would want you to see this."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Katherine looked at her mother, then at Beck, and took his hand. After climbing from the car, she steadied herself, her arm intertwined with Beck's. Then she looked toward the plane.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: At the sight of the flag-draped casket, Katherine let loose a shrill, full-body wail that gave way to moans of distilled, contagious grief.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "NO! NO! Noooooo! Not him! Noooooo!"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She screamed as the casket moved slowly down the conveyor belt. She screamed until she nearly collapsed, clutching Beck around the neck, her legs almost giving way.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: At the base of the luggage ramp, the screams hit the pallbearers.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Of all the Marines they had met or trained with, Jim Cathey was the one they considered invincible, built with steel-cable arms and endless endurance - a kid who had made sergeant at 19 and seemed destined to leapfrog through the ranks.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Most of the Marines who would serve as pallbearers had first met "Cat" at the University of Colorado, while enrolled in an elite scholarship program for enlisted infantrymen taking the difficult path to becoming officers. They partied with him, occasionally got into trouble with him, then watched him graduate with honors in anthropology and history in only three years.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When they lifted his casket, they struggled visibly with the weight, their eyes filling with tears as they shuffled to the white hearse.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: After they placed the flag-drapped coffin inside, Katherine fell onto one corner, pressing her face into the blue field of stars.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck put a hand on her back as she held the casket tight. By then, he was close enough to her to know that she wouldn't let go. He kept his hand on her back until he found a solution.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Would you like to ride with him?" he finally asked. She looked up, dazed, and replied with a sniffling nod. She took his hand again as he guided her to the front seat of the hearse, where the surprised funeral directors quickly moved papers to make room for her.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Jim Cathey's mother, father and sister took their own time with the casket, caressing the flag, remembering.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: His mother, Caroline, thought of the baby who used to reach out to her from the crib. His father, Jeff, saw the boy he watched grow into a man on long hunting trips through the barren landscape nearby.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: His sister, Joyce, saw the kid who became her protector. The day after she learned of his death, she had his face tattooed on the back of her neck, so "he will always be watching my back."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Last of all, the young Marine who had escorted his friend home walked up to the casket and came to attention.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Only a few months before, Gavin Conley had stood before his best friend at the formal commissioning ceremony in Boulder, where Cathey received his brass lieutenant's bars.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For Cathey, it was one of the most important days of his life, and Conley knew the best way to share his pride.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: At the end of the ceremony, Conley walked up to the new lieutenant and snapped his arm to his brow, giving the new officer his first salute.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In front of the casket on the tarmac, Conley again brought his hand to his face, this time in one slow, sweeping movement. As the family wept, his hand fell to his side.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: His job as escort was officially over.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Before climbing into the hearse with Katherine, Beck took one last look at the scene, fixing on the plane. By then, the passengers had moved on, leaving the Marines and the family alone with the casket - and everything that was about to follow.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Five days before Jim Cathey returned home, two uniformed men sat in a government SUV, several blocks from Katherine Cathey's home in Brighton, and bowed their heads.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck and Navy chaplain Jim Chapman closed their eyes in prayer as the chaplain asked for "words that will bring the family peace."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: This time, Beck was dressed in a drab green uniform in accordance with a controversial new mandate from the top brass not to wear dress blue uniforms to notifications, based on concerns that the distinctive blues had become too associated with tragedy.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: It was a warm, blue-sky Sunday afternoon. Nearby, a neighbor mowed his lawn.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When the knock came, Katherine Cathey was taking a nap. Her stepfather saw the Marines first and opened the door.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "We're here for Katherine," Beck said quietly.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Oh, no," Vic Leonard said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: At first, Katherine's mother thought it was someone trying to sell something. Then she saw her husband walking backward and the two men in uniform.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Oh, no," she said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "She's pregnant!"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Leonard suggested to his wife that she wake up Katherine. Vicki Leonard shook her head. She couldn't speak.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When her stepfather opened the door to her bedroom, Katherine could hear her mother crying. She thought something had happened to someone in her mother's family. She had never heard her mother cry like that.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "What's going on?" Katherine asked her stepfather.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "It's not good," he told her. "Come with me."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Her own screams began as soon as she saw the uniforms.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Katherine ran to the back of the living room and collapsed on the floor, holding her stomach, thinking of the man who would never see their baby. Finally she stood, but still couldn't speak.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As Beck and the chaplain remained on their feet, she glared at them. She ran to the back of the house and drew a hot bath. For the next hour, she sat in the tub, dissolving.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Shortly after their arrival, Beck had ducked back outside to make a quick phone call.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Inside a government SUV in Reno, just around the corner from the home where Jim Cathey grew up, another phone rang.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: 'Tell me it's not my son'

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The toolbox was a mess.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Jim Cathey's mother stood in the garage, trying to find the right wrench to fix a sprinkler head in her front yard.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: What a frustrating morning, she thought.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As she prepared to leave for the hardware store, the family dog started to howl - a howl like she had never heard before. She put the dog in the house and drove off.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When the silver SUV pulled up, the Marines inside assumed someone was home. A lawn mower sat outside and it looked as if someone was doing yardwork.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: No one answered the door.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: A neighbor drove up, looked at them and pulled into an adjacent driveway. The Marines started to get nervous. The neighbor looked out a window at them. Their orders were to remain parked at the house until the parents returned.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When Caroline Cathey drove up, she saw the strange government vehicle, then fixed her eyes on the man in the driver's seat.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "She saw me; she pulled in," Capt. Winston Tierney said. "And I hate this, but I think she might have suspected when she saw me. She got out of her vehicle and I told my guys, 'Time to go.'"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Caroline Cathey's hands went to her face.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "As I made my way up the driveway, we didn't say anything," Tierney said. "I wanted to wait until I was there. She looked at me and it looked like she was going to collapse. I supported her and tried to give her a hug."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He recounted the conversation from there:

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Please don't let it be," she said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I'm sorry to have to be here today. Can we go inside and sit down? There are some things we need to confirm."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Please tell me it's not Jimmy, please tell me it's not my son."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The Marines stayed with the Catheys for the next 10 hours. With Caroline's help, they contacted Jim Cathey's 9-year-old daughter, Casey, who was born while he was still in high school. Casey, along with Katherine, had pinned the lieutenant's bars on her father only a few months before.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Casey's mother and stepfather drove the little girl from Carson City, Nev., to Reno, where another one of the Marines - an operations chief who had children of his own - told her that her daddy had been hurt in the war and wouldn't be able to come back. He asked her if she understood. She answered with tears.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The Marines held fast until Jim Cathey's father, Jeff, returned from a trip he had taken to his son's favorite hunting grounds, where he was scouting for game birds.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When it was all over, the Marines climbed back into the silver SUV. A staff sergeant looked at Tierney.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Sir," he said. "Please don't take me on another one of these."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: From the moment his body departed Iraq, the sturdy, heavyweight cotton flag remained nearby, following him from the desert to Dover Air Force Base, Del., where a mortuary affairs team received his body.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: According to the Department of Defense, Cathey was killed in Al Karmah, Iraq, on Aug. 21. Members of his unit later told family members that Cathey was leading the search of an abandoned building when a booby-trapped door exploded. The explosion was so fierce it blew off an arm and leg of the Marine directly behind Cathey. That man, now in recovery, credits his lieutenant with saving his life.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Once Cathey's remains arrived at Dover, the mortuary affairs team began the delicate task of readying his body for the final trip home. When possible, military morticians prepare a body for viewing by the family. In Cathey's case, that wasn't an option.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Specialists at Dover wrapped his body in a white shroud and covered it with a satin body-length pillow and his dress blue uniform before closing the casket lid and securing the flag nearby.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: When the plane landed in Reno, the same flag was draped over the casket, which was loaded into the hearse to continue its journey to the funeral home.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: After all the noise at the airport - the screaming, the crying, the whining of jet engines - inside the funeral home each footstep echoed.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The pallbearers carried their friend's body to the front of an enormous empty room, then faded into the background. Beck posted himself at the head of the casket, his face frozen in the Marine stare.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: His eyes trained forward, he still saw everything.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Inside the room, Cathey's mother, Caroline, bent down to hug Katherine. They squeezed each other for a long time.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "You give me strength," the young widow said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Other family members sat on couches and some sat on the floor - hugging, holding hands, their eyes locked on the casket, for nearly half an hour.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Finally, Beck broke the silence.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I'm sorry," he said, excusing the family from the room. "There are some things I need to do."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck motioned to the pallbearers and began the instructions that would hold for the next three days.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Although the Marines are required to stand watch over a comrade's body, once the casket is safely inside a locked mortuary or church, they usually leave at night and return when the mortuary reopens.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: This time, however, the watch would not end.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Katherine and Caroline have both expressed concerns about Jim being left alone," Beck told the Marines. "So we won't leave him alone."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He then explained how to guard the casket. They all had posted watch before. They had stood at attention for hours as part of basic training, but nothing like this.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: They were to take shifts of about an hour at a time, Beck instructed, standing watch 24 hours a day. When changing the guard, they were to salute Cathey's casket first, then relieve the other Marine the same way.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He showed them the slow salute - the one they aren't taught in basic training - three seconds up, hold for three seconds and three seconds down.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "A salute to your fallen comrade should take time," he said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For Beck, that salute embodies more than the movement itself. Earlier in the day, someone had asked him about the arrival of "the body." He held up his hand with a firm correction.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "'The body' has a name." he said. "His name is Jim."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In the room, he walked up to the casket and paused.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Now, this is important, too," he said. "If a family member wants you to break, you can break. They may want to hug you or kiss you. That's OK. Hug them. If someone wants to shake your hand, shake their hand. I'll take my glove off when I shake their hand - you don't have to, it's up to you. But then go back to position.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Everyone understand?"

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Yes, sir," they responded. "Roger that."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "This is a serious business," he said. "Jim is watching you."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As the other Marines filed into the hallway, closing the door behind them, Beck walked back to the casket. For the first time, he and Jim Cathey were alone.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: It was time for the final inspection.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck walked up to the casket and lifted the flag back, tucking it into neat pleats and leaving just enough room to open the heavy wooden lid. He walked around the flag several times, making sure each stripe lined up straight, smoothing the thick stitching with his soft white gloves.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Then he lifted the lid.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For the past five days, Beck had spent hours looking at pictures of Jim Cathey, listening to the family's stories, dabbing their tears. When he looked inside, they were no longer strangers.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: For the next 10 minutes, Beck leaned over the open casket, checking the empty uniform that lay atop the tightly-shrouded body, making sure every ribbon and medal was in place. Occasionally, he pulled off a piece of lint or a stray thread and flicked it away.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Although casualty assistance officers receive an advisory from military morticians about whether a body is "viewable," some families insist on looking. The casualty assistance officer is often the one to make last-minute recommendations, since by then he knows the family and - after the final inspection - knows exactly what the family will see.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Whether or not the family decides on a viewing, Beck said, the procedure is no less meticulous.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In Cathey's case, the family decided not to look under the shroud. But Katherine wanted a few minutes alone with the open casket, to give her husband a few of the things they had shared - and one he never got to see.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck ran his hand alongside the shroud, taking one last look at the uniform.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He closed the lid and turned toward the door.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: 'I'm always kissing you, baby'

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Katherine draped her body over the smooth wood, pressing her pregnant belly to the casket, as close to a hug as she could get.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck placed a hand on her back.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Tell me when you're ready," he said. "Take your time."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: He stepped back.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The air conditioner clicked on, filling the room with a low hum. Ten minutes passed. It clicked off, leaving the room to her soft moans.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She moved only to adjust her feet, continuing to rub her belly against the wood. She closed her eyes and whispered something.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Then she looked up at Beck.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "OK," she said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As she stood at his arm, he opened the casket.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She didn't cry. She didn't speak. He gave her a few seconds, then took her hand and brought it to the middle of the empty uniform. He held her hand there and pressed down.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "He's here," he told her. "Feel right here."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She held her hand on the spot, pressing the uniform into the shrouded body beneath. She dragged her hand the length of all that was there.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Beck walked back to get the personal belongings Katherine had brought with her from Colorado.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Where do you want to start?" he asked.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "With the picture of us kissing," she said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She placed the picture at the top of the casket, above the neck of the uniform. She bent down and pressed her lips to it.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I'm always kissing you, baby," she whispered.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She took several other photos of their lives together and placed them around the uniform. She gently added a bottle of her perfume, then picked up the dried, fragile flowers of her wedding bouquet.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Before Jim Cathey had left for officer training, they were married by a justice of the peace in Denver, planning a big wedding on his return from Iraq. Her wedding dress still hangs in her closet at home, unworn.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She placed the flowers alongside the uniform, then turned again to the major.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "The ultrasound," she said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: The fuzzy image was taken two days after her husband's death. Katherine had scheduled the appointment for a day when Jim was supposed to call, so they could both learn the baby's gender together. He had a feeling it was a boy, he had told her. If it was, she suggested they name the child after him.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She stood cradling the ultrasound, then moved forward and placed it on the pillow at the head of the casket. She stood there, watching for several minutes, then removed it.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She walked the length of the casket, then stepped back, still holding the only image of James J. Cathey Jr.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She leaned in and placed it over her husband's heart.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: In the house where Jim Cathey grew up, a tattered stuffed animal still peers from a heavy wooden chest.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "This is Floppy Floyd," his mother said. "The last time he was here he said he wanted to take Floyd back, for the baby."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She held the stuffed animal to her face. Elsewhere in the house, she still has all of Jim's baby teeth and every award he ever won.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: On his bookshelf, encyclopedias are shelved near the Louis L'Amour novels she used to read to him, next to a collection of Thucydides' writings.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "These are the things that made him who he is today," she said, then caught herself in present tense.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Who he was today," she corrected herself softly.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Later, in the kitchen, she paused at a note that has hung on the refrigerator since the day Jim left home.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "See you all later. You know I love you and will be thinking about you every minute of every day. I miss you. Don't worry about me too much. I'll be back May 8th as a Marine! Write as much as you can. I will look forward to the letters. With all my love, J.C."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: She looked away from the note and at the things that made Jim Cathey who he was.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Maybe now I know why my son was always in a hurry," she said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Jeff Cathey almost didn't make it to his son's funeral. From the moment he saw the Marines at the door, he was thinking of his own.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: Jeff, who suffers from clinical depression, spiraled deeper the day the Marines came to the house, to the point where his family worried more about him than their own grief. His wife hid all of his guns. Even so, the day after he found out about his son's death, he insisted on going back to the hunting grounds where he and Jim had spent their best times together.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Before he left, I made him swear on his son's life that he would come back to me," Caroline said.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I thought about doing it. Ending it," Jeff said, breaking into tears. "I really did. I want to be with him."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: As he sat on the couch, he tried to compose himself.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "Good thoughts," he told himself. "Good thoughts."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: And then found plenty.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "One of my finest memories was when we were hunting and he came back to the car, overturned a pail, sat down and started doing his homework.

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "I wish I had a picture of that."

author: Jim Sheeler
headline: Final Salute
graf: "You do," his wife said, rubbing his back, pointing to his head. "Right up here."

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Ten seconds. Count it: One. Two. Three. Four. Five. Six. Seven. Eight. Nine. Ten. Ten seconds was roughly how long it lasted. Nobody had a stopwatch, nothing can be proven definitively, but that's the consensus. The tornado that swooped through Utica at 6:09 p.m. April 20 took some 10 seconds to do what it did. Ten seconds is barely a flicker. It's a long, deep breath. It's no time at all. It's an eternity.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: If the sky could hold a grudge, it would look the way the sky looked over northern Illinois that day. Low, gray clouds stretched to the edges in a thin veneer of menace. Rain came and went, came and went, came and went.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: The technical name for what gathered up there was stratiform cloud cover, but Albert Pietrycha had a better way to describe it: "murk." It was a Gothic-sounding word for a Gothic-looking sky. A sky that, in its own oblique way, was sending a message.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Pietrycha is a meteorologist in the Chicago forecast office of the National Weather Service, a tidy, buttoned-down building in Romeoville, about 25 miles southwest of Chicago. It's a setting that seems a bit too ordinary for its role, too bland for the place where the first act of a tragedy already was being recorded. Where the sky's bad intentions were just becoming visible, simmering in the low-slung clouds.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Where a short distance away, disparate elements--air, water and old sandstone blocks--soon would slam into each other like cars in a freeway pileup, ending eight lives and changing other lives forever.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: The survivors would henceforth be haunted by the oldest, most vexing question of all: whether there is a destiny that shapes our fates or whether it is simply a matter of chance, of luck, of the way the wind blows.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: It was a busy day for Pietrycha and his colleagues. The classic ingredients for a tornado--warm air to the south, cooler air north and a hint of wind shear--had seemed imminent most of the morning. Spring and early summer are boom times for tornadoes, the most violent storms on Earth.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: What bothered Pietrycha was a warm front that loitered ominously across southern Illinois. If the front's moist, humid air moved north too quickly in the daylight hours, clashing with cooler air, the instability could create thunderstorms liable to split off into tornadoes.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: But by early afternoon, it seemed that maybe, just maybe, northern Illinois would escape. If the front waited until after sunset to arrive, its impact would be negligible because the air near the ground--with no sunshine to warm it--would cool off. Nope, a relieved Pietrycha said to himself. Probably not today.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: It was only a hunch. Meteorologists know a lot about tornadoes, but with all they know, they still can't say why some thunderstorms generate tornadoes and some don't. Or why tornadoes, once unleashed, do what they do and go where they go.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: That's why forecasting is as much art as science. Too many warnings not followed by actual tornadoes make people skeptical and careless. Too many warnings can be as dangerous as too few. And while meteorologists can spot an approaching hurricane days in advance, the average warning time for a tornado is 11 minutes.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: What she was thinking was, Gotta beat that rain.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Frowning up at a sky as flat and gray as a cookie sheet, Shelba Bimm, 65, figured she just might be able to outrun the next downpour. Worth a try, anyway.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Bimm was standing in the driveway of her house at 238 W. Church St. in Utica, population 977, just outside Starved Rock State Park.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: It was precisely 5:15 p.m. She had her schedule figured down to the minute. Busy people do that. But this ornery rain--will it or won't it, and if it starts up again, how long will it last?--was irksome.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: She was due in Oglesby at 6 p.m. for the weekly class she was taking for her certification as an EMT Intermediate, the next level up from EMT, a rank Bimm had held since 1980, answering the frequent summons from the Utica volunteer fire department. Folks in town were accustomed to the sight of the white-haired Bimm in the driver's seat of her black Honda CRV, yanking on the wheel with one hand and gripping her dispatch radio with the other.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Shelba Bimm had been a 1st-grade teacher for 42 years. She was retired now--if that's what you want to call it, even though she was at least as busy these days as she'd ever been when running a classroom, what with her EMT work and the dollhouse business she operated out of the front room of her home. And now she and Dave Edgcomb, Utica's fire chief, were taking classes to upgrade their credentials.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Oglesby is a 15-minute drive from Utica, so normally Bimm didn't hit the road until 5:30 p.m. But then again, she thought, just look at that sky.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: If she left now, she might be able to get there and dash from the parking lot at Illinois Valley Community College and into class without getting soaked. It's gonna be, she thought, one hell of a storm.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: So she scooted into her car--the one with the can't-miss-it license plate BIMM 2--and took off, backing out of her driveway and heading east on Church Street.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: At the four-way stop a few yards from her house she turned south on Mill Street. Near the corner was a bar called Milestone. A block later, at the corner of Mill and Canal Street, she passed Duffy's Tavern.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Bimm turned west on Illinois Highway 71 and then headed on into Oglesby, pulling into the campus parking lot at 5:30 p.m. The western sky was getting blacker and blacker, as if something had been spilled on the other side of it and was seeping through.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: All told, it took her less than a minute to cross Utica. Had she happened to lift her pale blue eyes to the rear view mirror as she left the city limits, she would have seen, poised there like a tableau in a snow globe just before it's shaken up, her last intact view of the little town she loved.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Pietrycha and his colleagues work in a big square room with a central ring of linked desks and a computer monitor perched on just about every flat surface.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Across Pietrycha's work station, six computer screens glowed with radar information that told him, through tiny pixels of perky green and hot red and bold yellow, about hail and rain, about wind rotation and velocity.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: To check the screens, Pietrycha, a slender man with short sandy hair and the preoccupied air of someone who's always working out a math problem in his head, quickly rolled his chair back and forth, back and forth, screen to screen to screen, taking frequent swigs from a Coke can.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: As 4 p.m. approached, the end of his shift, the warm front was still dawdling in southern Illinois. Looking good. So Pietrycha got ready to go. He lives in Oswego, some 13 miles northwest of Romeoville.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: To Mark Ratzer, a fellow meteorologist with a neat blond crew cut who was in charge of the office that day, Pietrycha said, "Hey, if things get out of hand, call me."

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: The specials at Duffy's Tavern that night, according to the green felt-tip lettering on the white board above the bar, were: "All You Can Eat Spaghetti w/garlic breadsticks, $4.99" and "Cajun NY Strip w/onions and peppers and potato salad, $16.99" and "2 stuffed walleye, $13.99." The soup was cheesy broccoli.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Lisle Elsbury, 56, had bought Duffy's a year ago. Buying it meant leaving behind the life he knew as a heating and air conditioning repairman in Lyons, and slapping down all his chips right here in Utica.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Elsbury was a compact man with a nervous energy that seemed to oscillate just beneath his skin. His small gray mustache dipped at either end, curling around his upper lip like a parenthesis.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: He liked to stand behind the long bar, its rich brown wood so ancient and polished by innumerable elbows that it looked sumptuous, almost liquid. It shimmered in the light.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: If he'd glanced out the big front window just then, he might have seen Bimm's black Honda going south on Mill as she headed to class. But Elsbury was too busy to be gazing out windows. When you owned a bar and grill, there was always something to do. Always a ledger to balance, a glass to rinse, a burger to turn.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: After a rocky start--Utica is a tough town to break into, with friendships stretching back decades--Elsbury was feeling pretty good. Things were looking up, even though there were four other taverns in town--Skoog's Pub, Joy & Ed's, Canal Port and Milestone--all within a stone's throw.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Duffy's and Milestone were the new kids on the block. Not literally--the buildings were each more than a century old, two-story structures that anchored either end of Utica's roughly one-block business district. The proprietors, not the properties, were new. Elsbury and his wife, Pat, had bought Duffy's; Larry Ventrice and his wife, Marian, were running Milestone.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: They were alike in a lot of ways, the Elsburys and the Ventrices. They were two couples trying to make a go of it in a new business in a new town. Money was tight. Hours were long. You worked as hard as you could work, and you still weren't sure sometimes if you were going to survive.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: At this time of day, though, with the sun going down and the room filling up, Elsbury was reminded of the reasons he loved running a bar. Toughest work he'd ever done, but Lord, he just loved the feel of the place. The laughter. The talk. The scrape of chair legs on the red-painted plywood floor. A kind of benign, peppy chaos.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Two TV sets were angled on small platforms extending from the wall at both ends of the bar, their screens busy with maps sprouting wavy lines and harsh-looking arrows. Bartender Chris Rochelle, 23, a skinny, good-looking kid with spiky black hair, had changed both sets from ESPN to the Weather Channel.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: The sky, he told anybody who asked, just didn't look right to him. Didn't look right at all.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: By the time Pietrycha walked back into the weather service office at about 5:45 p.m., everything had changed. It was as if an orchestra conductor, with a simple flick of the baton, had abruptly altered the room's tempo. What had been casual was suddenly intense. Phones rang, people scurried back and forth, frowning meteorologists hunched over computer screens.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: That lackadaisical warm front suddenly had come to life, moving north much faster than any of the forecasters thought it would, initiating the fatal tangle of warm and cold air. Tornadoes darted across the Midwest, making jailbreaks from the thunderstorms.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: At 5:32 p.m., Pietrycha's colleague, radar operator Rich Brumer, had issued a tornado warning for north-central Illinois. Typically, a watch--which alerts people to be on their guard--precedes a warning, but the warm front had risen so fast that Brumer went straight to the warning.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Now it was a matter of what meteorologists call interrogating the storm: keeping an eye on the screens as the data pours in, supplied by the Doppler radar tower that rises just behind the Romeoville office. In one sense, Pietrycha and his colleagues are immensely powerful as they compile fact after fact after fact about the atmosphere. They know just about everything there is to know about the air, the clouds, the wind, the rain.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: But in another sense, they're utterly helpless. They don't know the "ground truth": the meteorological term for what's actually happening to real people, people who don't just record and measure the weather but must live through it.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: That night, the weather service would tally 53 tornadoes in the Midwest. Fourteen whipsawed across north-central and northeastern Illinois.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: One of those--born about 2 miles southwest of Granville and cutting a 15 1/2-mile, 200-yard-wide notch from Granville to Utica--seemed to make a beeline for a venerable two-story tavern. It would arrive at 6:09 p.m.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: At 5:55 p.m. the phone rang in Beverly Wood's mobile home in Utica. It was her daughter, Dena Mallie, a vivacious 44-year-old who lives in Peru, just west of Utica.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: "We're having really bad hail," Mallie told her mother.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Wood, 67, was in the middle of dinner with Wayne Ball, 63, whom she'd dated for years and who lived in a mobile home right across the road, and Helen Studebaker Mahnke, 81, another friend who lived in the same trailer park just east of the downtown business district.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Wood and Ball were an easy, comfortable couple, with an affection that ran deep and true. When Ball's hands were severely frostbitten during his work with the railroad several years ago, and had to be bandaged and immobile for many months, it was Wood who fed him, who lit and held his cigarettes for him.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Wood had heated up a frozen pizza and mixed a few drinks. Mallie could hear music in the background; the three old friends had settled in for the evening. But Wood deeply feared storms.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: "We're going to scoot," she told Mallie. "We're going uptown."

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Trailers, as everybody knew, were notoriously vulnerable in bad weather. It made sense for Wood, Mahnke and Ball to hunker down in one of the Utica taverns, one of those big, reliable old buildings that could shrug off a storm like it had been shrugging them off for decades.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Leaving the pizza--minus the three slices they'd just eaten--on the table with the drinks, because they'd be back in a jiffy, Wood, Mahnke and Ball hurried outside and climbed into Wood's car, a taupe Buick Century

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: It couldn't have taken Wood more than a minute to drive them to the bar, even pausing for the single stop sign on East Church, even heeding the posted speed limit of 20 m.p.h.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: She parked across the street, and they quickly walked in through Milestone's double doors. Wood was in such a hurry she didn't lock the car; for her, an unheard-of lapse. It was just after 6 p.m.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Relief. They were, they thought, safe now.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: For several minutes before the three arrived, Milestone's lights flickered.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Larry Ventrice, 49, was getting irritated. On or off, he didn't care. Just wished they'd make up their mind, on or off, on or off. It climbed a person's nerves, real quick.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: He was a restless, impatient man, a man with a finger-snap temper but a good heart. He hailed from Bridgeport, a South Side Chicago neighborhood, and was proud of it, and he was proud as well of what he'd done with the tavern: filled it with funky antiques such as a roulette wheel and fake "WANTED" posters that gave the place a toe-tapping, down-home feel. The atmosphere started at the threshold, where a couple of horseshoes served as door pulls, and continued on around to the building's southern exterior, where a big, colorful mural, a rollicking pioneer scene with wagon trains and sod-busters, had been painted on the sandstone blocks.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Larry Ventrice knew about the bad weather heading their way. On the big TV set over the bar he'd heard the stations yakking about tornadoes and seeking shelter and all the rest of it, but he wasn't worried. Why should he be? Milestone, with its thick sandstone walls, flat concrete roof and slate foundation, was as solid as a vault. It was 117 years old, but just as hard times strengthened a person's character, surely rough weather over the years toughened up a building, didn't it? Showed its true mettle. Milestone was a survivor. You'd bet your life on it.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Larry knew just about everybody who was there that night, and they knew him. His cousin Jim Ventrice, 70, was sitting at a table finishing up a bowl of chicken noodle soup while waiting for his second course, a pork chop sandwich he'd ordered from Marian Ventrice, 50, Larry's wife.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Everybody called Jim Ventrice "Cousin Junior" or just Junior.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Junior, a slight man who wore his shirt tucked in and his hair combed neatly back from his forehead, had gotten to Milestone at about 5:40 p.m. that night. He stopped in at least once a day because he liked the bar's cozy, nobody's-a-stranger ambience.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: He'd taken a seat, spotted Jay Vezain at the bar and called out, "Hey, Jay, how're you?"

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Vezain, 47, who worked at the Utica grain elevator just south of Duffy's, was nursing a bottle of beer. "I'm OK, Junior, how're you?"

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: He had a good sense of humor, Vezain did, and the kind of smile to go with it: quick, mischievous-looking. A lot of folks saved their best jokes for Vezain, just to see that smile.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Over in the corner, Carol Schultheis, 40--Wayne Ball's daughter--was playing the video poker game, shoving in coins and waiting for luck, and taking occasional drags on a Marlboro Light. She'd been diagnosed with multiple sclerosis a few years ago, but so far it hadn't slowed her down; she was a day-shift cook at Joy & Ed's, and everybody in Utica knew her and she knew everybody right back, and if you passed her on the street you'd get a smile and a wave and maybe a naughty joke or two.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Rich Little, 37, a truck driver from nearby Troy Grove, was sitting at the bar, drinking a bottle of Bud Light. He was supposed to meet his girlfriend here at 6:30 p.m.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Back in the kitchen, Debbie Miller, 44, pushed a pork chop around on the grill for Junior's sandwich.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: The lights flickered again. The door opened, and Wood, Mahnke and Ball came in.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Just after that, Debbie Miller's family spilled in through the back door, a pinwheeling mass of kids that must have quickly overwhelmed the small hallway and kitchen, a living scribble of elbows and long legs and sneakers and stick-thin arms, talking and pushing.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: There was Debbie's husband, Mike, 49, lanky and bushy-haired; sons Mike Jr., 18, Gregg, 14, and Christopher, 8; and daughters Ashley, 16, and Jennifer, 12, along with Gregg's best friend Jarad Stillwell, 13.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Mike Miller's lean, lined, mournful face seemed to carry all the family's woes in its crevices. They'd had a lot of hard luck over the years. Money was tight, and Mike's salary from the Illinois Central Railroad never seemed quite able to stretch from one payday to the next, not with all those skinny tow-headed kids to take care of. Debbie Miller had signed on as a cook at Milestone about a year and a half ago, and Ashley and Mike Jr. sometimes came along, too, to wait tables or sweep up, netting a few bucks from Larry.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: So when Mike Miller, back in the family's little blue house a half-mile south on Washington Street, had gotten spooked by those increasingly agitated TV weather reports, he thought of Milestone. Milestone was a second home. And Milestone, he figured, would be safer. It was big and thick-walled and had a stone-floored basement that was reassuring just to think about.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Milestone, anybody would tell you, was as sturdy as a preacher's promise.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Mike had just pulled a frozen pizza out of the oven for the kids' dinner, but to heck with it: They could eat when they got back home in a few minutes, after the storm passed.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: So Mike ran down the crumbling steps with his children right behind him, and everybody scrambled into the family's Ford LTD.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: By the time he and the kids got to the bar--two minutes later, tops--Debbie Miller was shutting down the grill, just like Larry had told her to.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: "Everybody in the basement," Marian Ventrice said. "Kids first. Get the kids." She was a nervous, fretful, excitable woman, and you could hear the anxiety spiking in her voice.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: The basement door was toward the front of the bar, under the stairs leading to the second floor. It was an old-fashioned cellar door, flush with the wooden floor, and you pulled up on a metal handle then flipped the door over.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Jarad and Gregg trooped down the wooden stairs, followed by Jennifer, Christopher, Ashley and Mike Jr., and then the adults. They moved quickly, efficiently, but without panic, because they were heading to safety; the basement was a haven, the basement was exactly where you'd want to be at that moment. Thick stone floor, low ceiling. Like a cave.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: "Stick together, everybody stick together," Marian said, and she and Larry went to the center of the basement. So did the older people--Wood, Ball and Mahnke--and the Miller family piled up against the north wall, just beyond the bottom of the stairs. Gregg and Jarad headed to the south wall, next to the walk-in cooler.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Everybody was still talking, still speculating about the storm, and Mahnke asked Ashley and Jennifer their names. Marian was agitated, jittery, but everybody else was relaxed and casual, so casual, in fact, that Junior and Little had brought their beers with them. They set them on top of the chest-high freezer against which they stood, waiting for somebody to tell them it was OK to go back upstairs. No big deal.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: At 5:58 p.m., Dena Mallie saw it from her driveway in Peru.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: As it blossomed darkly, a huge batwing erasing the sky around it, a Utica contractor named Buck Bierbom saw it from his back yard.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Rona Burrows saw it. She leaned out the front door at Mill Street Market, where she worked as a cashier, and looked up at the sky.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Lisle Elsbury saw it from the alley behind Duffy's.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: It was a great black mass, a swirling coil some 200 yards wide at the ground--it was wider in the sky--heading northeast at about 30 m.p.h. They looked up and saw it but they thought: No. Couldn't be. Could it?

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: There was a wild beauty to it, a fiercely knotted loveliness that was like nothing they'd ever seen. They could see debris swirling in it, pulled in and out and sucked up and around, frenzied sticks of wood, trees, dirt, other things, everything.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: The ones who watched it come, watched it fill more and more of the blue-green sky like the canvas of a finicky painter who decides to slather the whole thing in black and start over, felt almost hypnotized at first, rooted to the earth but looking up, up, up. "Awesome" is the word that came instantly to Mallie. And not the way teenagers meant it. Awesome as in something that fills you up with awe.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Steve Maltas, 23, a Utica volunteer firefighter with a trim goatee and a distinct aversion to small talk, was at the car wash in Utica's south end. He heard the report from the LaSalle Fire Department on his dispatch radio: A tornado was bearing down on them.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Maltas gunned his pickup toward the fire station, just up on Mill across from Milestone. He knew where the switch was to activate the tornado siren, the mechanical wail that would give his friends and neighbors a fighting chance.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: He braked in front of the yellow-brick firehouse, cut the engine, raced inside and ran smack into a dilemma: He had no authority. Only the chief was supposed to give the OK to sound the warning. Another firefighter, quiet, blond Shane Burrows, 23--Rona Burrows' son--was there too. He had tried to reach Edgcomb, but the chief's cell phone was turned off--a requirement for the EMT class.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: The two men had seconds to decide and what they decided was:

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Screw the rules.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Flip the switch. A moment later they were joined in the firehouse by Steve Maltas' mother, Gloria, who'd hustled there when she heard about the storm. She, too, worked at the firehouse in her spare time.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: But even with the siren, the townspeople weren't paying attention. When Gloria Maltas looked outside, she saw them standing in the street, watching the sky. Maybe they thought the siren was just a precaution, or maybe they were trusting old Utican wisdom: A tornado won't go in a valley. A tornado won't cross water. Both were false.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: So Gloria, ordinarily a shy, reticent woman who deeply disliked anything that could be remotely construed as making a spectacle of herself, who usually spoke in a soft, whispery voice that made listeners lean in a little to catch her words, did something wholly uncharacteristic: She directed Steve to one side of Mill Street and she took the other, and they began running and yelling at people who stood in the doorways, telling them to get inside, take cover, for God's sake go back in.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Gloria kept running. She ran faster than she'd ever run before, and she didn't realize how fast she was running. A day or so later, her legs ached and she couldn't figure out why, and then she remembered the running, running up and down Mill Street, screaming at people who must've wondered what on earth had gotten into sweet little Gloria Maltas.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Steve Maltas made it back to the fire station, where his last warning was issued to a few folks who stood in the doorway of the bar across the street. "Get in! Get back in!" he hollered, and he saw that one of them was Jay Vezain, who did as he was told, and then the others who'd been standing behind Vezain went back in too.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Because the fire station didn't have a basement, Maltas and Burrows and the other firefighters who had gathered there headed for the boiler room. They heaved the door shut behind them, and then they waited, having done all they could do, for whatever the next flurry of seconds would bring.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Gloria Maltas, whose last warning was to the people standing outside Duffy's, wasn't going to make it back to the fire station. It was only a block away, and she had started back, thinking she could do it, but then she glanced over her shoulder and Oh my God saw the tornado gaining on her, spreading out behind her.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: She was running toward the station, running and running, but there wasn't time, there wasn't time. The big black triangle was rising right behind her, capturing more and more of the sky.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: At Mill Street Market, the tiny grocery store in the middle of the block, Gloria halted at the glass door--the one with the "We appreciate our customers" sign--and pounded on it. Closed, locked. Nobody stirred inside. Gloria had done her job too well. They were all in the back, she guessed, having fled into the big walk-in freezer.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: Still Gloria pounded and hollered, because there was nothing else to do, no other option. She had to get inside somewhere, anywhere, and then she saw Rona Burrows running toward the door, jiggling the key in the lock, twisting it, that lock was always stubborn.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: "Hurry up!" cried Burrows, pulling her inside. "If I have to see you flying through the air, I'll kill you!" she added, half-laughing, half-sobbing, and then they got to the back of the store, past the meat display case and into the freezer where the others--Mary Jo and Bruce Conner, the couple who managed the market, and a woman Gloria didn't know--were huddled.

author: Julia Keller
headline: A Wicked Wind Takes Aim
graf: They waited that final minute, not knowing if they were really safe, not knowing if the walls would hold, not knowing if these were the last seconds of their lives, and they embraced, and then--at 6:09 p.m.--there was a sound like hundreds of cars being dumped on the roof, and they knew that it was, unmistakably, upon them.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: In the basement of Duffy's Tavern, dirt sifted between the floorboards overhead for 10 seconds. They could hear muffled booms from above, the crashes, the bangs and cracks and rattles. The whole building seemed to shudder, as if bumped rudely in a crowd. Sixty seconds before, they had hurried into the basement, chased there by a tornado flying toward the tiny town of Utica at 6:09 p.m. on April 20.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Down the wooden steps they had come, hurrying, hurrying, but trying not to shove. The lights died. Once at the bottom, they huddled shoulder to shoulder, next to things they couldn't see: shelves with plastic tubs of French dressing and twist-tied bags of the green and white mints that Lisle Elsbury liked to hand out to departing customers.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Elsbury, the owner of Duffy's, was last in line, having gathered everybody--six staff members, six customers--and made sure they were headed down the stairs and then closing the basement door behind him. His foot was still on the bottom step when it hit.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Ten seconds of shaking. Of falling dirt. "Everybody OK?" Elsbury said, once the shaking stopped. A nervous murmur of yeses.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: He waited another 45 seconds or so. When he thought it was all over--you couldn't be sure, not really, but you followed your instincts--Elsbury headed up the steps and cautiously opened the door.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: He expected chaos. He expected, at the very least, severe damage: splintered bar, overturned tables and chairs, busted windows.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: But Elsbury saw little change. Later he would discover a great deal of structural damage to the second floor, but for now, he felt lucky.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Chris Rochelle, 23, the bartender, was right behind his boss. When he saw that Duffy's seemed intact, Rochelle moved straight out the back door to check on the rest of the town. He had good friends up and down this street, but none better than Larry Ventrice over at Milestone, Larry who'd encouraged him to start lifting weights again and take care of himself, Larry who'd lent him a car in which to drive home to Kansas last Christmas. If Duffy's looked OK, then Rochelle wanted to help his friend Larry clean up Milestone.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: He ran north through the alley, past the backs of Duffy's and Skoog's Pub and the other buildings, past the blown-down bricks and felled trees and hunks of twisted metal.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: When he got to the corner he couldn't believe what he saw. What he didn't see.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Rochelle ran back to Duffy's--he would have no memory of the running, of his knees rising and falling or of the breath tearing in and out of his chest, but he knew he must have done so, because that's where he ended up--and he screamed, "Milestone's gone! Milestone's gone!" Even as he was saying it, even as the words flew out of his mouth, it didn't sound possible. But it was. He had seen it. Or, not seen it.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Steve Maltas, who had taken refuge in the boiler room of the firehouse along with seven other volunteer firefighters, shoved open the heavy door. Yep, the building was still standing.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Then they all hurried outside, and the first thing they saw was what wasn't there: Milestone.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: A knee-high pile of rubble--sandstone blocks, thick wooden beams and a crusty overlay of broken concrete--seethed and steamed in the space where a two-story building had stood since 1887, right across the street from the firehouse.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: For a few seconds Maltas and the others were too stunned to move, too numb, their minds utterly rejecting what their eyes were telling them was true: A building had been flattened in 10 seconds, like a sandcastle squashed by a bored kid at the beach.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: They broke out of their astonishment and ran across the street to the jagged pile. Where to start? What to do? Good God. The center was absolute mashed chaos--wood and concrete and stone and wire and a thick powdery mist of pulverized mortar--but the edges, the edges looked bizarre: At the edges were huge intact sandstone blocks that had toppled in neat rows, like dominoes.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: They started pulling at the rocks, doing what anybody would do: trying to get to whoever was inside, grabbing and lifting and clawing. They could hear screams and calls for help, and it was a healthy sound, God knows, because silence would have been worse.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Seconds later, they were joined by other people, people who had emerged from downtown buildings and looked around to check the damage and then saw--Good Lord--Milestone, what was left of Milestone, and so they ran to the site and bent over or dropped to their knees and pulled, scratched, dug and heaved the stones, but there were so many stones and so many layers and it seemed hopeless. They couldn't let themselves think that, though, so they just kept digging and pulling at stones.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: So intent were they, so focused, that at first they didn't notice the damage to the rest of Utica. They didn't really see the garage right next to Milestone, where the Fire Department parked its ambulances, wrecked so badly that later it would have to be torn down. They hardly noticed that Starved Rock Bait & Tackle, the century-old building across the alley from Milestone where Jim Collins had sold gas, cigarettes, soda pop and hunting licenses for almost two decades, was a ruined mess.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: All anybody could think about was Milestone, Milestone, Milestone, because the tavern wasn't just mauled and pummeled, wasn't just grievously damaged. It was gone.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: In the top layer of the rubble, two bodies were clearly, excruciatingly visible. And because Utica is a small town, because everybody knows everybody, they knew who they were: Jay Vezain and Carol Schultheis, two local folks who'd been having a drink in Milestone just before the storm.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: By the time Joe Krizel got there about five minutes later, at least two dozen people were tugging at the rubble. Krizel worked at Uniman, a sand plant on a hill just north of Utica. From his vantage point up there, he had watched the tornado move in, watched it churn and whip its way northeast, then saw it pause over Utica--10 seconds, he thought, no more--almost as if it had an appointment there, as if it knew where it wanted to go, right down to the street address. Krizel couldn't tear his eyes away from it.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Then the spinning black cloud moved on, heading up the hill where it broke apart, and Krizel suddenly felt released from whatever spell that awful thing had cast over him.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
graf: Krizel, 49, had been a volunteer firefighter for more than two decades. He knew there'd be a lot of damage, so he slid into his pickup to head downtown. Trouble was, the road was blocked by debris--ripped-up trees with their shocked roots still dangling, thrown-down telephone poles, big chunks of roofs, swatches of curled-up sheet metal--and he couldn't get through. He hollered at Blayne Bimm--son of Shelba Bimm, one of Krizel's Fire Department colleagues--who also worked at Uniman, and Blayne hopped into an endloader and cleared the way for the pickup.

author: Julia Keller
headline: Milestone's gone!'
