The guard has a son 23 years old, and the slaying impels the young man to go to the United States. He comes back before crossing the Rio Grande and tells Enrique about riding on trains, leaping off rolling freight cars and dodging la migra, Mexican immigration agents.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Because of the security guard's murder, Marco swears that he will never change money again. A few months later, though, he gets a call. For a large commission, would he exchange $50,000 in lempiras on the border with El Salvador? Uncle Marco promises that this will be the last time.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Enrique wants to go with him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: But his uncle says he is too young. He takes one of his own brothers instead.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Robbers riddle their car with bullets. Enrique's uncles careen off the road. The thieves shoot Uncle Marco three times in the chest and once in the leg. They shoot his brother in the face. Both die.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Now Uncle Marco is gone.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: In nine years, Lourdes has saved $700 toward bringing her children to the United States. Instead, she uses it to help pay for her brothers' funerals.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Within days, Uncle Marco's girlfriend sells Enrique's television, stereo and Nintendo game--all gifts from Marco. Without telling him why, she says, "I don't want you here anymore." She puts his bed out on the street.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Enrique, now 15, gathers his clothing and goes to his maternal grandmother.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "Can I stay here?" he asks.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: This had been his first home, the small stucco house where he and Lourdes lived until Lourdes stepped off the front porch and left. His second home was the wooden shack where he and his father lived with his father's mother, until his father found a new wife and left. His third home was the comfortable house where he lived with his Uncle Marco.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Now he is back where he began. Seven people live here already: his grandmother, Agueda Amalia Valladares; two divorced aunts; and four young cousins. They are poor. "We need money just for food," says his grandmother, who suffers from cataracts. Nonetheless, she takes him in.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: She and the others are consumed by the slayings of the two uncles; they pay little attention to Enrique. He grows quiet, introverted.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He does not return to school.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: At first, he shares the front bedroom with an aunt, Mirian Liliana Aguilera, 26. One day she awakens at 2 a.m. Enrique is sobbing quietly in his bed, cradling a picture of Uncle Marco in his arms. Enrique cries off and on for six months. His uncle loved him; without his uncle, he is lost.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Grandmother Agueda sours quickly on Enrique. She grows angry when he comes home late, knocking on her door, rousing the household. About a month later, Aunt Mirian wakes up again in the middle of the night. This time she smells acetone and hears the rustle of plastic. Through the dimness, she sees Enrique in his bed, puffing on a bag. He is sniffing glue.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Enrique is banished to a tiny stone building seven feet behind the house but a world away. It was once a cook shack, where his grandmother prepared food on an open fire. Its walls and ceiling are charred black. It has no electricity. The wooden door pries only partway open, and the single window has no glass, just bars. A few feet beyond is his privy--a hole with a wooden shanty over it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: The stone hut becomes his home.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Now Enrique can do whatever he wants. If he is out all night, no one cares. But to him, it feels like another rejection.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Nearby is a neighborhood called El Infiernito, or Little Hell, controlled by a street gang, the Mara Salvatrucha. Some MS have been U.S. residents, living in Los Angeles until 1996, when a federal law began requiring judges to deport them if they committed serious crimes. Now they are active throughout much of Central America and Mexico. Here in El Infiernito, they carry chimbas, guns fashioned from plumbing pipes, and they drink charamila, diluted rubbing alcohol. They ride the buses, robbing passengers.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Enrique and a friend, Jose del Carmen Bustamante, 16, venture into El Infiernito to buy marijuana. It is dangerous. On one occasion, Jose is threatened by a man who wraps a chain around his neck. The boys never linger. They take their joints partway up a hill to a billiard hall, where they sit outside smoking and listening to the music that drifts through the open doors.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: With them are two other friends. Both have tried to ride freight trains to El Norte. One is known as El Gato, the cat. He talks about migra agents shooting over his head and how easy it is to be robbed by bandits. In Enrique's marijuana haze, train-riding sounds like an adventure.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He and Jose resolve to try it soon.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Some nights, at 10 or so, they climb a steep, winding path to the top of another hill. Hidden beside a wall scrawled with graffiti, they inhale glue late into the night. One day, Enrique's girlfriend, Maria Isabel Caria Duron, 17, turns a street corner and bumps into him. She is overwhelmed. He smells like an open can of paint.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "What's that?" she asks, reeling away from the fumes. "Are you on drugs?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "No!" Enrique says.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He tries to hide his habit. He dabs a bit of glue into a plastic bag and stuffs it into a pocket. Alone, he opens the end over his mouth and inhales, pressing the bottom of the bag toward his face, pushing the fumes into his lungs.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Belky notices cloudy yellow fingerprints on Maria Isabel's jeans: glue, a remnant of Enrique's embrace.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Maria Isabel sees him change. His mouth is sweaty and sticky. He is jumpy and nervous. His eyes grow red. Sometimes they are glassy, half-closed. Other times he looks drunk. If she asks a question, the response is delayed. His temper is quick. On a high, he grows quiet, sleepy and distant. When he comes down, he becomes hysterical and insulting.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Drogo. Drug addict, one of his aunts calls him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Sometimes he hallucinates that someone is chasing him. He imagines gnomes and fixates on ants. He sees a cartoon-like Winnie the Pooh soaring in front of him. He walks, but he cannot feel the ground. Sometimes his legs will not respond. Houses move. Occasionally, the floor falls.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: For two particularly bad weeks, he doesn't recognize family members. His hands tremble. He coughs black phlegm.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Enrique marks his 16th birthday. All he wants is his mother. One Sunday, he and his friend Jose put train-riding to the test. They leave for El Norte.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: At first, no one notices. They take buses across Guatemala to the Mexican border.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "I have a mom in the U.S.," Enrique tells a guard.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "Go home," the man replies.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: They slip past the guard and make their way 12 miles into Mexico to Tapachula. There they approach a freight train near the depot. But before they can reach the tracks, police stop them. The officers rob them, the boys say later, but then let them go--Jose first, Enrique afterward.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: They find each other and another train. Now, for the first time, Enrique clambers aboard. The train crawls out of the Tapachula station. From here on, he thinks, nothing bad can happen.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: They know nothing about riding the rails.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Jose is terrified. Enrique, who is braver, jumps from car to car on the slow-moving train. He slips and falls--away from the tracks, luckily--and lands on a backpack padded with a shirt and an extra pair of pants.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He scrambles aboard again.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: But their odyssey comes to a humiliating halt.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Near Tierra Blanca, a small town in Veracruz state, authorities snatch them from the top of a freight car. The officers take them to a cell filled with MS gangsters, then deport them. Enrique is bruised and limping, and he misses Maria Isabel. They find coconuts to sell for bus fare and go home.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Enrique sinks deeper into drugs. By mid-December, he owes his marijuana supplier 6,000 lempiras, about $400. He has only 1,000 lempiras. He promises the rest by midweek, but cannot keep his word. The following weekend, he encounters the dealer on the street.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: The supplier accuses Enrique of lying and threatens to kill him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Enrique pleads with him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: If Enrique doesn't pay up, the dealer vows, he will kill Enrique's sister. The dealer mistakenly thinks that Enrique's cousin, Tania Ninoska Turcios, 18, is his sister. Both girls are finishing high school, and most of the family is away at a Nicaraguan hotel celebrating their graduation.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Enrique pries open the back door to the house where his Uncle Carlos Orlando Turcios Ramos and Aunt Rosa Amalia live. He hesitates. How can he do this to his own family? Three times, he walks up to the door, opens it, closes it and leaves. Each time, he takes another deep hit of glue.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Finally, he enters the house, picks open the lock to a bedroom door, then jimmies the back of his aunt's armoire with a knife. He stuffs 25 pieces of her jewelry into a plastic bag and hides it under a rock near the local lumberyard.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: At 10 p.m., the family returns to find the bedroom ransacked.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Neighbors say the dog did not bark.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "It must have been Enrique," Aunt Rosa Amalia says. She calls the police. Uncle Carlos and several officers go to find him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "Why did you do this? Why?" Aunt Rosa Amalia yells.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "It wasn't me." As soon as he says it, he flushes with shame and guilt. The police handcuff him. In their patrol car, he trembles and begins to cry. "I was drugged. I didn't want to do it." He tells the officers that a dealer wanting money had threatened to kill Tania.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He leads police to the bag of jewelry.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "Do you want us to lock him up?" the police ask.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Uncle Carlos thinks of Lourdes. They cannot do this to her. Instead, he orders Tania to stay indoors indefinitely, for her own safety.<

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: But the robbery finally convinces Uncle Carlos that Enrique needs help. He finds him a $15-a-week job at a tire store. He eats lunch with him every day--chicken and homemade soup. He tells the family they must show him their love.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: During the next month, January 2000, Enrique tries to quit drugs. He cuts back, but then he gives in. Every night, he comes home later. He looks at himself in disgust. He is dressing like a slob--his life is unraveling. He is lucid enough to tell Belky that he knows what he has to do.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He simply has to go find his mother.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Aunt Ana Lucia Aguilera agrees. She and Enrique have clashed for months. Ana Lucia is the only breadwinner. Even with his job at the tire store, Enrique is an economic drain.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Worse, he is sullying the only thing her family owns: its good name.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: They speak bitter words that both, along with Enrique's Grandmother Agueda, will recall months later. "Where are you coming from, you old bum?" Ana Lucia asks as Enrique walks in the door. "Coming home for food, huh?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "Be quiet!" he says. "I'm not asking anything of you."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "You are a lazy bum! A drug addict! No one wants you here." All the neighbors can hear. "This isn't your house. Go to your mother!"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Over and over, in a low voice, Enrique says, half pleading, "You better be quiet."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Finally, he snaps. He kicks Ana Lucia twice, squarely in the buttocks.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: She shrieks.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: His grandmother runs out of the house. She grabs a stick and threatens to club him if he touches Ana Lucia again. Now even his grandmother wishes he would go to the United States. He is hurting the family--and himself. She says, "He'll be better off there."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Maria Isabel, Enrique's girlfriend, finds him sitting on a rock at a street corner, weeping, rejected again. She tries to comfort him. He is high on glue. He tells her he sees a wall of fire that is killing his mother. "¿Por qué me dejó?" he cries out. "Why did she leave me?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He feels shame for what he has done to his family and what he is doing to Maria Isabel, who might be pregnant. He fears he will end up on the streets or dead. Only his mother can help him. She is his salvation. "If you had known my mom, you would know she's a good person," he says to his friend Jose. "I love her."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Enrique has to find her. He sells the few things he owns: his bed, a gift from his mother; his leather jacket, a gift from his dead uncle; his rustic armoire, where he hangs his clothes.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He crosses town to say goodbye to Grandmother Maria. Trudging up the hill to her house, he encounters his father. "I'm leaving," he says. "I'm going to make it to the U.S." He asks him for money.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: His father gives him enough for a soda and wishes him luck.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "Grandma, I'm leaving," Enrique says. "I'm going to find my mom."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Don't go, she pleads. She promises to build him a one-room house in the corner of her cramped lot.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: But he has made up his mind.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: She gives him 100 lempiras, about $7--all the money she has.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "I'm leaving already, Sis," he tells Belky the next morning.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: She feels her stomach tighten. They have lived most of their lives apart, but he is the only one who understands her loneliness. Quietly she fixes a special meal: tortillas, a pork cutlet, rice, fried beans with a sprinkling of cheese.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "Don't leave," she says, tears welling in her eyes.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: "I have to."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: It is hard for him too. Every time he has talked to his mother, she has warned him not to come--it's too dangerous. But if somehow he gets to the U.S. border, he will call her. Being so close, she'll have to welcome him. "If I call her from there," he says to Jose, "how can she not accept me?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He makes himself one promise: "I'm going to reach the United States, even if it takes one year."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Only after a year passes will he give up, turn on his heel and go back.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: Quietly, Enrique, the slight kid with a boyish grin, fond of kites, spaghetti, soccer and break dancing, who likes to play in the mud and watch Mickey Mouse cartoons with his 4-year-old cousin, packs up his belongings: corduroy pants, a T-shirt, a cap, gloves, a toothbrush and toothpaste.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: For a long moment, he looks at a picture of his mother, but he does not take it. He might lose it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He writes her telephone number on a scrap of paper. Just in case, he also scrawls it in ink on the inside waistband of his pants.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He has $57 in his pocket.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: On March 2, 2000, he goes to his Grandmother Agueda's house. He stands on the same porch that his mother disappeared from 11 years before.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- The Boy Left Behind
graf: He hugs Maria Isabel and Aunt Rosa Amalia. Then he steps off.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: His quiet vow to villagers: 'I'm going to find my mom'.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The day's work is done at Las Anonas, a rail-side hamlet of 36 families in the state of Oaxaca, Mexico, when a field hand, Sirenio Gomez Fuentes, sees a startling sight: a battered and bleeding boy, naked except for his undershorts.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: It is Enrique.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: He limps forward on bare feet, stumbling one way, then another. His right shin is gashed. His upper lip is split. The left side of his face is swollen. He is crying.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Gomez hears him whisper, "Give me water, please."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The knot of apprehension in Sirenio Gomez melts into pity. He runs into his thatched hut, fills a cup and gives it to Enrique.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: "Do you have a pair of pants?" Enrique asks.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Gomez dashes back inside and fetches some. There are holes in the crotch and the knees, but they will do. Then, with kindness, Gomez directs Enrique to Carlos Carrasco, the mayor of Las Anonas. Whatever has happened, maybe he can help.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Enrique hobbles down a dirt road into the heart of the little town. He encounters a man on a horse. Could he help him find the mayor? "That's me," the man says. He stops and stares. "Did you fall from the train?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Again, Enrique begins to cry.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Mayor Carrasco dismounts. He takes Enrique's arm and guides him to his home, next to the town church. "Mom!" he shouts. "There's a poor kid out here! He's all beaten up." Carrasco drags a wooden pew out of the church, pulls it into the shade of a tamarind tree and helps Enrique onto it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Lesbia Sibaja, the mayor's mother, puts a pot of water on to boil and sprinkles in salt and herbs to clean his wounds. She brings Enrique a bowl of hot broth, filled with bits of meat and potatoes.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: He spoons the brown liquid into his mouth, careful not to touch his broken teeth. He cannot chew.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Townspeople come to see. They stand in a circle. "Is he alive?" asks Gloria Luis, a stout woman with long black hair. "Why don't you go home? Wouldn't that be better?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: "I am going to find my mom," Enrique says, quietly.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: He is 17. It is March 24, 2000. Eleven years before, his mother had left home in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, to work in the United States. She did not come back, and now he is riding freight trains up through Mexico to find her.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Gloria Luis looks at Enrique and thinks about her own children. She earns little; most people in Las Anonas make 30 pesos a day, roughly $3, working the fields. She digs into a pocket and presses 10 pesos into Enrique's hand.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Several other women open his hand, adding 5 or 10 pesos each.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Mayor Carrasco gives Enrique a shirt and shoes. He has cared for injured immigrants before. Some have died. Giving Enrique clothing will be futile, Carrasco thinks, if he can't find someone with a car who can get the boy to medical help.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Adan Diaz Ruiz, mayor of San Pedro Tapanatepec, the county seat, happens by in his pickup.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Carrasco begs a favor: Take this kid to a doctor.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Diaz balks. He is miffed. "This is what they get for doing this journey," he says. Enrique cannot pay for any treatment. Why, Diaz wonders, do these Central American governments send us all their problems?

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Looking at the small, soft-spoken boy lying on the bench, he reminds himself that a live migrant is better than a dead one. In 18 months, Diaz has had to bury eight of them, nearly all mutilated by the trains. Already today, he has been told to expect the body of yet another, in his late 30s.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Sending this boy to a doctor would cost the county $60. Burying him in a common grave would cost three times as much. First, Diaz would have to pay someone to dig the grave, then someone to handle the paperwork, then someone to stand guard while Enrique's unclaimed body is displayed on the steamy patio of the San Pedro Tapanatepec cemetery for 72 hours, as required by law.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: All the while, people visiting the graves of their loved ones would complain about the smell of another rotting migrant.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: "We will help you," he tells Enrique finally.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: He turns him over to his driver, Ricardo Diaz Aguilar. Inside the mayor's pickup, Enrique sobs, but this time with relief. He says to the driver, "I thought I was going to die."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: An officer of the judicial police approaches in a white pickup. Enrique cranks down his window. Instantly, he recoils. He recognizes both the officer and the truck.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The officer, too, seems startled.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: For a moment, the officer and the mayor's driver discuss the new dead immigrant. Quickly, the policeman pulls away.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: "That guy robbed me yesterday," Enrique says. The policeman and a partner had taken 100 pesos from him and three other migrants at gunpoint in Chahuites, about five miles south.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The mayor's driver is not surprised. The judicial police, he says, routinely stop trains to rob and beat immigrants.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The judiciales--the Agencia Federal de Investigacion--deny it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: In San Pedro Tapanatepec, the driver finds the last clinic still open that night.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: When Enrique's mother left, he was a child. Six months ago, the first time he set out to find her, he was still a callow kid. Now he is a veteran of what has become a perilous children's pilgrimage to the north.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Every year, experts say, an estimated 48,000 youngsters like Enrique from Central America and Mexico enter the United States illegally and without either of their parents. Many come looking for their mothers. They travel any way they can, and thousands ride the tops and sides of freight trains.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: They leap on and off rolling train cars. They forage for food and water. Bandits prey on them. So do street gangsters deported from Los Angeles, who have made the train tops their new turf. None of the youngsters have proper papers. Many are caught by the Mexican police or by la migra, the Mexican immigration authorities, who take them south to Guatemala.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Most try again.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Like many others, Enrique has made several attempts.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The first: He set out from Honduras with a friend, Jose del Carmen Bustamante. They remember traveling 31 days and about 1,000 miles through Guatemala into the state of Veracruz in central Mexico, wherela migra captured them on top of a train and sent them back to Guatemala on what migrants call el bus de lagrimas, the bus of tears. These buses make as many as eight runs a day, deporting more than 100,000 unhappy passengers every year.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The second: Enrique journeyed by himself. Five days and 150 miles into Mexico, he committed the mistake of falling asleep on top of a train with his shoes off. Police stopped the train near the town of Tonala to hunt for migrants, and Enrique had to jump off. Barefoot, he could not run far. He hid overnight in some grass, then was captured and put on the bus back to Guatemala.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The third: After two days, police surprised him while he was asleep in an empty house near Chahuites, 190 miles into Mexico. They robbed him, he says, and then turned him over to la migra, who put him, once more, on the bus to Guatemala.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The fourth: After a day and 12 miles, police caught him sleeping on top of a mausoleum in a graveyard near the depot in Tapachula, Mexico, known as the place where an immigrant woman had been raped and, two years before that, another was raped and stoned to death. La migra took Enrique back to Guatemala.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The fifth: La migra captured him as he walked along the tracks in Queretaro, north of Mexico City. Enrique was 838 miles and almost a week into his journey. He had been stung in the face by a swarm of bees. For the fifth time, immigration agents shipped him back to Guatemala.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The sixth: He nearly succeeded. It took him more than five days. He crossed 1,564 miles. He reached the Rio Grande and actually saw the United States. He was eating alone near some railroad tracks whenmigra agents grabbed him. They sent him to a detention center, called El Corralon, or the corral, in Mexico City. The next day they bused him for 14 hours, all the way back to Guatemala.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: It was as if he had never left.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: This is his seventh try, and it is on this attempt that he suffers the injuries that leave him in the hands of the kind people of Las Anonas.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Here is what Enrique recalls:

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: It is night. He is riding on a freight train. A stranger climbs up the side of his tanker car and asks for a cigarette.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Trees hide the moon, and Enrique does not see two men who are behind the stranger, or three more creeping up the other side of the car. Scores of migrants cling to the train, but no one is within shouting distance.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: One of the men reaches a grate where Enrique is sitting. He grabs Enrique with both hands.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Someone seizes him from behind. They slam him face down.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: All six surround him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Take off everything, one says.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Another swings a wooden club. It cracks into the back of Enrique's head.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Hurry, somebody demands. The club smacks his face.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Enrique feels someone yank off his shoes. Hands paw through his pants pockets. One of the men pulls out a small scrap of paper. It has his mother's telephone number. Without it, he has no way to locate her. The man tosses the paper into the air. Enrique sees it flutter away.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The men pull off his pants. His mother's number is inked inside the waistband. But there is little money. Enrique has less than 50 pesos on him, only a few coins that he has gathered begging. The men curse and fling the pants overboard.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The blows land harder.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: "Don't kill me," Enrique pleads.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: His cap flies away. Someone rips off his shirt. Another blow finds the left side of his face. It shatters three teeth. They rattle like broken glass in his mouth.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: One of the men stands over Enrique, straddling him. He wraps the sleeve of a jacket around Enrique's neck and starts to twist.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Enrique wheezes, coughs and gasps for air. His hands move feverishly from his neck to his face as he tries to breathe and buffer the blows.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: "Throw him off the train," one man yells.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Enrique thinks of his mother. He will be buried in an unmarked grave, and she will never know what happened.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: "Please," he asks God, "don't let me die without seeing her again."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The man with the jacket slips. The noose loosens.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Enrique struggles to his knees. He has been stripped of everything but his underwear. He manages to stand, and he runs along the top of the fuel car, desperately trying to balance on the smooth, curved surface. Loose tracks flail the train from side to side. There are no lights. He can barely see his feet. He stumbles, then regains his footing.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: In half a dozen strides, he reaches the rear of the car.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The train is rolling at nearly 40 mph. The next car is another fuel tanker. Leaping from one to the other at such speed would be suicidal. Enrique knows he could slip, fall between them and be sucked under.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: He hears the men coming. Carefully, he jumps down onto the coupler that holds the cars together, just inches from the hot, churning wheels. He hears the muffled pop of gunshots and knows what he must do. He leaps from the train, flinging himself outward into the black void.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: He hits dirt by the tracks and crumples to the ground. He crawls 30 feet. His knees throb.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Finally, he collapses under a small mango tree.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Enrique cannot see blood, but he senses it everywhere. It runs in a gooey dribble down his face and out of his ears and nose. It tastes bitter in his mouth. Still, he feels overwhelming relief: The blows have stopped.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: He recalls sleeping, maybe 12 hours, then stirring and trying to sit. His mind wanders to his mother, then his family and his girlfriend, Maria Isabel, who might be pregnant. "How will they know where I have died?" He falls back to sleep, then wakes again. Slowly, barefoot and with swollen knees, he hobbles north along the rails. He grows dizzy and confused. After what seems to be several hours, he is back again where he began, at the mango tree.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Just beyond it, in the opposite direction, is a thatched hut surrounded by a white fence.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: It belongs to field hand Sirenio Gomez Fuentes, who watches as the bloodied boy walks toward him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: At the clinic, Dr. Guillermo Toledo Montes leads Enrique to an examination table.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Enrique's left eye socket has a severe concussion. The eyelid is injured and might droop forever. His back is covered with bruises. He has several lesions on his right leg and an open wound hidden under his hair. Two of his top teeth are broken. So is one on the bottom.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Dr. Toledo jabs a needle under the skin near Enrique's eye, then on his forehead. He injects a local anesthetic. He scrubs dirt out of the wounds and thinks of the immigrants he has treated who have died. This one is lucky. "You should give thanks you are alive," he says. "Why don't you go home?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: "No." Enrique shakes his head. "I don't want to go back." Politely he asks if there is a way that he can pay for his care, as well as the antibiotics and the anti-inflammatory drugs.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The doctor shakes his head. "What do you plan to do now?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Catch another freight train, Enrique says. "I want to get to my family. I am alone in my country. I have to go north."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The police in San Pedro Tapanatepec do not hand him over to la migra. Instead, he sleeps that night on the concrete floor of their one-room command post. At dawn, he leaves, hoping to catch a bus back to the railroad tracks. As he walks, people stare at his injured face. Without a word, one man hands him 50 pesos. Another gives him 20. He limps on, heading for the outskirts of town.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The pain is too great, so he flags down a car. "Will you give me a ride?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: "Get in," the driver says.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: Enrique does. It is a costly mistake.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: The driver is an off-duty immigration officer. He pulls into a migracheckpoint and turns Enrique over.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: You can't keep going north, the agents say.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: He is ushered onto another bus, with its smell of sweat and diesel fumes. He is relieved that there are no Central American gangsters on board. Sometimes they let themselves be caught by la migra so they can beat and rob the migrants on the buses. In spite of everything, Enrique has failed again--he will not reach the United States this time, either.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Badly Beaten, a Boy Seeks Mercy in a Rail-Side Town
graf: He tells himself over and over that he'll just have to try again.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: As Enrique enters Mexico's southernmost state of Chiapas, he knows why immigrants call it "the beast." Bandits, street gangs and police will be out to get him. Even tree branches scraping the boxcars may hurl him from the train. But he will take those risks. He needs to find his mother.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique wades chest-deep across a river. He is 5 feet tall, stoop-shouldered and cannot swim. The logo on his cap boasts hollowly, "No Fear."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The river, the Rio Suchiate, forms the border. Behind him is Guatemala. Ahead is Mexico, with its southernmost state of Chiapas. "Ahora nos enfrentamos a la bestia," immigrants say when they enter Chiapas. "Now we face the beast."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Painfully, Enrique, 17, has learned a lot about "the beast." In Chiapas, bandits will be out to rob him, police will try to shake him down, and street gangs might kill him. But he will take those risks, because he needs to find his mother.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: When he was 5 years old, she left him in Honduras and joined hundreds of thousands of women from Central America and Mexico seeking work in the United States. An estimated 48,000 youngsters go north alone every year, many to search for their mothers.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: This is Enrique's eighth attempt to reach El Norte. First, always, comes the beast. About Chiapas, Enrique has discovered several important things.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: In Chiapas, do not take buses, which must pass through nine permanent immigration checkpoints. A freight train faces checkpoints as well, but Enrique can jump off as it brakes, and if he runs fast enough, he might sneak around and meet the train on the other side.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: In Chiapas, never ride alone.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: In Chiapas, do not trust anyone in authority and beware even the ordinary residents, who tend to dislike migrants.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Once the Rio Suchiate is safely behind him, Enrique beds down for the night in a cemetery near the depot in the town of Tapachula, tucking the "No Fear" cap beneath him so it will not be stolen. He is close enough to hear diesel engines growl and horns blare whenever a train pulls out.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The cemetery is a way station for immigrants. At sunup on any given day, it seems as uninhabited as a country graveyard, with crosses and crypts painted periwinkle, neon green and purple. But then, at the first rumble of a departing train, it erupts with life. Dozens of migrants, children among them, emerge from the bushes, from behind the ceiba trees and from among the tombs.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: They run on trails between the graves and dash headlong down the slope. A sewage canal, 20 feet wide, separates them from the rails. They jump across seven stones in the canal, from one to another, over a nauseating stream of black. They gather on the other side, shaking the water from their feet. Now they are only yards from the rail bed.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: On this day, March 26, 2000, Enrique is among them. He sprints alongside rolling freight cars and focuses on his footing. The roadbed slants down at 45 degrees on both sides. It is scattered with rocks as big as his fist. He cannot maintain his balance and keep up, so he aims his tattered tennis shoes at the railroad ties. Spaced every few feet, the ties have been soaked with creosote, and they are slippery.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Here the locomotives accelerate. Sometimes they reach 25 mph. Enrique knows he must heave himself up onto a car before the train comes to a bridge just beyond the end of the cemetery. He has learned to make his move early, before the train gathers speed.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Most freight cars have two ladders on a side, each next to a set of wheels. Enrique always chooses a ladder at the front. If he misses and his feet land on the rails, he still has an instant to jerk them away before the back wheels arrive.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: But if he runs too slowly, the ladder will yank him forward and send him sprawling. Then the front wheels, or the back ones, could take an arm, a leg, perhaps his life.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "Se lo comio el tren," other immigrants will say. "The train ate him up."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The lowest rung of the ladder is waist-high. When the train leans away, it is higher. If it banks a curve, the wheels kick up hot white sparks, burning Enrique's skin.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He has learned that if he considers all of this too long, then he falls behind--and the train passes him by.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: This time, he trots alongside a gray hopper car. He grabs one of its ladders, summons all of his strength and pulls himself up. One foot finds the bottom rung. Then the other.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He is aboard.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique looks ahead on the train. Men and boys are hanging on to the sides of tank cars, trying to find a spot to sit or stand. Some of the youngsters could not land their feet on the ladders and have pulled themselves up rung by rung on their knees, which are bruised and bloodied.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Suddenly, Enrique hears screams.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Three cars away, a boy, 12 or 13 years old, has managed to grab the bottom rung of a ladder on a fuel tanker, but he cannot haul himself up. Air rushing beneath the train is sucking his legs under the car. It is tugging at him harder, drawing his feet toward the wheels.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "Don't let go!" a man shouts. He and others crawl along the top of the train to a nearby car. They shout again.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The boy dangles from the ladder. He struggles to keep his grip.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Carefully, the men crawl down and reach for him. Slowly, they lift him up. The rungs batter his legs, but he is alive. He still has his feet.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique guesses there are more than 200 migrants on board, a tiny army of them who charged out of the cemetery with nothing but their cunning.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Arrayed against them are Mexican immigration authorities, or la migra, along with crooked police, street gangsters and bandits. They wage what a priest at an immigrant shelter calls "la guerra sin nombre," the war with no name. Chiapas, he says, "is a cemetery with no crosses, where people die without even getting a prayer."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: All of this is nothing, however, against Enrique's longing for his mother, who left him behind 11 years ago. Although his effort to survive often forces her out of his mind, at times he thinks of her with a loneliness that is overwhelming. He remembers when she would call Honduras from the United States, the concern in her voice, how she would not hang up before saying: "I love you. I miss you."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique considers carefully. Which freight car will he ride on? This time he will be more cautious than before.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Boxcars are the tallest. Their ladders do not go all the way up. Migra agents would be less likely to climb to the top. And he could lie flat on the roof and hide. From there, he could see the agents approaching, and if they started to climb up, he could jump to another car and run.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: But boxcars are dangerous. They have little on top to hold on to.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Inside a boxcar might be better.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: But police, railroad security agents or la migra could bar the doors, trapping him inside. If the doors closed accidentally, he might die. Migrants say temperatures inside climb to 100 degrees, and people kneel to ask God to stop the train. Some suffocate, and others stand on their bodies to reach tiny air holes above the doors.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: A good place to hide could be under the cars, up between the axles, balancing on a foot-wide iron shock absorber. But Enrique might be too big to fit. Besides, trains kick up rocks. Worse, if his arms grew tired, or if he fell asleep, he would drop directly under the wheels.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique settles for the top of a hopper. He holds on to a grate running along the rim. From his perch 14 feet up, he can see anyone approaching on either side of the tracks, up ahead or from another car. Below, at each end, the hopper's wheels are exposed: shiny metal, 3 feet in diameter, 5 inches thick, churning. He stays as far away as he can.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He doesn't carry anything that might keep him from running fast. At most, if it is exceptionally hot, he ties a nylon string on an empty plastic bottle, wraps it around his arm and fills the bottle with water when he can.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Some immigrants climb on board with a toothbrush tucked into a pocket. Others bring a small Bible with telephone numbers, penciled in the margins, of their mothers or fathers or other relatives in the United States. Maybe nail clippers, a rosary or a scapular with a tiny drawing of San Cristobal, the patron saint of travelers, or of San Judas Tadeo, the patron saint of desperate situations.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: As usual, the train lurches hard from side to side. Enrique holds on with both hands. Occasionally, the train speeds up or slows down, smashing couplers together and jarring him backward or forward. The wheels rumble. Sometimes each car rocks the other way from the ones ahead and behind. El Gusano de Hierro, some migrants call it. The Iron Worm.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: In Chiapas, the tracks are 20 years old. Some of the ties sink, especially during the rainy season, when the roadbed turns soggy and soft. Grass grows over the rails, making them slippery.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: When the cars round a bend, they feel as if they might overturn. Enrique's train runs only a few times a week, but it averages three derailments a month, by the count of Jorge Reinoso, chief of operations for Ferrocarriles Chiapas-Mayab, the railroad. One year before, a hopper like Enrique's overturned with a load of sand, burying three immigrants alive. Enrique rarely lets himself admit fear, but he is scared that his car might tip. El Tren de la Muerte, some migrants call it. The Train of Death.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique is struck by the magic of the train--its power and its ability to take him to his mother. To him, it is El Caballo de Hierro. The Iron Horse.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The train picks up speed. It passes a brown river that smells of sewage. Then a dark form emerges ahead. "¡Rama!" the immigrants yell. "Branch!" They duck.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique grips the hopper. To avoid the branches, he sways from side to side. All of the riders sway in unison, ducking the same branches--left then right. One moment of carelessness and the branches will hurl them into the air. Matilda de la Rosa, who lives by the tracks, recalls a migrant who came to her door with an eyeball hanging on his cheek. He cupped it near his face, in his right hand. He told her, "The train ripped out my eye."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Each time the train slows, Enrique goes on high alert for la migra.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Immigrants wake one another and begin climbing down to prepare to jump. If the train speeds up again, everyone climbs back up. The movement down and up the ladders looks like a strangely choreographed two-step.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: But slowing down at Huixtla, with its red and yellow depot, can mean only one thing: Coming up is La Arrocera, one of the most dreaded immigration checkpoints in Mexico.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique has defied La Arrocera before. This time, he arrives in the heat of noon. Tension builds. Some migrants stand on top of the train, straining to see the migra agents up ahead. As the train brakes, they jump.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The train lurches sideways. Enrique leaps from car to car, finally landing on a boxcar. The train stops. He lies flat, face down, arms spread-eagle, hoping la migra won't see him. But several agents do.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "¡Bajate, puto! Get down, you whore!"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "No! I'm not coming down!"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: There is no ladder all the way to the top. Maybe they won't come up after him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "Get down!"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "No!"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The agents summon reinforcements. One starts to climb up.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique scrambles to his feet and races along the top of the train, soaring across the 4-foot gaps between cars. As he runs, three agents follow on the ground, pelting him with rocks and sticks, an experience many immigrants say they have here. Stones clang against the metal. Enrique flees from car to car, more than 20 in all, struggling to keep his footing each time he leaps from a hopper to a fuel tanker, which is lower and has a rounded top.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He is running out of train. He will have to go around La Arrocera alone. It may be suicidal, but he has no choice. More stones ping off the train. Enrique scurries down a ladder and sprints into the bushes.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "¡Alto! ¡Alto! Stop!" the agents shout.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: As Enrique runs, he hears what he thinks are gunshots behind him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Except in extraordinary circumstances, Mexican immigration agents are barred from carrying firearms. According to a retired agent, however, most have .38-caliber pistols. Some of the shelter workers tell of migrants hit by bullets. Others tell of torture. Before long, Enrique will meet a man whose chest is pockmarked with cigarette burns. The man tells him that a migra agent at La Arrocera branded him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: In the scrub brush, though, Enrique worries less about agents than about madrinas with machetes. The name for these men is a play on words: These civilians help the authorities, as a madrina, or godmother, would, and administer madrizas, or savage beatings. Human rights activists and some police agencies say the madrinas commit some of the worst atrocities--rapes and torture--and are allowed by authorities to keep a portion of what they steal.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique runs on. He crawls under a barbed wire fence, then under a double strand of smooth wire. It is electrified. At night, Guillermina Galvez Lopez, who lives at La Arrocera, hears the trains and, not long afterward, the piercing screams of immigrants, wet from the swampy grass, who run into the wire.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "Help me! Help me!" they wail.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Ten times in 10 months, train riders have carried to her front door men and boys without arms, legs or heads. In 1999, Clemente Delporte Gomez, a patrolman with Grupo Beta Sur, the government's migrant rights organization, watched a young Salvadoran slip on railroad ties near La Arrocera. Train wheels cut him in two at the midriff. Delporte saw the Salvadoran's heart flicker three times. Then it was still.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique knows he has plunged deep into bandit territory. At least three, maybe five swarms of robbers, some with Uzis, some on drugs, patrol the three-mile dirt paths that immigrants must use to go around La Arrocera, authorities say. They seem to operate with such impunity that Mario Campos Gutierrez, a supervisor with Grupo Beta, thinks the authorities collaborate.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Before taking these paths, migrants hide their money. Some stitch it into the seams of their pants. Others put a bit in their shoes, a bit in their shirts and a coin or two in their mouths. Still others bag it in plastic and tuck it into intimate places. Some roll it up and slip it into their walking sticks. Others hollow out mangoes, drop their pesos inside, then pretend to be eating the fruit.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique figures he doesn't have enough money to bother.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Last time he sneaked past La Arrocera, he was lucky because he was careful. He stuck with a band of street gangsters. This time he is alone. He focuses on the thought that will make him run the fastest: "I cannot miss the train."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: If he misses the one he just left, he knows he will be a sitting duck, waiting for days in the bushes and the tall grass until another one comes.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique races so fast he feels the blood pounding at his temples. The grass, growing in three-foot tentacles, lassos his feet. He stumbles, gets up and keeps running. He passes an abandoned brick house. Half the roof is gone.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The house is notorious. Not long before, Grupo Beta had found a bed of bricks inside, covered with emerald green leaves from a plant that looked like a bird of paradise--and two soiled pairs of panties crumpled on the dirt floor. Women are raped here, most recently a 16-year-old assaulted repeatedly over three days.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Many are gang-raped, including a Salvadoran woman, four months pregnant, who was assaulted at gunpoint by 13 bandits along the railroad tracks to the south. Nearly one in six immigrant girls detained by authorities in Texas says she has been sexually assaulted during her journey, according to a 1997 University of Houston study. Some girls journeying north cut off their hair, strap their breasts and try to pass for boys. Others scrawl on their chests: "TENGO SIDA. I have AIDS."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique does not stop. He reaches the Cuil bridge, where the railroad spans a 40-foot stream of murky brown water. This, migrants and Grupo Beta officers say, is the most dangerous spot. Bandits haul mattresses up into nearby trees, eat lunch and wait for their prey. As immigrants cross the bridge, the bandits drop out of the limbs and surround them. Other robbers hide along the tracks above and below the bridge, which is thick with bushes and vines. One fishes in the river or cuts grass with a machete, like a fieldworker, and whistles to the others to set a trap.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Just a month before, bandits ambushed five Salvadorans as they crossed the bridge at 4 a.m. They tried to run. The bandits shot one in the back. Four months later, three Salvadorans and a Mexican, all in their 20s, were killed. The Salvadorans, their hands tied behind them, were shot in the head. The Mexican was stabbed. All they had left was their underwear.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique dashes across the bridge and keeps running. Mountains stand to his right. The ground is so wet that farmers grow rice between their rows of corn. He can feel heat and humidity rising from the loamy earth. It saps his energy, but he runs on.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Finally, he stops, doubled over, panting.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He is not sure why, but he has survived La Arrocera. Maybe it was his extra caution, maybe it was his decision to run, maybe it was his attempt to lie flat and hide atop the boxcar, which delayed his getting off the train and gave the bandits an opportunity to target migrants ahead of him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He is desperate for water. He spots a house.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The people inside are not likely to give him any. Chiapas is fed up with Central American immigrants, says Hugo Angeles Cruz, a professor and migration expert at El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Tapachula. They are poorer than Mexicans, and they are seen as backward and ignorant. People think they bring disease, prostitution and crime and take away jobs. Some cannot be trusted. People in Chiapas talk of being robbed by migrants with guns and knives. They tell of an older woman who welcomed an immigrant into her home and was beaten to death with an iron pipe.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Boys like Enrique are called "stinking undocumented." They are cursed, taunted. Dogs are set upon them. Barefoot children throw rocks at them. Some use slingshots. "Go to work." "Get out! Get out!"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Drinking water can be impossible to come by. Migrants filter ditch sewage through T-shirts. Finding food can be just as difficult. Enrique is counting: In some places, people at seven of every 10 houses turn him away.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "No," they say. "We haven't cooked today. We don't have any tortillas. Try somewhere else."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "No, boy, we don't have anything here."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Sometimes it is worse. People in the houses turn the immigrants in.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique sees another migrant who has managed to make it around La Arrocera. He, too, needs water badly, but he doesn't dare ask. He is afraid of walking into a trap. To immigrants, begging in Chiapas is like walking up to a loaded gun.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "I'll go," Enrique says. "If they catch someone, it will be me."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He approaches a house and speaks softly, his head slightly bowed. "I'm hungry. Can you spare a taco? Some water?" The woman inside sees injuries from the train-top beating he took during his last attempt to go north. "What happened?" she asks. She gives him water, bread and beans.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The other migrant comes nearer. She gives him food too.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: A horn blows. Enrique runs to the tracks. Other immigrants who have survived La Arrocera come out of the bushes. They sprint alongside the train and reach for the ladders on the freight cars.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique climbs up onto a hopper. The train picks up speed.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: For the moment, he relaxes.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The Iron Worm squeaks, groans and clanks--black tankers, rust-colored boxcars and gray hoppers winding north on a single track that parallels the Pacific coast. Off to the right are hillsides covered with coffee plants. Cornstalks grow up against the rails. The train moves through a sea of plantain trees, lush and tropical.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: By early afternoon, it is 105 degrees. Enrique's palms burn when he holds on to the hopper. He risks riding no-hands. Finally, he strips off his shirt and sits on it. The locomotive blows warm diesel smoke. People burn trash by the rails, sending up more heat and a searing stench. Enrique's head throbs. The sun stings in his eyes, and his skin tingles. He moves around the car, chasing patches of shade. For a while, he stands on a narrow ledge at the end of a fuel tanker. It is just inches above the wheels.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He cannot let himself fall asleep; one good shake of the train, and he would tumble off.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Moreover, street gangsters, some deported from Los Angeles, prowl the train tops looking for sleepers. Many of the migrants huddle together, hoping for safety in numbers. They watch for anyone with tattoos, especially gangsters who have skulls inked around their ankles--one skull, police say, for every person they have killed. Their brutality is legendary. Immigrants tell of nine gangsters who hurled a man off their train, then forced two boys to have sex together or be thrown off too.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Some migrants nap on their feet, using belts or shirts to strap themselves to posts at the ends of the hoppers. Others struggle to stay awake. They take amphetamines, slap their own faces, do squats, talk to one another and sing. At 4 a.m. the train sounds like a chorus.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Today, Enrique is terrified of another beating. Every time someone new jumps onto his car, he tenses. Fear, he realizes, helps to keep him awake, so he decides to induce it. He climbs to the top of the tank car and takes a running leap. With arms spread, as if he were flying, he jumps to one swaying boxcar, then to another. Some have 4-to-5-foot gaps. Others are 9 feet apart.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The train passes into northern Chiapas. Mountains draw closer. Plantain fields soften into cow pastures. Enrique's train slows to a crawl. As the sun sets, he hears crickets begin their music and join the immigrant chorus.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: The train nears San Ramon, close to the northern state line. It is past midnight now, and the judicial police are probably asleep. Train crews say this is where the police stage their biggest shakedowns. One conductor says the officers, 15 at a time, stop the trains. They grab fleeing migrants by their shirts. The conductor has heard them say: "If you move, I'll kill you. I'll break you in two." Then, "Give us what you've got, or we send you back."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: At nearby Arriaga, the chief of the judicial police, or Agencia Federal de Investigacion, denies that his agents stop trains in San Ramon and rob immigrants. The chief, Sixto Juarez, suggests that any robbing is done by gangsters or bandits who impersonate judicial officers.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Enrique greets the dawn without incident. He puts Chiapas behind him. He still has far to go, but he has faced the beast eight times now, and he has lived through it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: It is an achievement, and he is proud of it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: Around noon, he reaches Ixtepec, a southern crossroads in Oaxaca, the next state north, 285 miles into Mexico. As his train squeals to a stop, migrants jump down and look for houses where they can beg for a drink and a bite to eat. La bestia might be behind them, but most are still afraid. Two of them are too frightened to go into town. They offer Enrique 20 pesos and ask him to buy food. If he will bring it back, they will share it with him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He takes off his yellow shirt, stained and smelling of diesel smoke. Underneath he wears a white one. He puts it on over the dirty one. Maybe he can pass for someone who lives here. He resolves not to panic if he sees a policeman, and to walk as if he knows where he is going.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
