graf: He takes the pesos and walks down the main street, past a bar, a store, a bank and a pharmacy. He stops at a barber shop. His hair is curly and far too long. It is an easy tip-off. People here tend to have straighter hair.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He strides purposefully inside.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: "¡Orale, jefe!" he says, using a phrase Oaxacans favor. "Hey, chief!" He mutes his flat, Central American accent and speaks softly and singsongy, like a Oaxacan. He asks for a short crop, military style. He pays with the last of his own money, careful not to call it pisto, as they do back home. That means alcohol up here.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He is mindful about what else he says. Migra agents trip people up by asking if the Mexican flag has five stars (the Honduran flag has, but the Mexican flag has none), or by demanding the name of the mortar used to make salsa (molcajete, a uniquely Mexican word), or inquiring how much someone weighs. If he replies in pounds, he is from Central America. In Mexico, people use kilos.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: In Guatemala, soda is called agua. Here in Mexico, agua is water. A jacket is a chamarra, not a chumpa. A T-shirt is a playera, not a blusa. At one point, Enrique glances into a store window and sees his reflection. It is the first time he has looked at his face since he was beaten. He recoils from what he sees. Scars and bruises. Black and blue. One eyelid droops.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: It stops him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: He was 5 years old when his mother left him. Now he is almost another person. In the window glass, he sees a battered young man, scrawny and disfigured.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Defeated Seven Times, a Boy Again Faces 'the Beast'
graf: It angers him, and it steels his determination to push northward.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: From the top of his rolling freight car, Enrique sees a figure of Christ.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: In the fields of Veracruz state, among farmers and their donkeys piled with sugar cane, rises a mountain. It towers over the train he is riding. At the summit stands a statue of Jesus. It is 60 feet tall, dressed in white, with a pink tunic.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The statue stretches out both arms. They reach toward Enrique and his fellow wayfarers on top of their rolling freight cars.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Some stare silently. Others whisper a prayer.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: It is early April 2000, and they have made it nearly a third of the way up the length of Mexico, a handful of immigrants, riding on boxcars, tank cars and hoppers. Enrique is 17. He is one of an estimated 48,000 Central American and Mexican children who go to the United States alone every year. Many are searching for their mothers, who have left for El Norte to find work and never come back.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Many credit religious faith for their progress. They pray on top of the train cars. At stops, they kneel along the tracks, asking God for help and guidance. They ask him to keep them alive until they reach El Norte. They ask him to protect them against bandits, who rob and beat them; police, who shake them down; and la migra, the Mexican immigration authorities, who deport them.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Many carry small Bibles, wrapped in plastic bags to keep them dry. On the pages, in the margins, they scrawl the names and addresses of the people who help them. The police often check the bindings for money to steal, the migrants say, but usually hand the Bibles back.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Some pages are particularly worn. The one that offers the 23rd Psalm, for instance: "Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Or the 91st Psalm: "There shall no evil befall thee, neither shall any plague come nigh thy dwelling. For he shall give his angels charge over thee, to keep thee in all thy ways."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Some migrants rely on a special prayer, "La Oracion a las Tres Divinas Personas"--a prayer to the Holy Trinity. It has seven sentences--short enough to recite in a moment of danger. If they rush the words, God will not mind.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: That night, Enrique climbs to the top of a boxcar. In the starlight, he sees a man on his knees, bending over his Bible, praying.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique climbs back down.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He does not turn to God for help. With all the sins he has committed, he thinks he has no right to ask God for anything.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: FOR THE RECORD: Enrique's Journey--Chapter 4 of the six-part series, published Friday in Section A, described Teotihuacan in Mexico as an Aztec metropolis. The Aztecs adopted the site as a ceremonial ground and gave it its modern name, but it originated and peaked as a metropolis during the pre-Aztec period.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: What he receives are gifts.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique expects the worst. Riding trains through the state of Chiapas, which immigrants call "the beast," has taught him that any upraised hand might hurl a stone. But here in the states of Oaxaca and Veracruz, he discovers that people are friendly. "It's just the way we are," says Jorge Zarif Zetuna Curioca, a legislator from Ixtepec.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Perhaps not everyone is that way, but there is a widespread generosity of spirit. Many residents say it is rooted in the Zapotec and Mixtec indigenous cultures. Besides, some say, giving is a good way to protest Mexico's policies against illegal immigration.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Not long after seeing the statue of Jesus, Enrique is alone on a hopper. Night has fallen, and as the train passes through a tiny town, it blows its soulful horn. He looks over the side. More than a dozen people, mostly women and children, are rushing out of their houses along the tracks, clutching small bundles.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Some of the migrants grow afraid. Will these people throw rocks? They lie low on top of the train. Enrique sees a woman and a boy run up alongside his hopper

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "¡Orale, chavo! Here, boy!" they shout.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: They toss up a roll of crackers. It is the first gift.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique reaches out. He grabs with one hand, but holds tightly to the hopper with the other. The roll of crackers flies several feet away, bounces off the car and thumps to the ground.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Now women and children on both sides of the tracks are throwing bundles to the immigrants on the tops of the cars. They run quickly and aim carefully, mostly in silence, trying hard not to miss.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "¡Alli va uno! There's one!"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique looks down. There are the same woman and boy. They are heaving a blue plastic bag. This time the bundle lands squarely in his arms.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "¡Gracias! ¡Adios!" he says into the darkness. He isn't sure the strangers, who pass by in a flash, even heard him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He opens the bag. Inside are half a dozen rolls of bread.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique is stunned by the generosity. In many places where the train slows in Veracruz, at a curve or to pass through a village, people give. Sometimes 20 or 30 people stream out of their homes along the rails and toward the train. They smile, then shout and throw food.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The towns of Encinar, Fortin de las Flores, Cuichapa and Presidio are particularly known for their kindness. These are unlikely places for people to be giving food to strangers. A World Bank study in 2000 found that 42.5% of Mexico's 100 million people live on $2 or less a day. Here, in rural areas, 30% of children 5 and younger eat so little that their growth is stunted, and the people who live in humble houses along the rails are often the poorest.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Families throw sweaters, tortillas, bread and plastic bottles filled with lemonade. A baker, his hands coated with flour, throws his extra loaves. A seamstress throws bags filled with sandwiches. A teenager throws bananas. A store owner throws animal crackers, day-old pastries and half-liter bottles of water.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: A young man, Leovardo Santiago Flores, throws oranges in November, when they are plentiful, and watermelons and pineapples in July. A stooped woman, Maria Luisa Mora Martin, more than 100 years old, who was reduced to eating the bark of her plantain tree during the Mexican Revolution, forces her knotted hands to fill bags with tortillas, beans and salsa so her daughter, Soledad Vasquez, 70, can run down a rocky slope and heave them onto a train.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "If I have one tortilla, I give half away," one of the food throwers says. "I know God will bring me more."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Another: "I don't like to feel that I have eaten and they haven't."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Still others: "When you see these people, it moves you. It moves you. Can you imagine how far they've come?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "God says, when I saw you naked, I clothed you. When I saw you hungry, I gave you food. That is what God teaches."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "It feels good to give something that they need so badly."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "I figure when I die, I can't take anything with me. So why not give?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "What if someday something bad happens to us? Maybe someone will extend a hand to us."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique is hungry, but he fears that the half-dozen rolls from the food throwers might be all there is to his good fortune, so he stashes them for later.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: In little more than an hour, the train nears a town: Cordoba.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The cargo is beginning to change. It is valuable and more easily damaged--Volkswagens, Fords and Chryslers. Security guards check the freight cars, catch every rider they can and hand them over to authorities. More important, says Cuauhtemoc Gonzalez Flores, an official of the Transportacion Ferroviaria Mexicana railroad, if a migrant falls and is injured or killed, it costs $8 a minute to stop the train, often for hours, until investigators arrive.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: A sewage stream appears by the tracks. Cordoba is getting close. The immigrants finish their water, because it is hard to run fast holding bottles. They tie sweaters or extra shirts around their waists. Enrique grabs his bag of bread. About 10 p.m., he smells a familiar cue: a coffee-roasting factory next to the red brick station. As the train slows, he leaps and flees.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He sits on a sidewalk one block north of the station. Two police officers approach.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: His odds are better if he does not bolt. He tucks his bread into a crevice. He swallows his fright and tries to look unconcerned.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The officers, in navy blue uniforms, walk straight up to him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He does not move, even flinch. Cops can sense fear. They can tell if someone is illegal. You have to be calm, he says to himself. You can't look afraid or hide. You have to look right at them.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Unlike food throwers, the police do not bear gifts. They pull out pistols.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "If you run, I'll shoot you," one says, aiming at Enrique's chest.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: They take him and two younger boys, sitting nearby, to a cavernous railroad shed, where seven other officers are holding 20 migrants.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: It is a full-scale sweep.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: They line up the immigrants against a wall. "Take everything out of your pockets."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Only a bribe, Enrique knows, will keep him from being deported back to Central America. He has 30 pesos, about $3, that he earned lifting rocks and sweeping near the tracks in Tierra Blanca. He prays it will be enough.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: One officer pats him down and says to empty his pockets.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique drops his belt, a Raiders cap and the 30 pesos. He glances at his fellow migrants. Each is standing behind a little pile of belongings.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "¡Salganse! ¡Vayanse, ya! Get out! Leave!"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He will not be deported. But he pauses. He screws up his courage. "Can I get my things back, my money?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "What money?" the officer replies. "Forget about it, unless you want to have your trip stop here."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique turns his back and walks away.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Even in Veracruz, where strangers can be so kind, the authorities cannot be trusted. The chief of state police in nearby Fortin de las Flores will not comment on the incident.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Exhausted, Enrique retrieves his bag of bread, climbs onto a flatbed truck and sleeps. At dawn, he hears a train. He trots alongside a freight car and clambers aboard, holding his bread.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The tracks, smoother now, begin to climb. It grows cooler. The train passes 60-foot stalks of bamboo. It rolls through putrid white smoke from a Kimberly-Clark factory that turns sugar cane pulp into Kleenex and toilet paper.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: In Orizaba, the train changes crews. Enrique asks a man standing near the tracks, "Can you give me one peso to buy some food?" The man inquires about his scars. They are from a beating little more than a week ago on top of a train. He gives Enrique 15 pesos, about $1.50.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique runs to buy soda and cheese to go with his bread. He looks north and sees snow-covered Pico de Orizaba, the highest summit in Mexico. Now it will turn icy cold, especially at night, much different from the steamy lowlands. Enrique begs two sweaters. Before the train pulls out, he runs from car to car, looking into the hollows at the ends of the hoppers, where riders occasionally discard clothing. In one, he finds a blanket.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: As the train starts, Enrique shares his cheese, soda and rolls with two other boys, also headed for the United States. One is 13. The other is 17. Silently, Enrique thanks the food throwers again for the bread.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He relishes the camaraderie: how riders take care of one another, pass along what they know, divide what they have. Camaraderie often means survival. "I could get to the north faster alone," he figures, "but I might not make it."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The mountains close in. Enrique invites the two boys to share his blanket. Together they will be warmer. The three jam themselves between a grate and an opening on top of a hopper. Enrique stuffs rags under his head for a pillow. The car sways, and its wheels click-clack quietly. They sleep.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The train enters a tunnel, the first of 32 in the Cumbres de Acultzingo, or the Peaks of Acultzingo. Outside is bright sun. Inside is darkness so black that riders cannot see their hands. They shout, "¡Ay! ¡Ay! ¡Ay! ¡Ay! ¡Ay!" and listen for the echo. Enrique and his friends sleep on. Back in the daylight, the train hugs a hillside. Below, a valley is filled with fields of corn, radishes and lettuce, each a different hue of green.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: El Mexicano is the longest tunnel. For eight minutes, the train vanishes inside. Black diesel smoke hugs the tops of the cars. It burns the lungs and stings the eyes. Enrique's eyes are closed, but his face and arms turn gray. His nose runs black soot. Engineers fear El Mexicano. If a locomotive overheats, they must stop. Riders spring for the arched exits, gasping for clean air.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Back outside, ice forms on the cars. Riders ache and shiver. Their lips crack, and their eyes grow dull. They hug themselves. They pull their shirts over their mouths to warm themselves with their breath. When the train slows, they jog alongside to ward off the cold. As night falls, some of the older immigrants drink whiskey. Too much and they tumble off. Others gather old clothing and trash and build fires on the ledges over the wheels of the hoppers. Some stand in the warm plumes of diesel smoke.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: At dawn, the tracks straighten and level out. At 1½ miles above sea level, the train accelerates to 35 mph. Enrique awakens. He sees cultivated cactus on both sides. Directly in front rise two huge pyramids, the Aztec metropolis of Teotihuacan.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Then he sees switches and semaphores. Housing developments. A billboard for Paradise Spa. A sewage ditch. Taxis.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The train slows for the station at Lecheria. Enrique gets ready to run.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He is in Mexico City.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The Veracruz hospitality has vanished.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: One woman wrinkles her nose when she talks about migrants. She is hesitant to slide the deadbolt on the metal door of her tall stucco fence. "I'm afraid of them. They talk funny. They are dirty."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique starts knocking on doors. He begs for food. In Mexico City, where crime is rampant, people are often hostile. "We don't have anything," they say at house after house, usually through locked doors.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Finally, at one house, another gift: A woman offers him tortillas, beans and lemonade.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Now he must hide from the state police, who guard the depot at Lecheria, a gritty industrial neighborhood on the northwestern outskirts of Mexico City. He crawls into a 3-foot-wide concrete culvert.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: At 10:30 p.m., a northbound train arrives. From Mexico City onward, the rail system is more modern, and trains run so fast that few immigrants ride on top. Enrique and his two friends pick an open boxcar. If they are caught inside, it will be hard to escape, but they count on the scarcity of migra checkpoints in northern Mexico. The boys load cardboard to lie on and stay clean.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique notices a blanket on a nearby hopper. He climbs a ladder to get it and hears a loud buzz from overhead. Live wires carry electricity above the trains for 143 miles north. Once used for locomotives that no longer operate, the wires still carry 25,000 volts to prevent vandalism. Signs warn: "Danger--High Voltage." But many of the migrants cannot read.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: They do not even need to touch the lines to be killed. The electricity arcs up to 20 inches. Only 36 inches separate the wires from the tallest freight cars, the auto carriers. In railroad offices in Mexico City, computers plot train routes with blue and green lines, and at least once every six months the screens flicker, then black out. An immigrant has crawled on top of a car, been hit by electricity and short-circuited the system. When the computers reboot, the screens flash red where it happened.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique climbs the hopper car. Carefully, he snatches a corner of the blanket and yanks it down. Then he scrambles back to his boxcar and settles into a bed that he and his friends have fashioned out of straw they found inside.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The boys share a bottle of water and one of juice. They plow through a heavy fog, and Enrique sleeps soundly--too soundly.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He does not sense when police stop their train in the middle of the central Mexican desert. Officers dressed in black find the boys curled under their blanket in the straw. They take them to their jefe, who is cooking a pot of stew over a campfire. He pats them down to check for drugs. Then, instead of arresting them, he gives all three tortillas and water--and toothpaste to clean up.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique is astonished. The jefe lets them re-board the boxcar and tells them to get off the train before San Luis Potosi, where 64 railroad security officers guard the station. At midmorning, Enrique sees two flashing red antennas. The boys jump off the train half a mile south of town.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Until now, Enrique has opted to keep moving. But here the countryside is too desolate to live off the land, and begging is too chancy. He needs to work if he is going to survive. Besides, he does not want to reach the border penniless. He has heard that U.S. ranchers shoot immigrants who come to beg.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He trudges up a hill to the small home of a brick maker. Politely, Enrique asks for food. The brick maker offers yet another kindness: If Enrique will work, he will get both food and a place to sleep.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Happily, Enrique accepts.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Some migrants say Mexicans exploit illegals for a fraction of the going wage, which is 50 pesos, or about $5, a day. But the brick maker does better than that: 80 pesos. And he gives Enrique shoes and clothing.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: For a day and a half, Enrique works at the brickyard, one of 300 that straddle the tracks on the northern edge of San Luis Potosi. Workers pour clay, water and dried cow manure into large pits. They roll up their pants and stomp on the sloppy concoction, as if pressing grapes to make wine. When the slop becomes a firm brown paste, they slap it into wooden molds. Then they empty the molds on flat ground and let the bricks dry.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The bricks are stacked into pyramids inside ovens as big as rooms. Under the ovens, the fires are stoked with sawdust. Each batch of bricks bakes for 15 hours, sending clouds of black smoke into the sky.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique's job is to shovel the clay. At night, he sleeps in a shed on a dirt floor he shares with one of his friends from the train.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "I have to get to the border," Enrique tells him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Should he take another train? Freight cars have brought him 990 miles from Tapachula near Guatemala. Is he pushing his luck?

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: His employer says he should ride a Volkswagen van called a combithrough a checkpoint about 40 minutes north of town. The authorities won't stop a combi, the brick maker says. Then he should take a bus to Matehuala, and he might be able to get a ride on a truck all the way to Nuevo Laredo on the Rio Grande.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique collects his pay, 120 pesos. He spends a few on a toothbrush.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He hails a combi. It breezes through the checkpoint. He pays 83 pesos to board a bus to Matehuala. Outside the bus station, he sees a kindly looking man.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "Can you help me?" Enrique asks.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The man gives him a place to sleep. The next morning, Enrique walks to a truck stop.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "I don't have any money," he tells every driver he sees. "Can you give me a ride however far north you are going?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: One after another, they turn him down. If they said yes, police might accuse them of smuggling. Drivers say it is enough to worry about officers planting drugs on their trucks and demanding bribes. Moreover, some of the truckers fear that immigrants might assault them.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Finally, at 10 a.m., one driver takes the risk.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique pulls himself up into the cab of an 18-wheeler hauling beer.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "Where are you from?" the driver asks.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Honduras.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: "Where are you going?" The driver has seen boys like Enrique before. "Do you have a mom or dad in the United States?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique tells him about his mother.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: A sign at Los Pocitos says, "Checkpoint in 100 Meters." The truck idles in line. Then it inches forward. Judicial police officers ask the driver what he is carrying. They want his papers. They peer at Enrique.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The driver is ready: My assistant.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: But the officers do not ask.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: A few feet farther on, soldiers stop each vehicle to search for drugs and guns. Two fresh-faced recruits wave them through.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Oblivious to chatter on the trucker's two-way radio, Enrique falls asleep. The driver clears two more checkpoints. As he nears the Rio Grande, he stops to eat. He buys Enrique a plate of eggs and refried beans and a soda, another gift.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Riding a truck, Enrique figures, is a dream.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Sixteen miles before the border, he sees a sign: "Reduce Your Speed. Nuevo Laredo Customs."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Don't worry, the driver says, la migra check only the buses.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: A sign says, "Bienvenidos a Nuevo Laredo." Welcome to Nuevo Laredo.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: The driver drops him off. With 30 pesos he has left, he takes a bus that winds into the city.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: He has one more piece of good fortune. At the Plaza Hidalgo, in the heart of Nuevo Laredo, Enrique sees a man from Honduras whom he has met on a train. The man takes him to an encampment along the Rio Grande. Enrique likes it. He decides to stay until he can cross.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: That night, as the sun sets, Enrique stares across the Rio Grande and gazes at the United States. It looms as a mystery.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Somewhere over there lives his mother. She has become a mystery too. He was so young when she left that he can barely remember what she looks like: curly hair; eyes like chocolate. Her voice is a distant sound on the phone.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- Inspired by Faith, the Poor Rush Forth to Offer Food
graf: Enrique has spent 47 days bent on nothing but surviving. Now, as he thinks about her, he is overwhelmed.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique is stuck on the Mexican side of the Rio Grande, watching, listening and planning. Somewhere on the other side, in the United States, is his mother.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: You are in American territory," a Border Patrol agent shouts into a bullhorn. "Turn back."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Sometimes Enrique strips and wades into the Rio Grande to cool off. But the bullhorn always stops him. He goes back.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "Thank you for returning to your country."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He is stymied. For days, Enrique, 17, has been stuck in Nuevo Laredo, on the southern bank of the Rio Bravo, as it is called here. He has been watching, listening and trying to plan. Somewhere across this milky green ribbon of water is his mother.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: She left him behind 11 years ago in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, to seek work in the United States. Enrique is challenging the unknown to find her. During her most recent telephone call, she said she was in North Carolina. He has no idea if she is still there, where that is or how to reach it. He no longer has her phone number.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He had written it on a scrap of paper, but it blew away while he was being robbed and beaten almost four weeks ago on a freight train in southern Mexico. He did not think to memorize it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Of the estimated 48,000 youngsters from Central America and Mexico who go north illegally on their own every year, many do not memorize telephone numbers or addresses. They wrap them in plastic and tuck them into a shoe or slip them under a waistband. Some of the numbers are lost, others are stolen. Occasionally kidnappers snatch the children themselves, find the numbers and call the mothers for ransom.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Stripped of phone numbers and destinations, many of the children become stranded at the river. Defeat drives them to the worst this border world has to offer: drugs, despair and death.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: It is almost May 2000, nearly two months since Enrique left home the last time. He is a hardened veteran of seven attempts to reach El Norte. This is his eighth. By now, his mother must have called Honduras again, and the family must have told her that he was gone. His mother must be worrying.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He has to telephone her.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Besides, she might have saved enough money to hire a smuggler, or coyote, who can take him across the river.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He remembers one number back home--at a tire store where he worked. He will call and ask his old employer to find Aunt Rosa Amalia or Uncle Carlos Orlando Turcios Ramos, who had arranged his job, and ask them for his mother's number. Then he will call back and get it from his boss.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: For the two calls, he needs two telephone cards: Fifty pesos apiece. When he phones his mother, he'll call collect.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He cannot beg 100 pesos. People in Nuevo Laredo won't give. Mexicans along the border, he notices, are quick to proclaim their right to immigrate to the United States. "Jesus was an immigrant," he hears them say. But most won't give Central Americans food, money or jobs.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: So he will work by himself. He'll wash cars.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: The encampment he has joined is a haven for migrants, coyotes, junkies and criminals, but it is safer for him than anywhere else in Nuevo Laredo, a city of half a million and swarming with immigration agents, or la migra, and all kinds of police, who might catch him and deport him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: The camp is at the bottom of a narrow, winding path that slopes to the river. Each evening, without fail, he summons his courage and goes to the Nuevo Laredo city hall with a large plastic paint bucket and two rags. From a spigot on the side of the building, he fills the bucket. Then he goes to parking places across the street from a bustling taco stand. One of his rags is red. Each time someone arrives to eat dinner, he waves the red rag to guide the customer into a parking space, like a ground crew ushering a jetliner to a gate.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Usually there is competition. Two or three others immigrants set up their buckets along the same sidewalk.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique approaches a woman driving a yellow Chevrolet Impala with chrome-spoke wheels. She is talking on her cell phone. May he wash her car?

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: She ends the call and declines.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: A man and his young daughter drive up.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "May I clean your car?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "No, son."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: The woman with the Impala returns with her tacos. Enrique waits until traffic is clear, then waves his red rag and guides her out.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Suddenly, she reaches out her car window and presses 3 pesos into his hand.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique approaches dozens of people, but just one or two say yes. By 4 a.m., when the stand closes, he has eked out 30 pesos, or $3.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: The air around the taco stand fills with the aroma of barbecue. Enrique watches workers pull strips of meat from a vat, put them on large chopping blocks and cut them up. Customers sit at long stainless steel tables and eat. Sometimes, when the stand closes, the servers slip him a couple of tacos.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Otherwise, for his only meal every day, he depends upon Parroquia de San Jose, or St. Joseph's Parish, and another church, Parroquia del Santo Niño, the Parish of the Holy Child. Each gives food cards to migrants. One is good for 10 meals and the other for five. Enrique can count on one meal a day for 15 days. The cards are like gold. Sometimes they are stolen and turn up on a meal-card black market.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Each day, Enrique goes to one church or the other to eat. It is safe; the police stay away. Like clockwork, Leti Limon, a volunteer, swings open the double yellow doors at San Jose and shouts, "Who's new?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "Me! Me!" men and boys cry out from the courtyard.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: They rush to the door and jostle against it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "Get in line! Get in line!" Limon is poor herself; she cleans houses across the river in Laredo, Texas, for $20 apiece. But she has helped to feed these immigrants for a year and a half, figuring that Jesus would approve. She issues the newcomers beige cards and punches the cards of those who enter. A parish priest counts 6% children.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: One by one, the migrants stand behind chairs at a long table. At the head is a mural of Jesus, his hands extended toward plates of tacos, tomatoes and beans. Above him are his words: "Come to me, all you who are weary and find life burdensome."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: The lights dim, and two big fans spin to a stop, so everyone can hear grace. Some who have not eaten in two or three days cannot wait; from behind their chairs, they grab at the tacos with one hand, bread with the other.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Chairs screech as everyone pulls them out at once. Spoons of stew touch lips before bottoms hit the seats. In a clatter of forks against plates, beans, stew, tomatoes, rice and doughnuts disappear.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: For permission to stay in the relative safety of the encampment, the leader, El Tirindaro, who is addicted to heroin, usually wants drugs or beer. But he has not asked Enrique for anything. El Tirindaro is a subspecies of coyote known as a patero, because he smuggles people into the United States by pushing them across the river on inner tubes while paddling like a pato, or duck. Enrique is a likely client.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: In addition to smuggling, El Tirindaro finances his heroin habit by tattooing people and selling clothing that immigrants have left on the riverbank. Enrique stares as El Tirindaro lies on a mattress, mixes Mexican black tar heroin with water in a spoon, warms it over a cigarette lighter, draws it into a syringe and stabs the needle straight into a vein.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Besides migrants, the camp has 10 perpetual residents. Seven are addicts. They call heroin la cura, or the cure.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Also among the permanent campers are several immigrants who are stuck. One, a fellow Honduran, has lived on the river for seven months. He tried to enter the United States three times. Every time, he was caught. He has descended into depression and a life of glue sniffing.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Each time he tried to cross, he says, he went alone.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique listens. They call him El Hongo, the mushroom, because he is quiet, soaking everything in.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique is protected. Because he is so young, everyone at the camp looks after him. When he goes at night to wash cars, someone walks him through the brush to the road. They warn him against heroin. But leaving the camp scares him, and they give him marijuana to calm him down.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Car washing goes poorly. One night, he earns almost nothing.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: The 15 days on his meal cards pass quickly. Now he needs part of his money to eat. Every peso he spends on food cannot go toward the phone cards. He begins to eat as little as possible--crackers and soda.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Sometimes Enrique does not eat at all. Friends at the camp share their meals. One teaches him to fish with a line coiled on a shampoo bottle. The line, fitted with a hook, has three spark plugs at the end to sink it. Enrique swings the spark plugs around his head, then casts toward the middle of the Rio Grande. The line whirs as it spools off the bottle. He hauls in three catfish.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Even El Tirindaro is generous; the sooner Enrique can buy a phone card and call his mother, the sooner Enrique will need his services. When one of Enrique's meal cards is stolen, El Tirindaro gives him the unexpired card of a migrant who has crossed the river successfully. He knows that Enrique cannot swim, so he paddles him back and forth on the water in an inner tube to quiet his fears.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique learns that El Tirindaro is part of a smuggling network. A middle-aged man and a young woman, both Latinos, meet him and his clients after they cross the river. Then they all drive north together, and El Tirindaro walks his clients around Border Patrol checkpoints, giving wide berth to the agents. After the last checkpoint, El Tirindaro returns to Nuevo Laredo, and the couple and others in the network deliver the clients to their destinations. The price is $1,200.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: El Hongo listens as his camp mates talk about dos and don'ts: Find an inner tube. Take along a gallon of water. Learn where to get into the river, where not. They talk about the poverty they came from; they would rather die than go back. Enrique tells them about Maria Isabel, his girlfriend, and that she might be expecting.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique talks about his mother. He says he is extremely depressed.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "I want to be with her," he says, "to know her."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "If you talk, it's better," a friend says.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: But it gets worse. Enrique defends a friend against a street gangster and is spared a beating only by the intervention of another gangster from his neighborhood back home. Then his luck runs out with the authorities. He is arrested in town--twice, both times for loitering. Police call him a street bum and lock him up. In jail, the toilet runs over, and drunks smear the wall with its contents. Both times, Enrique wins his release by sweeping and mopping.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: One night, as he walks 20 blocks back to the river from washing cars, it rains. He ducks into an abandoned house, finds some cardboard and places it on a dry spot. He removes his sneakers and puts them and his bucket near his head. He has no socks, blanket or pillow. He pulls his shirt up around his ears and breathes into it to stay warm. Then he lies down, curls up and tucks his hands across his chest.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Lightning flashes. Thunder rumbles. Wind wails around the corners of the house. The rain falls steadily. On the highway, trucks hiss their brakes, stopping at the border before entering the United States. Across the river, the Border Patrol shines lights on the water, looking for immigrants trying to cross.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: With his bare feet touching a cold wall, Enrique sleeps.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: It is May 14, 2000, a Sunday when many churches in Mexico celebrate Mother's Day.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Finally, Enrique has saved 50 pesos. Eagerly, he buys a phone card. He gives it to one of El Tirindaro's friends for safekeeping. That way, if the police catch him again, they cannot steal it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "I just need one more," he says. "Then I can call her."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Every time he goes to Parroquia de San Jose, it makes him think about his mother, especially on this Mother's Day. In addition to the refectory, on the second floor are two small rooms where up to 10 women share four beds. They have left their children behind in Central America and Mexico to find work in El Norte, and they have found this place to sleep. Each could be his mother 11 years ago.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: They try to ignore a Mother's Day party downstairs, where 150 women from Nuevo Laredo laugh, shout and whistle as their sons dance, pillows stuffed under their shirts to make them look pregnant. Upstairs, the women weep. One has a daughter, 8, who had begged her not to go. She asked her to send back just one thing for her birthday: a doll that cries. Another cannot shake a nightmare: Back home, her little girl is killed, and her little boy runs away in tears. Daily she prays: "Don't let me die on this trip. If I die, they will live on the street."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique wonders: What does his mother look like now?

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "It's OK for a mother to leave," he tells a friend, "but just for two or four years, not longer." He recalls her promises to return for Christmas and how she never did. "I've felt alone all my life." One thing, though: She always told him she loved him. "I don't know what it will be like to see her. She will be happy. Me too. I want to tell her how much I love her. I will tell her I need her."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Across the Rio Grande on Mother's Day, his mother, Lourdes, thinks about Enrique. She has, indeed, learned that he is gone. But in her phone calls home, she never finds out where he went. She tries to convince herself that he is living with a friend, but she remembers their last telephone conversation: "I'll be there soon," he had said. "Before you know it, on your doorstep." Day after day, she waits for him to call. Night after night, she cannot sleep more than three hours. She watches TV: migrants dying in the desert, ranchers who shoot them.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: She imagines the worst and becomes terrified that she might never see him again. She is utterly helpless. She asks God to watch over him, guide him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: On the afternoon of the Mother's Day celebration, three municipal police visit the camp. Enrique does not try to run, but he is jittery. They ignore him. Instead, they take away one of his friends.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique has no money for food. He takes a hit of glue. It makes him sleepy, takes him to another world, eases his hunger and helps him forget about his family.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: A friend catches six tiny catfish. He builds a fire out of trash. It grows dark. He cuts the fish with a lid from an aluminum can.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique hovers nearby. "You know, Hernan, I haven't eaten all day."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Hernan guts the fish.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique stands silently, waiting.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: It is May 15. Enrique washes cars. He has a good night and makes 60 pesos. At midnight, he rushes to buy his second phone card. He puts only 30 pesos on it, gambling that his second call will be short. If his old employer finds Aunt Rosa Amalia and Uncle Carlos and gets his mother's number, then it won't take many minutes to call his boss a second time and pick it up.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique saves his other 30 pesos for food.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He and his friends celebrate. Enrique drinks and smokes some marijuana. He wants a tattoo. "A memory of my journey," he says.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: El Tirindaro offers to do it free. He shoots up to steady his hand.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique wants black ink.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: But all El Tirindaro has is green.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique pushes out his chest and asks for two names, so close together they are almost one. For three hours, El Tirindaro digs into Enrique's skin. In gothic script, the words emerge:

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: EnriqueLourdes.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: His mom, he thinks happily, will scold him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: The next day just before noon, he stirs from his dirty mattress. He is hungry. Hours pass. His hunger grows. Finally, he cannot stand it. He retrieves the first phone card from the friend who is holding it, and he sells it for food.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Worse, he is so desperate that he sacrifices it at a discount, for 40 pesos. He saves a few pesos for the next day and uses all of his money to buy crackers, the cheapest thing that will fill his stomach.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Now he has gone from two phone cards to one, worth only 30 pesos. He regrets surrendering to his hunger. If only he can earn 20 pesos more. Then he will go ahead and phone his old boss and hope that his aunt or uncle will call back on their own, so he won't need a second card.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: But someone has stolen his bucket. A friend at camp lends him one. He trudges back out to the car wash across from the taco stand. He sits on the bucket. Carefully, he pulls up his T-shirt. There, in an arch just above his belly button, is his tattoo, painfully raw.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: EnriqueLourdes. Now the words mock him.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: For the first time, he is ready to go back home. But he holds back his tears and lowers his shirt.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He refuses to give up.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He considers crossing the Rio Grande by himself. But his friends at camp warn him against it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: They talk about river bandits who kill, a man sucked under by a whirlpool, dogs at Border Patrol checkpoints that respond to German and can smell sweat, the 120-degree desert, diamondback rattlers, saucer-sized tarantulas and wild hogs with tusks. Some immigrants, dehydrated and delirious, kill themselves. Their leathery corpses sway from belts around their necks on whatever is sturdy and tall. Water jugs lie empty at their feet.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: El Hongo listens. Finally, he decides against going alone. "Why should I die doing this?" he asks himself. Somehow, he will call his mother and ask her to hire El Tirindaro.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: On May 18, he awakens to find that someone has stolen his right shoe. He spots a sneaker floating near the riverbank. He snags it. It is for a left foot. Now he has two left shoes. Bucket in hand, he hobbles back to the taco stand, begging along the way. People give him a peso or two. He washes a few cars, and it starts to rain. Astonishingly, he has put together 20 pesos in all.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: That is enough to trade in his 30-peso phone card for one worth 50 pesos.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He will use the 50 peso card to call his old boss at the tire store. If the boss reaches his aunt and uncle, and if they know his mother's number, and if his aunt or uncle will call him back ...

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: It is May 19. Father Leonardo Lopez Guajardo at Parroquia de San Jose is known to let migrants phone from the church if they have cards. Each day, he serves as their telephone assistant. In flip-flops, he pads to the door every 15 minutes or so and summons someone for a return call.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: In late afternoon, Enrique reaches his old boss with his request. Two hours later, the padre bellows Enrique's name. As always, word spreads through the courtyard like wildfire: Someone named Enrique has a phone call.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "Are you all right?" asks Uncle Carlos.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "Yes, I'm OK. I want to call my mom. I've lost the phone number."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Somehow, his boss has neglected to tell them this. Do they have it with them? Aunt Rosa Amalia fumbles in her purse. She finds the number. Uncle Carlos reads it, digit by digit, into the phone.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Ten digits.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Carefully, Enrique writes them down, one after another, on a shred of paper.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Just as Uncle Carlos finishes, the phone dies.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Uncle Carlos calls again.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: But Enrique is already gone. He cannot wait.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: When he talks to his mom, he wants to be alone; he might cry. He runs to an out-of-the-way pay phone to call her. Collect.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He is nervous. Maybe she is sharing a place with unrelated immigrants, and they have blocked the telephone to collect calls. Or she might refuse to pay. It has been 11 years. She does not even know him. She had told him, even harshly, not to come north, but he has disobeyed her. Each of the few times they have talked, she urged him to study. This, after all, was why she left--to send money for school. But he has dropped out of school.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Heart in his throat, he stands on the edge of a small park two blocks from the camp. Next to the grass is a Telmex phone box on a pole.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: It is 7 p.m. and dangerous. Police patrol the park.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Enrique, a slight youngster with two left shoes, pulls the shred of paper from his jeans. They are worn and torn; he is too tattered to be in this neighborhood. He reaches for the receiver. His T-shirt is blazing white, sure to attract attention.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Slowly, carefully, he unfolds his prized possession: her phone number.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: He listens in wonderment as his mother answers.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: She accepts the charges.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: Mami?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: At the other end, Lourdes' hands begin to tremble. Then her arms and knees. "Hola, mi hijo. Hello, my son. Where are you?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "I'm in Nuevo Laredo. Adonde estas? Where are you?"

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "I was so worried." Her voice breaks, but she forces herself not to cry, lest she cause him to break down too. "North Carolina." She explains where that is. Enrique's foreboding eases. "How are you coming? Get a coyote." She sounds worried. She knows of a good smuggler in Piedras Negras.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "No, no," he says. "I have someone here." Many smugglers deliver their clients to bandits. Enrique trusts El Tirindaro, but he costs $1,200.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: She will get the money together. "Be careful," she says. Go to a hotel. Get the telephone number and the address of Western Union in Nuevo Laredo. She will wire money for a room.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: "No," he says. He is camping by the river. But he will call back with the Western Union information, so she can send a little money anyway.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: The conversation is awkward. His mother is a stranger. This is probably expensive; he knows that collect calls to the United States from back home in Honduras cost several dollars a minute.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: But he could feel her love. He places the receiver in its cradle and sighs.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- A Milky Green River Between Him and His Dream
graf: At the other end, his mother finally cries.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Enrique's mother pays smugglers to get him across the Rio Grande and then to her in North Carolina. She cannot sleep. She has visions of him dead.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: At 1 a.m., Enrique waits on the edge of the water.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: "If you get caught, I don't know you," says the man called El Tirindaro. He is stern.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Enrique nods. So do two other immigrants, a Mexican brother and sister, waiting with him. They strip to their underwear.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Across the Rio Grande stands a 50-foot pole equipped with U.S. Border Patrol cameras. In daylight, Enrique has counted four sport utility vehicles near the pole, each with agents. Now, in the darkness, he cannot see any.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: He leaves it up to El Tirindaro, a subspecies of smuggler known as apatero because he pushes people across the river on inner tubes by paddling soundlessly with his feet, like a pato, or duck. El Tirindaro has spent hours at this spot studying everything that moves on the other side.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Enrique, 17, tears up a small piece of paper and scatters it on the riverbank. It is his mother's phone number. He has memorized it. Now the agents cannot use it to locate and deport her. She left him behind in Honduras more than 11 years ago and entered the United States illegally to seek work. In all, Enrique has spent four months trying to find her.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: El Tirindaro holds an inner tube. The Mexicans climb on. He paddles them to an island in midstream. He returns for Enrique with the tube.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: He steadies it in the water.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Carefully, Enrique climbs aboard. The Rio Bravo, as it is called here, is swollen with rain. Two nights before, it had killed a youngster he knew. Enrique cannot swim, and he is afraid.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: El Tirindaro places a plastic garbage bag on Enrique's lap. It contains dry clothing for the four of them. Then El Tirindaro paddles and starts to push. A swift current grabs the tube and sweeps it into the river. Wind whips off Enrique's cap. Drizzle coats his face. He dips in a hand. The water is cold.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: All at once, he sees a flash of white--one of the SUVs, probably with a dog in back, inching along a trail above the river.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Silence. No bullhorn barks, "Turn back."

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: The inner tube lurches along. It is May 21, 2000. Agents will catch 108,973 migrants in this area alone during fiscal 2000. The tube sloshes and bounces. Enrique grips the valve stem. The sky is overcast, and the river is dark. In the distance, bits of lights dance on the surface.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: At last, he sees the island, overgrown with willows and reeds. He seizes the limb of a willow. It tears off. With both hands, he lays hold of a larger branch, and the inner tube swings onto the silt and grass. They have crossed the southern channel. On the other side of the island flows the northern channel, even more frightening because it is closer to the United States.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: El Tirindaro circles the island on foot and looks across the water. The white SUV reappears, less than 100 yards away. It is moving slowly along the dirt trail, high on the riverbank.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Its roof lights flash red and blue on the water, creating a psychedelic sheen. Agents turn to aim a spotlight straight at the island.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Enrique and the Mexicans dive to the ground face-first. If the agents spot them and lie in wait, it could spell doom for Enrique. He is closer to his mother than ever. Authorities could deport the Mexicans back across the river, but they could send him all the way to Honduras. It would mean starting out for the ninth time.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: For half an hour, everyone lies stone-still.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Crickets sing, and water rushes around the rocks. Finally the agents seem to give up. El Tirindaro waits and watches. He makes certain, then returns.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Enrique whispers: Take the others first.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: El Tirindaro loads the Mexicans onto the tube. Their weight sinks it almost out of sight. Slowly, they lumber across the water.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Minutes later, El Tirindaro returns. "Get over here," he says to Enrique. "Climb up." He has other instructions: Don't rustle the garbage bag holding the clothes. Don't step on twigs. Don't paddle; it makes noise.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: El Tirindaro slips into the water behind the tube and kicks his legs beneath the surface. It takes only a minute or two. He and Enrique reach a spot where the river slows, and Enrique grabs another branch. They pull ashore and touch soft, slippery mud.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: In his underwear, Enrique stands for the first time on U.S. soil.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: As El Tirindaro hides the inner tube, he spots the Border Patrol.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: He and the three immigrants hurry along the edge of the Rio Grande to a tributary called Zacate Creek.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Get in, El Tirindaro says.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Enrique walks into the creek. It is cold. He bends his knees and lowers himself to his chin. His broken teeth chatter so hard they hurt; he cups a hand over his mouth, trying to stop them. For an hour and a half, they stand in Zacate Creek in silence. Effluent spills into the water from a three-foot-wide pipe close by. It is connected to a sewage treatment plant on the edge of Laredo, Texas. Enrique can smell it.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: El Tirindaro walks ahead, scouting as he goes.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: At his command, Enrique and the others climb out of the water. Enrique is numb. He falls to the ground, nearly frozen.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: "Dress quickly," El Tirindaro says.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: Enrique steps out of his wet undershorts and tosses them away. They are his last possession from home. He puts on dry jeans, a dry shirt and his two left shoes. It has been three days since his right one was stolen, and all he has been able to find is a second left shoe to replace it. He told his mother about it when he called her, but there was no time for her to send any money for a proper pair.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: El Tirindaro offers everyone a piece of bread and a soda. The others eat and drink. Enrique is too nervous. Being on the outskirts of Laredo means they are near homes. If dogs bark, the Border Patrol will suspect intruders.

author: Sonia Nazario
headline: Enrique's Journey- At Journey's End, A Dark River, Perhaps a New Life
graf: "This is the hard part," El Tirindaro says.

author: Sonia Nazario
