But Sam is overcome by an urge to be alone. He lifts the cat off his lap, ignoring a plaintive meow, and silently stands, tottering unsteadily as his thin frame rises in the afternoon light.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He threads his way toward the kitchen, where his mother bends over the sink, washing vegetables for supper. Most 14-year-old boys whirl through a room, slapping door jambs and dodging around furniture like imaginary halfbacks. But this boy, a 5-foot, 83-pound waif, has learned never to draw attention to himself. He moves like smoke.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He stops in the door frame leading to the kitchen and melts into the late-afternoon shadows.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He watches his mother, humming as she runs water over lettuce. The boy clears his throat and says he's not hungry. His mother sighs with worry and turns, not bothering to turn off the water or to dry her hands. The boy knows she's studying him, running her eyes over his bony arms and the way he wearily props himself against the door frame. She's been watching him like this since he left the hospital a few months before.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "I'm full," he says.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: She bends her head toward him, about to speak. He cuts her off.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "Really, Mom. I'm full."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "OK, Sam," she says quietly.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The boy slips behind his mother and steps into a pool of light.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: A huge mass of flesh balloons out from the left side of his face.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: His left ear, purple and misshapen, bulges from the side of his head. His chin juts forward. The main body of tissue, laced with blue veins, swells in a dome that runs from sideburn level to chin. The mass draws his left eye into a slit, warps his mouth into a small, inverted half moon. It looks as though someone has slapped three pounds of wet clay onto his face, where it clings, burying the boy inside.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: But Sam, the boy behind the mask, peers out from the right eye. It is clear, perfectly formed and a deep, penetrating brown.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: You find yourself instantly drawn into that eye, pulled past the deformity and into the world of a completely normal 14-year-old. It is a window into the world where Sam lives. You can imagine yourself on the other side of it. You can see yourself in that eye, the child you once were.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The third of Sam's face surrounding his normal eye reinforces the impression. His healthy, close-cropped hair is a luxuriant brown, shaped carefully in a style any serious young man might wear. It's trimmed neatly behind a delicate, well-formed ear. His right cheek glows with the blushing good health that the rest of his face has obscured.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The boy passes out of the kitchen, stepping into the staircase that leads to the second floor. A ragged burst of air escapes from the hole in his throat -- a tracheotomy funnels air directly into his lungs, bypassing the swollen tissue that blocks the usual airways. He walks along the worn hallway and turns into his room, the one with the toy license plate on the door. It reads "Sam."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The Northeast Portland house, wood-framed with a wide front porch and fading cream-colored paint, is like thousands of others on Portland's gentrifying eastside. Real estate prices have soared, but the Lightners still need new carpets in every room and could use new appliances. Although she'd rather stay home with the children, Debbie Lightner works part time as a bank teller. The paycheck helps, but she really took the job for the health insurance.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: From upstairs, Sam hears 12-year-old Emily and 9-year-old Nathan laughing. The kitchen, though, is silent. The boy figures his mother and father are talking about him and this night. For months Feb. 3, 2000, has been circled on the family calendar that hangs on a kitchen wall.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He grabs a small foam basketball and throws up an arcing shot that soars across the room and hits a poster tacked to the far wall.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: His mother made the poster by assembling family photographs and then laminating them. In the middle is a questionnaire Sam filled out when he was 8. He had been asked to list his three wishes. He wanted $1 million and a dog. On the third line, he doodled three question marks -- in those oblivious days of childhood, he couldn't think of anything else he needed.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The morning routine around the family's Northeast Portland house gets hectic when five Lightners line up for one bathroom, hunt for socks, eat breakfast and rush out the door. But Debbie Lightner still finds time for play with Sam as she challenges his decision about the shirt he'll wear to school.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Finally, his mother calls out. His teeth are brushed, his face washed. He runs his left hand through his brown hair, parting it to the right.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He must imagine what he looks like. There's no mirror to examine his face.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: In this boy's room, there's never been a mirror.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Ready for this, Sam?" asks David Lightner, a weathered jewelry designer who saves money by riding a motorcycle 25 miles to work. Sam nods his head and replies with a garbled sound, wheezing and breathless, the sound of an old man who has smoked too long and too hard.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "OK," his father replies. "Let's go."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: His sister and brother watch from the window as Sam and his parents walk to a Honda Accord that has 140,000 hard miles on the odometer. The boy gets in the back seat, and the Honda backs down the driveway.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Just a few blocks from home, Sam senses someone looking at him. After a lifetime of stares, he can feel the glances.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The Accord is stopped at a light, waiting to turn west onto Northeast Sandy Boulevard, when a woman walking a poodle catches sight of him. She makes no pretense of being polite, of averting her eyes. When the light changes, the woman swivels her head as if watching a train leave a station.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: On school mornings, Sam rustles up his own breakfast, and his sweet tooth sometimes gets the better of him. His wholesome side might lead him to microwave a bowl of hot cereal. But he's just as likely to top it with chocolate syrup.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Grant High School's open house attracts more than 1,500 students and parents. Even though they've come early, the Lightners must search for a parking place. Sam's father circles the streets until he finds one nearly 15 blocks from the school.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The family steps out onto the sidewalk and walks through the dark neighborhood. As Sam passes under a streetlight, a dark-green Range Rover full of teen-age boys turns onto the street. A kid wearing a baseball cap points at the boy. The car slows. The windows fill with faces, staring and pointing.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Sam walks on.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Soon, the streets fill with teen-agers on their way to Grant. Sam recognizes a girl who goes to his school, Gregory Heights Middle School. Sam has a secret crush on her. She has brown hair, wavy, and a smile that makes his hands sweat and his heart race when he sees her in class.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "Hi, Sam," she says.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He nods.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "Hi," he says.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The boy's parents fall behind, allowing their son and the girl to walk side by side. She does most of the talking.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He's spent a lifetime trying to make himself understood, and he's found alternatives to the words that are so hard for him to shape. He uses his good eye and hand gestures to get his point across.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Two blocks from Grant, kids jam the streets. The wavy-haired girl subtly, discreetly, falls behind. When the boy slows to match her step, she hurries ahead. Sam lets her go and walks alone.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Grant, a great rectangular block of brick, looms in the distance. Every light in the place is on. Tonight, there are no shadows.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He arrives at the north door and stands on the steps, looking in through the windowpanes. Clusters of girls hug and laugh. Boys huddle under a sign announcing a basketball game.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Sam grabs the door handle, hesitates for the briefest of moments and pulls the door open. He steps inside.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He walks into noise and laughter and chaos, into the urgency that is all about being 14 years old.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Into a place where nothing is worse than being different.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The computer room in Sam's house is out of main traffic patterns, and it's a place where Sam can slip off into his own world. On the Internet, Sam is just another screen name in a chat room, where his words speak for themselves, unfiltered by his distorted voice or his appearance.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Years later she still wonders if it was something she missed, some sign that things weren't right. But it wasn't until her seventh month that Debbie Lightner learned something had gone terribly awry.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: She struggled to sit up on the examination table. The baby, her doctor said, was larger than it should be. Debbie watched him wheel up a machine to measure the fetus. She felt his hands on her stomach.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "Something's wrong," the doctor said again.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He told Debbie he would call ahead to the hospital and schedule an ultrasound. He laughed and told Debbie he just wanted to be sure she wasn't having twins.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The next morning, at the ultrasound lab, the technician got right to work.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He immediately ruled out twins.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Then, a few minutes into the test, the technician fell silent. He repeatedly pressed a button to take pictures of the images on the monitor. After 30 minutes, he turned off the machine, left the room and returned with his boss. The two studied the photographs.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: They led the Lightners down the hall to a prenatal specialist. Their unborn child, he said, appeared to have a birth defect. The ultrasound indicated that the child's brain was floating outside the body.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He had to be blunt. This child will die.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Some parents, he said, would choose to terminate.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: No, Debbie remembers telling him. She and her husband were adamant that they would not kill this baby.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: On Sunday, Oct. 6, 1985, six weeks before she was due, Debbie went into labor at home. David drove her to the hospital, and the staff rushed her to the delivery room for an emergency Caesarean.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: She heard a baby cry. A boy. The boy they'd decided to name Sam.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: She passed out.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: When she came to, she asked to hold her child.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: No, her husband said. The boy was in intensive care. He needed surgery.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: David handed his wife two Polaroids a nurse had taken. A bulging growth covered the left side of the baby's face and the area under his neck.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: What is it? Debbie asked.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: I don't know, David said. But he's alive.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: When the Lightners arrived at the neonatal ICU, they were led to an isolette, a covered crib, that regulates temperature and oxygen flow. A nurse had written "I am Sam; Sam I am" -- a line from "Green Eggs and Ham" by Dr. Seuss -- and taped it to the contraption.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Wires from a heart monitor snaked across the baby's tiny chest. He was fragile, a nurse said, and they couldn't hold him.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The mass fascinated Debbie, and she asked if she could touch her son.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The nurse lifted the cover of the isolette, and Debbie reached down with a finger. The mass was soft. It jiggled. Debbie thought it looked like Jell-O.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The nurse closed the cover.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Debbie and her husband returned to her room, and she climbed into bed. She picked up one of the pictures her husband had given her and covered the mass with her fingers to see what her son should have looked like. He had brown hair and eyes.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: She wept.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The temptation is to break ranks during a family portrait, and wave when a neighbor drives by. Still almost everyone stays in character, Nathan, 9, is a cutup who mugs for the camera. Emily 12, tries to stay dignified. Maggie, the vocal family dog, is uncharacteristically quite, but David and Debbie are their naturally casual selves.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Tim Campbell, a pediatric surgeon known for tackling tough cases, walked into the ICU and peered into the isolette. The boy had a vascular anomaly. They were rare enough, but what this tiny infant had was even rarer. The anomaly was a living mass of blood vessels. And it had invaded the left side of Sam's face, replacing what should have been there with a terrible tangle of lymphatic and capillary cells.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The malformation extended from his ear to his chin. Campbell knew there was no way to simply slice it off, as if it were a wart, because it had burrowed its way deep inside Sam's tissue. Doctors knew little about such anomalies except that they were made up of fluid-filled cysts and clots that varied in size from microscopic to as big as a fingertip.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Campbell gently pulled the baby's mouth open. The mass swelled up from below and wormed its way into his tongue, threatening to block his air passage. He could barely breathe, and only immediate action would save him. He asked a nurse to direct him to the Lightner room.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Campbell introduced himself, explaining the surgery. He didn't mince words.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: I'm going to be in there a long time, the Lightners remember him saying. It's risky. He's little, and he's premature.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Campbell operated for six hours and removed 1 pound, 10 ounces of tissue from under Sam's neck. He operated a second time to remove bulk above his left ear and to ease his breathing with a tracheotomy tube. But there was no way, he told the Lightners, that he could safely remove the mass on Sam's face.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Campbell had sliced away a quarter of the infant's weight. Baby Sam, who weighed 5 pounds after the surgeries, spent three months recovering in the hospital.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He was 3 when he first realized he was different. His father remembers Sam running up and down a hallway when he stopped in midstride and stared at his image in a full-length mirror. He touched the left side of his face, almost as if to prove to himself that he was in fact that boy in the mirror.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He cried.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: His parents had been expecting this day. His father bent over and took Sam by the hand. He led him to a bedroom off the hall. Debbie joined them. David lifted Sam onto the bed. And then his parents told the little boy the complicated facts of his life.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Except for the deformity, Sam was normal in every way. But everyone outside Sam's circle of family and friends would have a hard time seeing beyond the mass of tissue on his face.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: And so it was.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: A little girl grabbed her mother's hand when Debbie pushed Sam, in a stroller, onto an elevator. The girl stared at the little boy, pointed at him and then loudly told her mother to "look at the ugly baby."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Bystanders often assumed Sam was retarded. A woman asked Debbie what drugs she had taken during her pregnancy. Strangers said they'd pray for the boy. Others just shook their heads and turned away.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: His parents went to another surgeon to see if he could reduce the mass. He removed some tissue from behind Sam's left ear but encountered heavy bleeding and closed up. Even then, the incisions wouldn't heal. Sam bled for six weeks.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: When the Lightners realized their son would have to live with his face, they refused to hide him from the world. They took him to the mall, to the beach, to restaurants. In Northeast Portland, where the Lightner family lived, people talked about seeing a strange-looking boy. "That boy," they called him.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The Lightners enrolled Sam in the neighborhood school. Sam, his breathing labored, caused a stir during registration. Teachers worried about having the boy in their classes.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: But he was an excellent student. He made friends, joined the Cub Scouts and played on a baseball team. He tried basketball for a year, but he fell easily because his head was so heavy.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: When Sam turned 12, he told his parents that he wanted to change his face. They took him to Dr. Alan Seyfer, an OHSU professor who chaired the medical school's department of plastic and reconstructive surgery. What Seyfer saw made him leery.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The mass was near vital nerves and blood vessels that surgery could destroy, leaving Sam with a paralyzed face. Hundreds of vessels ran through the deformed tissue, and every incision would cause terrible bleeding. Sam could bleed to death on the operating table.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Nonetheless, Seyfer, who spent 11 years as a Walter Reed Army Hospital surgeon, wanted to help. And so he scheduled Sam for surgery in June 1998. A month before he asked a friend, the chairman of the plastic-surgery department at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, to join him.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: A week before the surgery, Seyfer and his partner examined Sam one last time. They peered down his throat so they could study the mass without having to make an incision.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: They didn't like the view.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: That afternoon, Seyfer met with Sam and his parents and said he had made an agonizing decision. The surgery was too risky. In good faith, he could not operate.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The news crushed Sam. He realized he had always held out hope that a surgeon would pull him out of the horrible spotlight that targeted him every time he went out in public. But no. He was trapped.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Graduation from eighth grade is a big night for Sam - he wins the citizenship award and receives a huge round of applause from the crowd of parents and students. Sam's father playfully tousles his hair on the way out of the auditorium as brother Nathan watches.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Sam Lightner pedaled his bike as hard as he could, but his family zoomed ahead. His legs ached, and he panted for breath. Even his younger brother could ride his bike farther and longer.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Most days during this spring 1999 vacation, Sam wanted to just lie in bed and watch television.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: And when he spoke, his family kept asking him to repeat himself. No one -- the desk clerk at Central Oregon's Sunriver Lodge, the woman in the gift shop -- could understand him. He garbled his speech, as if he were speaking with a mouthful of food.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: But he wasn't eating. At dinner, he sat with his family, listening, picking at his food, waiting to go lie down on the sofa. Over his protests, his mother took him into the bathroom and weighed him.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Five pounds, she said. He'd lost five pounds. But a later visit to his pediatrician turned up nothing.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Sam woke up one morning in pain. He touched his face and found it tender. The mass was growing. His mother gave him Advil, but the mass continued to swell. Within a week, he couldn't swallow the pill. He stuck his finger in his throat. His tongue felt bigger. By the end of the week, Sam cried continually.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: A doctor removed a lump where Sam's shoulder met his neck, thinking the lump was pressing against a nerve. But the pain continued.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: On Sunday, Aug. 8, 1999, Sam came downstairs from his bedroom. He found his mother outside, sitting on the front porch. He walked out and sat next to her, crying. His speech slurred, and he had to repeat himself. The pain, he managed to tell her, had spread across the entire left side of his face.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The next morning, at the hospital, nurses poked and probed his face. He sat still while strange machines whirled about his head. And then he waited while specialists reviewed the X-rays and CAT scans. They found nothing.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Sam refused to go home. Someone, he pleaded, had to help him.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Doctors admitted him and ran more tests. Four days later, on Aug. 13, the mass awakened.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Pain racked Sam's body. He tried to call for help but couldn't speak. With his fingers, he reached up. His swollen tongue stuck several inches out of his mouth. He punched the button beside his pillow to call for help.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He wrote in a notebook to communicate with nurses and doctors, a notebook his mother would later store away with the other memorabilia of Sam's medical journey.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "I have no idea why. Since I was a baby. I was born with this.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "When I cough hard, little capillaries burst and a little blood comes out.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "Don't touch.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "Please, it hurts."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He held out his arm so nurses could give him morphine. They fed him through a tube.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Then the door to his room opened, and a new doctor walked in. The man asked Sam if he knew him. Sam shook his head.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: I'm Tim Campbell, the doctor said.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: He'd been making routine rounds when he spotted Sam's name on the patient board. Campbell hadn't seen the boy since he'd operated on him nearly 14 years before, the day after he was born.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Dr. Campbell thumbed through the reports at the nurses' station. He checked Sam's chart. The boy weighed 65 pounds -- he was wasting away.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Campbell pulled up a chair.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: How do you feel?

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Sam wrote in his notebook: "Anything to stop the headaches."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Anything else?

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "I really don't think this is going to work out."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: The doctors are trying.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "Please try your hardest."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Hang in there, Sambo.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "I'm in pain. It was really bad this morning."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Campbell made a note to order more morphine.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "I hurt."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: And methadone.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "I'm tired."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: Try to sleep.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: At a Certain Age, Nothing is More Important Than Fitting In
graf: "Will it kill me?"

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Dr. Tim Campbell looked down into Sam Lightner's face. The boy, he remembers thinking, was giving up. Unless something dramatic happened, he would die.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: The 14-year-old lay motionless in his bed at Portland's Legacy Emanuel Hospital & Health Center. His bloated face spilled across most of the pillow. His tongue protruded grotesquely from his mouth, and the swelling on the left side of his face wrenched one eye completely out of position. In late summer of 1999, the deformity he'd carried since birth had suddenly grown to life-threatening size, choking off his airway and esophagus.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Sam, Campbell remembers thinking in blunt medical slang, was "circling the drain." He'd seen the same look in children battling terminal cancer. At a certain point, they accepted their fate and surrendered to death.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: The doctor hurried back to his office, rummaged through his desk drawers and pulled out a slim blue book, a list of every pediatric surgeon in North America. He flipped through the pages.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Campbell paused when he reached the résumé of Dr. Judah Folkman, a cancer researcher he'd met 30 years earlier when they were both young surgeons. Folkman's research team had controlled tumors in mice by stifling the growth of the blood vessels that supplied them, causing a national stir and overwrought speculation that a cancer cure was at hand.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Folkman planned to test his technique on humans for the first time in May 1999. Campbell considered the fact that a wild excess of blood vessels had created Sam's deformity. Maybe, he thought, Folkman's strategy would work on the boy.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: But Folkman, besieged by more than a thousand desperate cancer patients a week, is fiercely protective of his time. He grants no interviews. A secretary screens all calls.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Campbell punched in the telephone number listed in the blue book, hoping Folkman might grant a favor to an old friend. The secretary put him on hold. Then Folkman came on the line.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: His response was discouraging. Sam's malformation was fully formed, and his method worked only on growing tumors. But Folkman suggested Campbell call a pediatric surgeon who worked for him as a research fellow. Campbell scribbled out a name: Jennifer Marler.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: She was a member of the Boston's Children's Hospital Vascular Anomalies Team, which treated malformations just like Sam's. Pleas for help deluge that team, too, and the surgeons can respond to only a fraction. But when Campbell reached her, Folkman's name provided instant access.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Marler suggested that Campbell take some photographs of Sam and send them along with the boy's medical file. Campbell should address the package to her to make sure it didn't get lost in the slush pile.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: The best she could offer was that she'd take a look.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Sam Lightner turned his head and stared straight into the camera while Campbell photographed his face. After Campbell left the hospital room, a psychiatrist walked in, pulled up a chair and began asking questions. Sam scribbled his answers in the notebook he used to communicate.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Then Sam asked a question.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: "Why is this happening?"

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: The psychiatrist had no answer. Instead, he asked another question. Tell me how you feel about life, Sam remembers him saying. Is life unfair?

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: How stupid, Sam thought. His tongue was sticking three inches out of his mouth. He couldn't eat. His left eye bulged abnormally, reacting to pressure that seemed to build each hour. An IV drip line ran into his arm and pumped him full of drugs: morphine, methadone, Celebrex and nortriptyline -- a combination of painkillers, anti-inflammatories and antidepressants. None of them helped. No one could tell him what was wrong.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Is life unfair?

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: "Sometimes."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: And then the swelling receded. Doctors couldn't explain why, but the sudden eruption died down as mysteriously as it had come to life. On Sept. 2, 1999 -- after a month long hospital stay -- Sam went home.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: But everything was different. Physically, Sam was a shell. He had lost 17 pounds and was down to 63 pounds. He could not speak. And the battle with the malformation had scarred him. His mother remembers a listless child who wouldn't stir from bed.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: On Nov. 15, 1999, doctors determined Sam was healthy enough to get back into his old routine. When he returned to Gregory Heights Middle School, however, something had changed. All the talk in the hallways was about high school -- girls, dances, sports. Being popular.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Life as Sam Lightner knew it was ending. All his classmates were obsessed with how they looked and how they fit in. But for Sam, the issues every young teen faces were magnified a thousandfold. He was moving out of the cocoon of familiarity that kept him among family and longtime classmates, who could see past the disfiguring mass he carried on his face. He was moving into a world of judgmental teen-agers and he would carry with him a terrible handicap, a face drastically shortchanged of its ability to reach others with a subtle expression, a slightly raised eyebrow, a flicker on the edge of his mouth. He was being cast among strangers who would turn away from his alien features so fast that they would miss the boy behind the mask.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Like all teens, Sam's perception of how others saw him would determine how he saw himself.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: And when strangers looked at Sam, they first fixated on the left side of his face, a swollen mass that looked like a pumpkin left in the fields after Halloween. His left ear was even more abnormal, a purple mass the size and shape of a pound of raw ground beef. His jaw, twisted. His teeth, crooked. His tongue, shoved to the side. His left eye, nearly swollen shut.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: When he walked to school each morning, he stopped at the crosswalk on Northeast Sandy Boulevard and watched passengers in cars and buses stare at him. When he walked through the neighborhood, he heard laughter and comments.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Once, a neighbor boy led his friends over to Sam's house and knocked on the front door so the others could see Sam's face.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: In late August, a thick envelope arrived in Dr. Jennifer Marler's office. She noticed it was from a Dr. Tim Campbell, an unfamiliar name, and tossed it aside. At the end of the day, after a brutal round of surgery, clinics and lab research, she was about to head home to her husband and three children when she spotted the envelope.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: She dropped into her chair, grabbed it, ripped it open along one end and dumped the contents onto her desk. She started with the medical report: Patient has lymphaticovenous malformation of the left side of face and neck. Condition was diagnosed prenatally. Involvement of the airway necessitated a tracheotomy. Difficulty swallowing necessitated a gastronomy tube. Malformation has grown to the point of orbitaldystopia. She remembered -- the Portland boy.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: She searched through the paperwork and foundseveral photos. She picked one up and held it between her fingers. Thephotograph haunted Marler.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: The boy lay in a hospital bed, staring at thecamera with pleading eyes. He looked like one of the children featured in ads aimed at raising money to help poor kids overseas.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Marler scanned the reports. The kid was on a morphine drip, diagnosed as clinically depressed.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Marler was 38 and had been a doctor for 11 years. Outside of a textbook, she had never come across such a profound facial deformity. He was the saddest-looking child she'd ever seen.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: And she had seen many. A score of photographs hang on her office wall, the faces of children who have set the course of Jennifer Marler's life. Some of the images show children she successfully operated on, relieving them of the deformities that robbed them of their futures. Others tell sadder stories, reminding her of children who died from their abnormalities or who took the risk of surgery and didn't survive.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Marler picked up the telephone and spoke with the nurse who scheduled weekly team conferences for the Vascular Anomalies Team. During the meeting, doctors discuss cases and decide whether they want to tackle them. The nurse said the next chance to present a case would be Sept. 22, 1999, just three weeks away.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: She decided she'd present Sam Lightner's case and argue that he be brought to Boston. First, though, she had to get the facts down cold. She picked up the telephone again, called her husband, apologized and told him to have dinner without her. She talked to her three young daughters and told them Mommy had something important to do.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: The team met Wednesday evenings in the surgical library. Members, fellows and residents gathered around a 15-foot-long oak table, nibbling cookies and sipping soft drinks.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Everyone found a seat, the lights dimmed and the patients' images appeared, one by one, on an overhead screen. The team members flipped through paperwork, scanning each patient's medical history. They spoke in short, clipped sentences, rife with medical jargon, challenging one another, looking for potential problems that might rule out surgery.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Marler remembers studying the paper in front of her. Nineteen children were up for consideration. Fewer than half would be chosen.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: The team moved quickly: The agenda included an 8-month-old girl from Argentina. A 3-year-old girl from Italy. A 9-year-old boy from Minnesota.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Sam Lightner was next. His picture -- the one Dr. Tim Campbell had taken -- flashed on the screen.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Who is he? someone asked.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Marler recalls choosing her words carefully. She wanted to make sure the team knew something of the boy's life. He was in pain, she says she told them. Without hope. The disfigurement severe.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Although the center takes some of the most difficult cases in the world, Marler knew Sam Lightner presented major problems.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Behind her, she heard papers rustle as the team read his medical history. They quickly zeroed in on those risks. They hesitated. Before making any decision, the team members wanted more information.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Next case.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Marler scheduled Sam for the Nov. 3, 1999, meeting. Again the answer was no.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: At the Nov. 10 meeting, she tried again, focusing not on the entire team, but on Dr. John Mulliken, the surgeon who directs the Vascular Anomalies Team and a researcher who's trying to figure out the causes of defects such as Sam's. Mulliken lectures at hospitals around the world and co-founded the International Society for the Study of Vascular Anomalies. He's written 185 scientific articles, 40 book chapters and two complete books.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: The way Marler saw it, a team of doctors would have to operate on Sam. And Marler wanted to be on the team.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: At this meeting, she spent an unusual 30 minutes arguing her case, knowing this was her last chance. She studied Mulliken, an impatient man, as he reviewed the files. She knew what he was thinking -- the horrendous bleeding, and the tangle of nerves in the mass. If Mulliken damaged one, the boy might lose the ability to speak, to close his left eye or to smile.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: She appealed to Mulliken's pride and compassion. No other surgeons, Marler remembers telling him, believe they can fix this.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: She watched Mulliken, Sam's last hope.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: The projector's motor hummed. Sam Lightner's face peered out into the room. Mulliken looked up at that face.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Bring him to Boston, he said.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: On April 7, 2000, Sam Lightner and his parents walked three blocks from their Boston hotel to Children's Hospital. The Lightners silently rode an elevator to the third floor, where a smiling receptionist waved them over and took the Lightner file. Sam found a seat and flipped through a stack of magazines. He caught the eye of a woman sitting across from him. She turned away. Sam saw her whisper something to a woman sitting next to her before both turned back to stare.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: "Samuel Lightner," the receptionist called.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: A woman led them down a hallway to an examination room. Sam climbed onto the table. A few minutes later, the Lightners heard a soft knock.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: She stood 5 feet 7 inches tall and wore a white doctor's smock over a long black skirt with matching black hose and shoes. Her brown hair was cut in a pageboy. "I'm Dr. Marler," she said.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: She sat down on a doctor's stool, tugged on her glasses and fiddled with a string of pearls that lay across her white and blue-striped blouse. "I'm so glad to meet you," she told Sam. A flush spread up his neck.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: Acceptance sometimes comes in the struggle to achieve it
graf: Debbie Lightner dug through her purse and handed Marler a picture taken shortly after Sam's premature birth. Marler stared at the image of the tiny infant. "Boy," she said, "you were a little peanut."

headline: The risks we take can tell us who we are
graf: Even to someone as experienced as Mulliken, the mass is a mystery. X-rays don't show soft tissue. So there's no way of knowing how invasive the mass is or what it's wrapped around. A single nerve leaves the brain and divides into five branches that spread out to control the side of the face. But the mass could rest on top of nerves, or it could spread under them. Or the nerves could snake right through it.

headline: The risks we take can tell us who we are

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: That afternoon Marler showed up at the hospital. It was her day off, but she wanted to check on Sam. She recalls reminding herself, as she made her way to the ICU, to look confident, to hide her worry from the Lightners.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: The Frontier Airlines jet touched down in Portland on July 20th. Sam Lightner made his way up the aisle and into the crowded terminal. He saw his father, brother and sister carrying balloons reading: "Welcome Home." They all hugged Sam and told him he looked good.

headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am

author: Tom Hallman Jr.

headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: Sam weighs his options and makes a quick response that will be colored, as such things are, by everything that has come before. The years of living with his deformity. The decision to risk a life-threatening surgery. The choices he has made -- to take a great chance and to confront life head on. "I am Sam," read the Dr. Seuss line the nurse posted over his isolette when he was born. "Sam I am."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: He wriggles out from under the man's arm.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "No," he says.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "What?"

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "I'll wait with the rest of the students," Sam says.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "But you don't have to."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "I'll wait," Sam says firmly. "This is where I belong."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: The line moves, and Sam watches the administrator walk away. There is no turning back. Sam is carried, step by shuffling step, toward the cafeteria. He descends a flight of steps, walks through a set of double metal doors and pauses, looking out at a sea of students.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: Then the line carries him forward to the first of several registration stations along the cafeteria's wall. Brian Doran, Sam's friend from Gregory Heights, spots him in line, hurries over and hands him a green piece of paper with a locker number and combination on it. Brian, who arrived earlier, has already claimed the locker and requested Sam as a partner.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: Sam feels someone touch his shoulder and turns to face Molly Paterno, an old friend from his neighborhood.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "I was thinking about you all summer, Sam," she says. "I wondered if you had the surgery."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: She studies him.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "Oh, Sam," she says. "You look great."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: Sam moves more easily as the line works its way from station to station. He studies his schedule.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "Sam?"

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: Emilie Bushlen bustles up and leans close.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "Sam, can I see your schedule?"

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: He hands her his slip of paper.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: "Sam," she squeals. "We got word-processing together."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: He blushes.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: The line moves forward. The next stop is for yearbook pictures. Sam looks at the order form, trying to figure out what picture package to order. He selects Package E, the one that will give him two extra prints. One will go to Dr. John Mulliken, the lead surgeon in Boston.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: The other has a place waiting for it on Dr. Jennifer Marler's wall.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: He hands the form to the photographer, who tells him where to sit and how to pose. "OK, kiddo," the photographer says. "Here we go."

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: He lifts the camera.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: Sam Lightner looks straight ahead. This is for the yearbook. This is for history.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: He smiles. Broadly.

author: Tom Hallman Jr.
headline: I am Sam, Sam I am
graf: And a brilliant flash illuminates his face.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: She hopes the ferry won't come, but if it does, she'll climb aboard. She'll tremble as she steps off the landing, because she can't swim, and she can't forget the many times she's crossed this ugly river only to meet more ugliness on the other side.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: But fear has never beaten Mary Lee Bendolph, and no river can stop her. She'll board that ferry, if it comes, because something tells her she must, and because all the people she loves most will board with her, and because if there's one thing she's learned in her difficult life, it's this:

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: When the time comes to cross your river, you don't ask questions. You cross.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: It won't look all that dramatic, just a new ferry taking a 63-year-old great-grandmother and her cousins across a Coca-Cola-colored river. But in this damp cellar of the Deep South, where the river has separated blacks and whites for 180 years, where even the living and the dead are less divided than the black and white towns camped on opposite shores, a new ferry will be like the river itself: more than it looks.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Some say the ferry won't ever come, others say any minute now. Either way, Mary Lee has already seen herself crossing. A round woman with a giggle like one of the river songbirds and a speaking voice pitched between a lullaby and a prayer, she often sees the future in her dreams, and trusts these visions as she does her cousins. They never lie. "The first mind you have when you get up in the morning," she says, "that the right mind. Then another mind come and tell you something else, that the wrong mind."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: This morning, her right mind tells her something's coming, something big. Maybe a ferry. Maybe death. Maybe the end of her holy place on the river, the only home she's ever known. It all seems the same in Gee's Bend, Ala.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Gee's Bend is where the Civil War came and went, but the slaves stayed, and their children stayed, and their grandchildren stayed, and their great-grandchildren, and so on, until today, Mary Lee and 700 of her kin cling to this bulb of bottom land their ancestors were chained to. They bear the surnames of the last slaveholders to live here. They grow corn near the slaveholders' headstones. They come and go amid the ghosts and dust devils that dance on the site of the old Big House.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: The South was once dotted with such places, where slaves lingered long after Lincoln freed them, most famously the sea islands off Georgia and South Carolina. But Gee's Bend is the only place anyone can think of where the slaves did more than linger. They conquered. They outlasted the masters, bought back the plantation and lived upon it in blissful isolation, not a collection of historical anomalies, but a vast family, sharing the same few names and the same handful of fables, like some hybrid of Alex Haley and Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Some of their isolation owes to geography. The Alabama River all but encircles Gee's Bend, carving from the caramel soil a U-shaped peninsula 5 miles wide and 8 miles long, a virtual island set apart from the 20th century, as it was from the 19th. Some of their isolation owes to personality. "Benders" have always held themselves aloof, a regal clan proud of their capacity for solitude. But most of their isolation owes to white folks across the river, who have done everything possible to make Gee's Bend lonelier than a leper colony, and who now--suddenly, oddly--want to bring Gee's Bend a brand new ferry.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: White folks. Mary Lee wonders what they're up to now. Every few decades, they remember Gee's Bend, and so begins another spell of hard times.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: White folks say a ferry would bring the modern world at last to this rural wilderness 60 miles southwest of Montgomery, where the heat-crazed insects sound like a million clocks ticking; where only two businesses exist, a post office the size of a phone booth and a general store with nothing on its shelves; where the night sky is unbroken by a single street lamp or stop light, and Orion feels close enough to gather in your fist, like a cluster of fireflies.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Mary Lee knows better. A ferry would also bring tourists and hunters and developers and criminals and snoops. In other words, the end of Gee's Bend, the last place on Earth still safe enough for children and dead folks to go walking after dark. "When you can sit in a place," she says, "and everybody be lovely--no fussing, no killing--to me, this don't even seem like the USA."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Then why not fight the ferry? She might. Except white folks never take no for an answer, and even some of her cousins are insisting, because a ferry, after all, would settle old scores. "It's a symbol of what we had," she says, "a symbol to what was taken from us."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: A ferry would close a 180-year-old circle, and Mary Lee is made of circles. Her body is round, her face is round, her river is round. In Mary Lee's world, everything is round, because it's not until the end of something--a century, a story, a sentence--that you really understand the beginning. Maybe it's all this ferry talk that's got her mind circling back. She's always had a gift for dreaming the future. Lately, she can't stop reliving the past.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Also, her mind is busy with something else, something more pressing than a ferry, though it feels connected. Mary Lee is sick, violently sick, and her sister recently foretold doom. "Cancer," her sister said, and Mary Lee could only agree.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: She's spent her whole life in this timeless place. How did age manage to find her? She still has the flirty giggle, the smile that makes men trip over themselves in church. How can her hair be sprouting tufts of gray like summer dandelions? Walking down the dirt lane, swinging her arms and looking up at the clouds, she could be a sixth-grader coming home from school. And yet, Mary Lee's life has been a series of sorrows and betrayals, and some days every bit of it shows on her face, despite the faraway look she wears to keep people from her deepest thoughts.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: "Some people have a good life," she says. "But I had a rough life. But I thank God that he helped me come through, and I ain't dead."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: While among the living, she plans to keep moving. Every day, she does a dozen chores, then makes rounds, seeing to the needs of her lovely people, which is how she describes those inside the circle of her heart. She has a mother to nurse, a brother to mind, grandchildren to raise, cousins to bury. Most of her life she picked cotton, now she tends people. If death or a ferry means to stop her, there's nothing to do but wait. Like dreaming the future, waiting is one of Mary Lee's special gifts.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Every Bender knows how to wait. Living here, you learn that fate is like a ferry. It comes when it comes.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: And when it gets here, everyone must cross.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: There was a ferry once.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: A flat-bottomed skiff, it wasn't much more than Huck Finn's raft. When Mary Lee was born, its pilot was a cranky old-timer named Uncle Linzie, who would pole you across the 600-yard river like a Venetian gondolier--if he felt like it.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Benders would ride the ferry into Camden, the sun-bleached country town across the river, for groceries and medicine. Camden, the seat of Wilcox County, was the only source Benders had for basic needs, the ferry their only link.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Still, Benders knew to use the ferry sparingly, because Camden was nearly all white, and most of its 1,000 residents meant to keep it that way. "You'd have to run through Camden," says Lucy Mingo, 68, who lives up the road from Mary Lee, by the swamp. "They was dirty people over there."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Camden was the kind of town where the newspaper got its start in the early 1800s, printing ads for slave-catchers. It was the kind of town where the manager of the Wilcox Hotel would tell a government worker in 1941, "A nigrah is a nigrah. And if you go and try to fix'em up, make somethin' out of 'em, put 'em to livin' like white folks and try to treat 'em decent, you don't do anything but make a mean nigger out of 'em that somebody eventually will have to kill." It was the kind of town ruled for a third of this century by a pear-shaped sheriff named Lummie Jenkins, whose pastimes included hunting quail and tormenting Benders. His thick glasses, Mary Lee recalls, turned his black eyes into burnt corn kernels.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Then, Martin Luther King Jr. appeared.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: In the early '60s, King's voting rights crusade took aim at Wilcox County, where no black had ever cast a ballot, though blacks outnumbered whites four to three. When King called for Benders to march on the Camden courthouse and demand their right to register, whites heard him crying, "Revolt!" while Benders heard him saying, "Cross that river for freedom."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: They heard, and they crossed. The ferry nearly capsized as Benders swarmed into Camden, clapping hands, singing. They didn't always stop at Camden, either. Often they stomped onward through Alabama, joining King in the most famous protests of the civil rights movement.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Some braved the nightsticks and bullwhips of Bloody Sunday, 1965, when marchers crossing the Alabama River at Selma were overrun by state troopers. It was one of the horrific moments of the era, a peaceful demonstration meeting a wall of brute force on the Edmund Pettus Bridge, and it turned America's stomach. Among the thousands of river crossings, it was one that led to change. Five months later, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed into law the Voting Rights Act.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Trampled, beaten, teargassed, jailed, Benders never backed up. ("No white man gonna tell me not to march," Lucy says, jutting her chin. "Only make me march harder.") If they seemed fearless, reckless, the reason was the river. At night, they could slip back into its sheltering arms, where whites didn't dare, or bother, to follow.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: "I loved to go over there," Mary Lee says, giggling. "Just so I could tell the white folks, and Mr. Lummie, 'You can't jail us all.'"

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: King heard about Gee's Bend and had to see. He came one cold February night, three weeks before Bloody Sunday, weary from a virus, ignoring the warnings of his security staff, who feared for his safety in a county run by Sheriff Lummie. Through a sideways-blowing rain, his caravan of cars made slow progress along the mud roads of Gee's Bend, and by the time he reached Pleasant Grove Baptist Church, a sagging barn with planks for pews, the hour was past midnight.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: A pot-bellied stove gave off scant heat. A bare lightbulb hung from the ceiling. Cold rain blurred the windows, and Sheriff Lummie lurked against the back wall. Then King stepped through the front door, and Pleasant Grove became the warmest, brightest, safest place on Earth.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: "They had a little prayer," Mary Lee says. "They sung a song. And then they turned it over to him."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: There was something about King that made Mary Lee's blood quicken, something she'd never seen in a black man before, a quality beyond her powers of description. "It was just like, like...." She searches for the word, shyly, the faraway look falling across her face. Then the look lifts. "It was power."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: King had been losing his voice for days, but he still managed to shake the walls of Pleasant Grove with a sound like nothing Mary Lee had ever heard, or else like everything she'd ever heard blended into a song that gave her goose bumps. It was a thunderclap before a lightning storm. It was a steamboat horn conjuring far-off places. It was Gabriel's trumpet calling her home.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: "He was a God-sent man," Mary Lee says. "He said he was gonna make it better for us colored people, and that everybody could have some of what they want to have."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: King delivered a message that amounted to Revelation for Mary Lee: He told her that she might not speak with perfect grammar, might not own more than one dress, might not be more than a dirt farmer descended from slaves, but she was every bit as good as those white folks across the river. Tears filled his eyes as he shouted, "I come over here to Gee's Bend to tell you--you are somebody."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: No one had ever said that to Mary Lee before.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Another time, Mary Lee saw King in Camden and gave him a big hug. She met him again in Selma and watched in awe as he drank from a "whites only" fountain.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: "I never saw a black person do a thing like that!" she says. "I was so glad. I said, 'I'm going to get me a taste my own self.' My sister tried to hold me back by the coat. I said, 'You're welcome to that coat. I'm getting me some of that water.'"

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: She savors the memory.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: "You know," she says, "it was no more different than other water. But it was colder." Her heart drummed hardest when King described the future. Like Mary Lee, he saw the future in his dreams. I have a dream, he kept saying, I have a dream.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: I have them too, Mary Lee thought.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: It was around then that white folks got together and decided the ferry had to go. Maybe they couldn't stop King, or his movement, but they could sure as hell keep a bunch of troublesome Negroes on Gee's Bend.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: There was no public meeting, no notice in the newspaper. Mary Lee and others just went down to the river one day and found their link to Camden cut. Though cars were rare, and the dirt roads of Gee's Bend were impassable much of the year, Benders now would be forced to drive around the river whenever they needed to buy a hoe or see a doctor.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: "We didn't close the ferry because they were black," Sheriff Lummie said. "We closed it because they forgot they were black."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: On the surface, Mary Lee's river is just another plain brown river, skittering down the middle of the Deep South like a raindrop down a dirty window. But rivers have their faraway looks too. Slow, timid, her river typically keeps to itself, hiding between steep banks the color of blushing cheeks. On hot summer days, it goes through the steaming fields at about the speed of a Model T, giving no sign of its quick temper, no hint of the Indians, settlers, slaves and steamships strewn along its floor, 40 feet down, all guarded by poisonous water moccasins and man-sized catfish and alligators that will bite a hound dog in half. "No one," a Camden minister wrote in the early '30s, "plays in the Alabama River."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: It travels 315 miles, mostly in circles, and like Mary Lee it never leaves Alabama. The errant child of two capricious rivers--the Coosa and Tallapoosa, which twirl down from the Georgia mountains--it does what errant children do: whatever it wants. Above Gee's Bend, it becomes even more erratic, performing balletic loops and sluggish U-turns, staggering left and right before finally crashing into the Tombigbee, which takes it to the sea.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: None of which describes Mary Lee's river.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Her river is a "strong brown god," as T.S. Eliot said of a different river, but also a way of thinking about God. Eternal. Silent. Life-giver and mysterious taker. It's the force that shaped Mary Lee's world, drew it like a hurried artist signing his name with a piece of charcoal in the lower right-hand corner of America. Some people spend their lives resisting what defines them. Mary Lee was baptized in the water that defines her. She takes it as a given, and gives thanks.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Like God, the river is whatever those who love it or fear it say it is. Wild and calm, cruel and kind. For a black daughter of the South, its contradictions run deeper. It begs to be crossed and bars the way. There are reasons, spiritual and logical reasons, why rivers run through the epic poems and hymns of the African American tradition, whether the Congo or Ohio, the Gambia or Mississippi. "I've known rivers," wrote Langston Hughes. "Whoever lifts himself," wrote Jean Toomer, "makes that great brown river smile."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Mary Lee has known only one river, and she's never seen it smile.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Maybe that's why she's always smiling, as if trying to compensate.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: "I'm just a lovely person," she says one morning in the midst of her chores. "I'm not a person to be angry, I never was. When you be pleasant, your light shine better. Your eyes feel better. Your body be more easy. I don't care how much confusionment it is, if I can't laugh and talk with you, and be friendly nice with you, I don't be around you no more."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Half a lifetime ago, Mary Lee relied on the river to protect her from those who couldn't be friendly, particularly a white man she'd never even met, a man she'll meet soon enough, if a ferry ever comes.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: His name is Hollis Curl. As owner of Camden's only newspaper, the Wilcox Progressive Era, he helped lead the fight against King's movement, and in the heat of battle published some regrettable things about Mary Lee's people. "I was as racist as anyone else," he says. "Not to the point where I'd mistreat anyone, but I wanted to preserve our way of life."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Now, steaming his 50-horsepower pontoon past Gee's Bend, past a flock of cattle egrets perched like white question marks in a bare tree, Curl swears those days are as well behind him as the creamy wake of his boat. Today, he's the 63-year-old chairman of the Alabama Press Assn., the genial, grandfatherly figure behind the move to restore the ferry. "I've undergone a metamorphosis," he says. "I'm the best friend [Benders] have."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Not long ago, he was their worst nightmare.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: "There's a code of behavior between whites and niggers," Curl said in 1970. "Say a colored man comes into your place of business wearing a hat. And a white man comes in at the same time wearing a hat. The white man may leave his hat on, and you don't notice this. You probably wouldn't notice whether he had a hat on or not. But if the colored man doesn't take his hat off when he comes in, you're going to notice it. Nobody ever told me to be sure and watch and see if this nigger takes his hat off. He just does."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Curl said and wrote what his readers believed, and enforced their beliefs as well. Besides owning the newspaper, he served as city court judge, jailing blacks whenever they marched through town without a parade permit. "They sang 'We Shall Overcome' so many times," he says, "we started to memorize the words."

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: One day, Curl jailed 410 men and women, a number he cites with pride, to show how much he's overcome.

author: J.R. Moehringer
headline: Crossing Over
graf: Though he wasn't party to the decision, getting rid of the ferry seemed like a fine idea to Curl. If the law couldn't keep the races apart, why not let the river.
